text: Excellent gym with plenty to do: nice bouldering area, nice training area and nice ropes section. Though I didn't use it, the weight/cardio area is huge and looks nice. This is my go to stop when in the area and need a climb. Great community of climbers! They should open one up in Long Beach!! Please!

This is a good gym but way too crowded and I feel like any issue that comes up would be brushed off as "peak times," or "busy." My main gripe is the lack of climbing etiquette and how that can actually be really dangerous. I top roped here for a few hours and on multiple occasions I saw people being really unaware in their lowering or swing off the wall and people not timing the routes correctly in the climbs. This place is so crowded that there was a lot of route crossing. One of the routes I liked best in the session I had to take a mandatory rest for 5 minutes because there was a guy crossing it and taking forever to send. So you will have oblivious climbers with bad manners here. When I tried to give feedback I didn't feel like I was understood, and the guy said, "Well we can't stop people from climbing," which totally wasn't what I was getting at. I was more curious as to the route setting strategy. I really wish gyms would do more to step in when bad etiquette occurs and actively educate guests.  I don't recall seeing any staff on the floor observing. I am used to climbing at a small gym that I am so grateful for. The routes at PG will challenge you and I had multiple regulars tell me the grades are being set at higher difficulty levels lately. Possible reasoning I heard was to help acclimate people to outdoor grades. There was an awesome 5.9 set with long reaches and required a lot of use of the slab. There are also ladderish 5.8s and 5.9s and good routes that require balance work. It all depends. But if you go when it is busy you kind of have to take what you can get which is frustrating if you are looking for a specific grade and certain type of set. The saving grace here is the gym area and locker room. For you $28 day pass you get all access. Gym equipment is clean, lots of organized weights, multiple sets of rings, two moon boards, people are self-aware in the spaces they are using. The locker room has excellent showers and a nice sauna. Towels are provided. And unfortunately although there is signage a lot of people walk around the locker room and bathrooms in their climbing shoes, so fingers crossed you don't get pink eye on the holds. Another plus to this facility is the events. Friendly staff, easy belay cert if you know what you are doing and can communicate it well. I'll probably go back but wouldn't do so regularly and I doubt the cost of membership would be worth what you would have to deal with in terms of how busy this place is all the time.

Planet granite is a good place to climb, not great, not very good, but just an average 2.5 star good.  Let me qualify that while hopefully not coming across as too elitist by saying I came from Salt Lake City, Utah, where there is a climbing community and climbing etiquette is understood at the gym and practiced by patrons of the gym.  Not so at Planet Granite.  I have seen people lower there partners far too quickly onto unsuspecting quests, have seen people cross onto other routes repeatedly, have seen people tie in inappropriately and had to take time to instruct them further as they obviously had not obtained a deep knowledge of climbing safety.   The climbing scene here is overcrowded and fills with chalk late in the day for those concerned with developing magnesium rich lung tissue.  Overpriced, but that is the cost of activity in the Bay Area I suppose.The one place where planet granite stands out, and perhaps its saving grace is the yoga instructors.  They are awesome.  It is hard to imagine that one would receive the best yoga instruction through a climbing gym but yet it is true.  Love their Yoga instructors.

If there's one thing I love it's rules that are not enforced. On 4-5 recent visits, adults who can read have had babies or toddlers in the 14+ area. Not invisible sleeping children, but crying laughing in or out of strollers and am I gonna fall on this car seat left here type of children. Even saw a playpen once. I believe myself to be the only one who is bothered by this but it is so regular I can't understand it.Otherwise I really like this place but something so basic really impacts the enjoyment to such a high degree. It is big and has a little of everything with great staff attitude.

I have been here a few times to boulder with friends. I have gone weekday evenings (which are the most packed), weekends, and holidays when they are opened. Unless you go at an odd time, parking can be a nightmare. Many times, I have to park at the very far end of the parking lot, but hey, at least it's free parking. Upon walking in, I'm always greeted quickly by someone friendly. The whole facility is rather large and they have a very nice gym. The top rope section is very tall and there is bouldering in the front and back. That being said, it always seems to be incredibly packed. I regularly climb somewhere else in San Jose which is a much smaller gym; however, I always feel so much more cramped and rushed to climb certain routes at PG. I think the routes are great but I wish that people would take turns better or watch their kids rather than have their kids jump on walls in front of you or underneath you.

Excellent gym! This is my 2nd time being at PG as I do not have a membership. There are plenty of space for rock climbing/bouldering and different level spread throughout. The rock wall does change about ~4-6 weeks so I thought that was a cool thing PG did to keep it different. Planet Granite is on the more expensive side at $100 monthly pass or $30 daily pass. I usually go with a friend who has a pass since they have one guest pass per month.

Came here with Martin, her friend, and Allen! Parking: pretty spacious! Not the best drawn lines, but you'll be fine.Steps before climbing/using their facility:1) Fill out your personal information and sign the waiver on the iPad.2) Go up to the counter, tell them what kind of pass (ie: day) you want.3) Show your ID, and rent any shoes if needed. 4) Watch a video tutorial in the back area (around 10 minutes long).5) Come back to the front and let them know you are done!Pro tip 1: you can  pay with Apple Pay! Pro tip 2: not sure if it's because I got lucky (I didn't bring my ID), but I showed a picture of my scanned ID and it was fine.Pro tip 3: You can get a free locker from the front desk (after #5) in exchange for an ID (ie: credit card too). Even the V0 and V1 are hard! Definitely got me super sore, but also motivated. There is a backlot where there seems to be some type of other activity going on (looks kind of like a balance beam), so just walk around and see what you want to do!I highly recommend getting climbing shoes...you will feel a lot safer, and also just more OP, hehehe. Borrow chalk from other friendly climbers, and have fun!PS: There is a "gym" in the back area (benches, squat racks, dumbbells and treadmill). There is also a whole section of a wall just meant for gripping practices. This is open for use too!

The Sunnyvale location is a great gym.  I didn't expect to gain access to the fitness area, yoga classes, and training area with a day pass, but it's all access, which is different from other rock gyms I've been to.  This place has a slack line outside, bumper plates, squat racks, moonboards, and free weights in addition to all the climbing you can do.There are 3 bouldering areas, lots of crack climbing, long and short top rope routes, and lead climbing.  I love the big open doors that allow for the breeze to enter!  What's crazy to me is that even with the huge space available, this place gets super busy in the evenings, so you may have to wait to climb.  We prefer to climb on week days when most people are working.  I highly recommend this gym if you live in the area.  You'll never get bored because they set a different wall each week!

I've been coming to Planet Granite for 6 months now, and I have found it to be a solid place to climb. I am still a beginner climber, and I think PG does a good job of accommodating beginners with easy climbs and lots of classes (though I've never taken one myself). The community at PG is also really nice, people are very friendly, even to strangers, so you can definitely meet new people while climbing. There are also lots of squat racks in the weight area, which I also really appreciate. I'm giving PG 4 stars because the gym has gotten wayyyyy too crowded as of late, and it has really made climbing a chore instead of a fun workout/experience. This should improve with the new gym getting built later this year, but as of right now, it's just way too crowded at PG.

Won a free belay lesson for 2, which included learning how to knit tie for climbers, how to belay properly, and safety for both. Our lesson was about 30-45 minutes, and our instructor was incredibly patient. All are given a free harness and shoe rental.We started off on a demo wall learning how to (in order):1) safely harness yourself and check your partner2) tie a fisherman's knot (how to tie rope to harness for climber)3) attaching rope/grigri to harness + how to actually belayThen we moved to rock climbing at the easiest routes. We tested (me, my bf, and another girl in our class) by taking turns being a belayer, climber, and someone practicing knots. Once finished, you're given a temporary belay pass and free day to climb as much as your heart desires.This place also has bouldering, yoga lessons, and a small gym, so there's ample ways to build skills to further yourself.Oh, and a store section to buy any rock climbing/bouldering goods!

ATTENTION: please be aware that more than 1/3 of the climb site is not available!!!And the price is the same.Personally, this is not a fair deal. It is a fact that PG ticket is calculated based on its location and venue size. For example, SF is cheaper than Sunnyvale. Today when I was advising the staff that they should *consider* having a discounted price because so many climb walls are under construction and not available. He said it is NOT possible. Out of goodwills, I listed out my reasons why I think discount should be considered. However, he kept giving me "No". Finally, I told him that I hope he can bring this up to the management team can discuss further. TBH, I expected them to *at least* tell me that they will consider this suggestion. But it seems like there is no room for discussion but a firm NO. To his fairness, he didn't show that he was annoyed by me. I understand that PG charges more $$$ because it is in the Bay Area, but please do not be a bully. I used to love this place but not anymore. PG is too big and popular but is very insensitive to its climbers. Overpriced tickets, crowded space, etc.

Pretty much the Rock Climber's heaven! Planet Granite is famous around the Bay Area/Peninsula as one of the two major gym chains for rock climbing. With multiple locations in SF, Belmont, Sunnyvale, PDX, Planet Granite is slowly expanding its reach to all rock climbers. (Other chain in Touchstone which monopolizes the market down in SoCal and East Bay)For the nitty gritty logistics, PG Sunnyvale is the best rock climbing gym in the Bay Area. Hands up! The staff who run this gym are top notch and their coaches/teams are immensely impressive. The routes/trails are changed every month (at least) and the boulder areas span 4 wall areas, 2 in front and 2 in back. The top rope area is right in between and even when the gym is packed, people can still find time to climb in. Busiest times are of course weeknights starting 7PM. Best times to go are early mornings, late weeknights, or weekends! Weekends are pretty tame and most people who come are non-members/families. Besides rock climbing, PG offers FREE fitness classes and yoga every day! Rock climbing classes are extra $$ but I've heard it was fairly worth it. Expect to always see at least 1 guy topless-- you've been warned. Everyone is super friendly and more than happy to give pointers! I've made some good friends here and the love of the sport really brings the best out of people :)My friend, Ashley invited me to come along January 2nd of this year and her friend, Mark, guest'd me in-- after that I was hooked. PG had everything I was dying for- plenty of boulder and top rope routes, amazing amicable people (being around my age is bonus), nice (free) lockers and accommodations (showers, steam room, etc.), and a hefty area of weights and cardio machines for me to run off my boba.Luckily in January, they have a promotion where the initiation fee of $45 was waived and I signed up for the direct deposit of $95/monthly. Yes my wallet had an initial shock but I quietly whispered to it that it was going to be worth it. Now my New Years resolution of staying fit and healthy is still going strong. I go at least 3-4 times a week to PG to rock climb and cardio/weights. I have yet to top rope and take a class, but I will make a conscious effort to do so ASAP! My standards for a rock climbing gym are skyrocket high. Thanks Planet Granite for being my second home and a slice of heaven.

I thought the facilities are great for climbers and gym users. I particularly enjoy their brand of fitness classes (F10, tbf, alpine etc)Thus far, I've particularly enjoyed classes with Heather, Aaron, Hillary, Rueben and Melissa.For yoga - I recommend the morning classes over the evening ones.

First time visiting this place and I thought it was a great experience. My toddler had a great time climbing and everyone was very friendly. All the climbers had patience and were welcoming to others climbing.  Highly recommend this place.
Super friendly place. Your membership gives you access to everything including unlimited classes. Free guests on fridays I think but the guest passes on other days are doable to get your feet wet.

I've been here on one other occasion to boulder, and my experience with the staff was far from friendly. So when I came here for a belay lesson with two other friends, I was not expecting a lot. Little did I know I was going to experience my best belay class ever! I've had maybe 4 belay lessons in my life spread out over my entire lifetime and I keep forgetting how to do it, so I did another class as a refresher. The instructor, JJ, was extremely clear, fun and friendly! The class took about an hour to an hour 15 min to complete with 4 people. I highly recommend taking a belay class here! At the end, they even give you a little cheat sheet of notes to keep in mind for taking the belay test when you come back. The cheat sheet also came with a couple coupons for 50% your next visit! SO AWESOME. Not only that, the instructor also gave us a length of rope so we can practice at home. TALK ABOUT GOING ABOVE AND BEYOND. This place is excellent and has a wide assortment of climbing and bouldering areas that'll definitely keep you entertained. I recommend going as early as possible, especially on the weekends. From 9-11am it was manageable to do climbs, but once it hit 11am-1pm, it was REALLY CROWDED. To the point where you had to wait for people to climb up and down before going up because a lot of the climbs are close together and zigzag with other ones. The only other downside is the price. For a day drop in pass, it's $28 NOT including the harness. That's another $5. Shoes are another $5. I believe chalk is $1. So if you don't have your own harness, shoes and chalk, you're looking at about $39 for a day pass. I live too far from here to get a membership, which is a little bit more than $1000/year.I'd probably come here every now and then to climb for a day pass price, especially because they have a rope with no knots to practice on hanging from the ceiling, which I've only seen at ClimbWorks in Berkeley and no other gyms I've gone to in the area (perfect for Spartan Race training!).

The membership price hikes, lower frequency of route setting, and crowded conditions has taken away from the value and community feel the gym used to have. It sounds like there are new owners- good for them that they are probably making a lot of money- or at least funding their gym expansion with members. I'll give it another few months to see if things get better, otherwise Touchstone might be my new go to soon.
Pretty big and nice area. Have a small gym and shower place as well. It was a fun time with friends

Word of caution on Planet Granite. It gets crowded and they don't police the areas where the kids are climbing very well. An adult ran under my son while he was falling off the wall. He flipped and landed on his shoulder and head. His arm was broken literally 2mm from the growth plate. He was 2mm away from being permanently disabled. I talked to another parent who kept their child there. They changed nothing after that incident.

Visiting from Boston and we really liked PGSV. Staff were super nice; Arjay is the man and helped us out even though it was crazy busy during the holidays. Def recommend the yoga classes, and climbing all the different walls. Lots of features for rope climbs (chimneys, roofs, crimpy verts, large crack wall section), the setting for bouldering was also pretty creative & fun. The gym section is huge. Fun place to spend the day for out of town visitors.

I climb here regularly. It can be a bit crowded at times, but the staff and management do a great job at monitoring, teaching, being patient and continuously upkeeping the gym, routes and walls. This is my "home gym", so obviously I'm biased, but PGSV is definitely a favorite

OMG I LOVE THIS ROCK GYM.The one and only negative I can point out is that there are no auto-belay devices, so you must have a partner belay you. Other than that, let me get into a list of reasons why this place is awesome:1. The walls are tall- most routes are probably at least 40 feet2. The routes are incredibly easy to follow. They're organized by the colors of the holds, rather than colored tape that branch from the holds. 3. Many routes are very creatively set. Some have you zigzag a lot while others require the use of the naturals on the wall itself. (I uploaded a picture of my favorite route- it makes you climb up one side of an arch, grab holds at the high point of the arch, and literally swing so your momentum can allow your feet to reach a ledge on the other side of the arch- and then you continue climbing upwards. It was so challenging and creative!)4. Many sections have "crack-only" ascents if you're into that. 5. There are many bouldering options and a bouldering "lap wall". 6. There's gym equipment and miscellaneous stuff like a slack line and monkey bars- ones that have you change directions 90 degrees during the traverse. If I had a robot as a belay partner, I don't think I would ever leave this place.
Great gym! Great music! Great people! Lots of fun. I spend pretty much every day there...Love it.

I had a great experience here thanks to Jess! It was our first time here and we wanted to climb with robes but couldn't because there was no more space for lessons. Jess was so sweet to offer us private lessons after she got off work!! She always hooked it up with a sweet deal! Thank you Jess if you see this!!! It was really fun and I would definitely come back. People are very friendly here and offered us help if they saw us struggling lol My only complaint would be the smell of the shoes. Kinda reminded me of went dog. Other than that it was a wonderful experience! Definitely call beforehand if it's your first time for a lesson. Also students are $22 before 5pm!

I take my 7 year old here and we both just love it. We first took the belaying lesson which was a lot of fun. And then I enrolled my daughter in 2 consecutive winter camps. The place is fun, the staff is patient and knowledgeable and the facilities while packed always seem to have some open climbing spaces - never have to queue up for too long. The parking is a bit painful and I wish that there was a bit more heating in the winter, but those are fairly minor nits in the large scheme of things.

This place is a rock climbing wonderland! It's huge, spacious, and you really don't need to worry about anyone kicking you in the face!There are all kinds of people here: noobs, groups, couples, and the elites. The people that work here really enforce the safety of each person. You'll be taken through a 10 minute instructional session about how to climb, tie, and get down. It was fun and I had a blast letting my inner Spiderman out. My arms were hurting the next day, but that must be a good thing lol. Like I said earlier, there's all kinds of people with different skill sets. You can tell who are frequent fliers, couples, and elites (because of their climbing styles and their sexy muscular backs. Yum!)Had a blast. Kind of pricey, but I'll be sure to come back. Thank you!

It's been a week since I got my membership, and I thought I share some of my thoughts. This review will be coming from a olympic weightlifter, and is aimed towards weightlifters. I don't plan to rock climb; I'm deathly afraid of heights.First of all, I'm a weightlifter and I come here for the bumper plates, squat racks, and cardio machine because the price is reasonable. Other olympic weightlifting gym in the South Bay charge (crossfit gyms mostly) $200+ a month for one to just lift weights which I think is insane.  Also, there a super cool sauna that you can use.OBSERVATIONS: 1.Shoe policy seems to be lightly enforced, and even nonexistent. There are quite alot of gym goers here, who think it's ok to walk around barefoot, and this is especially noticeable in the free weights and squat rack areas. There are a number of people who will start squatting in the racks, or perform deadlifts without wearing shoes, and even socks!. Yuck. - This is very dangerous, especially if a weight falls on your foot. Sure, some footwear might not prevent alot of damage if this were to occur, but it's better than nothing. (take this advice from a weightlifter whose done this; bruised toes hurt like ****, even with a shoe on.)- Going around shoeless is very unsanitary. Self-explanatory. There are parts of the free weight/crossfit flooring that smell like stinky feet. Gross. You don't want to pick up someone else's foot fungus, nor do you want your children too right? (So please leave your shoes on!)2. During the weekdays, 4pm-6/7pm can get ridiculously busy. Especially as the clock hits 6pm, an influx of people come for the crossfit class. Definitely try to plan around or avoid this time block, if you want to use the free weights. If you come in the morning during a weekday, the gym is nearly empty.3. Bathroom, showers, and locker room seem decently clean, especially for the amount of people who are constantly in and out. Sometimes the trash bin overflows, but it's not a deal breaker. Locker usage is complementary, and all you need is to bring a lock. The inside of some lockers can be dirtier than others. There's a paper towel dispenser and a hand dryer, so you can choose between which to use.4. Equipment: There are more than a dozen barbells, both women 35lbs and mens, so that's cool. Lots of gym only have men 45 lbs barbells. There are 3-4 Rogue 2.0 barbells, and I've done some snatched and Clean and Jerks on them. They're pretty decent. Sleeves spin well. Knurling is ok.You can also bring your own barbell in if you choose; you can't store it overnight though. 5. Chalk: A BIG BONUS! Since this is a rock climbing facility, chalk use is very much welcomed! This is awesome, as lots of commercial gyms ban and look down about chalk. The weightlifting area has 2 bags of chalk that anyone can use. 6. Parking can sometimes be difficult to find, depending on what time you come. Also, the way the parking spots are arranged takes some getting use to. Each lane of parking spots alternates in the direction they travel, as the lanes are all one way only. These are my observations for now, and I'll probably update this later.

The rock climbing section is great. Lots of variety with a range of difficulties. I also like the regular gym section, although I wish they had more than one stair stepper and the weights/stretching area is always super crowded.  Most of the climbers have good etiquette but I have seem some improper belaying and people climbing too close to each other and falling/kicking folks next to them in the head. That was pretty scary to witness.  I've taken some of the yoga classes and I am really happy with them. Overall this is a great, well rounded gym for those interested in training for mountaineering and other outdoorsy activities and general wellness.My major critique is that some patrons bring their young (like, toddler age) kids over to the weights/stretching area which is SUPER dangerous. They completely disregard people who are carrying around heavy weights or are on the mats doing planks, etc. Their kids run around *at their own peril* and get in the way of people trying to work out. Today there was a man rolling a yoga ball back and forth with his three year old, right in the middle of the floor exercises mats. I have submitted comment cards to the management and they've completely disregarded me. Safety for everyone should be their first concern and it clearly isn't.

Nice gym! Good routes, good workout space. People are nice, check in is easy. Enough racks to workout, good spots to hang board. The routes are fun and interesting. I do with they changed them a little more often, but overall this is a nice climbing gym!

Epic Climbing gym with really friendly staff/instructors. This is the place that got me hooked! I took Climbing 101 and the lead climbing class here- my instructors, Steve and Justin, were incredibly patient and encouraging. The walls have some interesting variation and the community of climbers is pretty chill.

Finally tried this place out and it was better than I thought (and better than the pics made it seem). My friends go weekly so I joined in. It was fairly quick to join, signing a waiver, renting shoes/harness for $6 and watching a safety video. I have long nails so I was told by 3 ppl to cut them short which I was sad about. They had nail clippers at the front so I guess it's common to make ppl clip their nails. Then it was straight to the climbing walls! I was a little intimidated though it didn't look like anyone cared how well you did. I did the "easiest" bolder climbing one and got scared close to the top and came down. It took some encouragement from my friends but I went back at it. Each time, I got less scared and maybe a tad more confident until I finally reached the top! Took an hour but at least I did it. Then we moved to the belay climbing wall where you're harnessed. Went up to the top with no problem and then tried some of the harder ones. I'm scared of heights so to be able to do this was great. I think starting with bouldering makes sense and then to belay since it's higher. When I asked,  I one could tell me which one was easier so hopefully that helps. There were kids doing both which was awesome! After, we worked out on the machines, enjoyed the sauna etc. I just did a guest pass but I'm considering joining - it was a really great workout! After a few hours, my hands were swollen and myForearms were sore but it was worth it!
Went today for some bouldering and it was all closed off. Why have a rock climbing gym with no bouldering?

Happiest place ever, if you love climbing or yoga. I can stay there for so many hours.I love the routes, especially the ones with very few but huge holds, where you need to jump or do some challenging balance exercise. I love that the members are friendly and helpful. They can give you useful tips because everyone loves learning and improving. Of course, the people who work there are very helpful too.I love it that if you don't have a belay partner, they'll always call for one, and most of the times someone will show up.Finally, I love to see people of all ages climbing, as well as families at the gym. We don't have kids yet, but when we have them we'll teach them how to climb at Planet Granite. Some people even bring their toddlers at the gym and that makes the gym an even happier place. Thank you, Planet Granite, for being flexible on that!

FIRST TIMERSYou can't climb until you have completed the belay class. The belay class schedule is:Monday - Friday: 6pm, 7pm and 8pm; Tues, Weds & Thurs also at 5pm.Saturdays: 10am, 11:30am, 1pm, 2pm, 3:30pm and 4:30pmSundays:9:30am, 10:30am, 11:30am, 12:30pm, 1:30pm, 2:30pm and 3:30pThe class is about an hour. You learn safety checks, how to belay (the person who is controlling the ropes for the person who is climbing), and do an entry practice climb. The class is $30 and includes your rentals. You'll get a temporary belay card so you can get out there and climb on your first day. You can't get a permanent one until you pass the belay test, but you can't take the test same day. If you decide you enjoy climbing, you can purchase the 5 visits for $70 special one-time deal (I believe the cost of the pass can go towards your initiation fee as well, if you decide to become a member).RETURNINGNext time you come, take the belay test. If you pass, you get a permanent one. Depending on how badly you fail, you'll get a temporary card so that you can practice more. The belay test is some questions about what you're safety checks are, how you tie the knots, and to demonstrate belaying (getting ready, belay as the climber climbs, climber stops, climber slips, and climber descend). Refresh your memory with the videos on the site: planetgranite.com/sv/cli….Rates are $25 for a day pass (this varies across PG locations in the Bay). Rentals are $6 for shoes and harness. Membership rates are $88/month, initiation rate is $45.FACILITIESThis location is half rock climbing facility and half gym. There are normal weights and treadmills as well as yoga class offerings. The bathrooms and showers were clean and looked fully stocked. The rock climbing side had a variety of wall levels and bouldering areas. There are only a few super beginner walls (levels lower than 5) but might as well push yourself with the level 7-8 walls. There are lockers in the bathroom, but there isn't a secure location near the walls to put your stuff, so just don't bring valuables.TIPSWhat to wear: comfortable, form-fitting clothes that won't get in your way while you climb or flash anyone below you.What to bring: water bottle and socks.What to expect: calloused hands and being super sore for the next few days. Drink your protein!

Sick gym. Really big, lots of routes. Definitely like 75th percentile plus in terms of the whole country.Nice staff. Super nice, easy to hang with, find a climbing partner, help you buy gear, etc.A bit expensive. 25 bucks. But you pay for it being one of the premier gyms. Great place for a date. Great place to workout. Great place to hang out.Check it out!

Fantastic gym. I've been going here for almost 2 years and love it everything I go.The only downs to this place is that it's pretty expensive compared to the other gyms. I understand inflation and maintenance but it still hurts every month. Parking here during peak hours is horrific. Sometimes you have park at the far end of the lot because there are so many people and it doesn't help that the lot is shared with several other companies. It's kind of hard to avoid peak hours because most people have 9-5 jobs so the only time you can go is early in the morning, which isn't bad but after work it's painful. Sometimes you'll be waiting awhile because so many people want to climb the problems you want to do. This goes for both bouldering and top roping. I've used the weights area and cardio machines and in general everything is well maintained. Although some of the cardio machines could be wiped down more often. I've seen cleaner machines at an active 24 hours. It's great that it offers yoga, spin and cross-fit. I've been to the yoga classes before and it is no joke. Great teachers who have a nice routine and passionate about the class.

This is specific to their statement that they host birthday parties at this facility. If I could I would give 0 stars. They do not have a room for the birthday party group. They just set your stuff outside and hopefully everyone is on the honor code and won't walk off with your stuff.  We could not do snacks or cake! No cake for a kids party ... Uncool. There is so special place for the birthday kid of honor to climb. There was no separate line at check in so some kids had to wait 20 minutes in the regular (only) check in line before they could join the party. It was so crowded Sunday afternoon that the kids had to be stationed at 2 levels for 18 kids. It gets pretty monotonous climbing the same levels every time. I can go on, but hopefully this review gives you pause if you are considering hosting a party there.My gripe is that they say they totally host birthday parties. Since we've had positive experiences climbing and bouldering there before we thought great. If they just said they don't do parties and stuck to what they do well, all could have been averted. Feeling bait and switched :(

Too crowded. Exceeds fire capacity some nights!!!! There are too many children as well to the point of feeling like you are at school. I enjoy San Francisco because of the lack of children. The yoga classes are too full and frequently people are turned away due to lack of space. When you do get a space in a yoga class, expect to have your mat touching on 2 to 3 sides.

The short: fun place to beThe energy here is great and people are fun to talk to! Tons of engineers/technical thinkers who transfer problem solving at work to bouldering/rock-climbing routes here. Most of the members are on the youger side. I've been here twice, both on a friend's guest pass.Check-in process is easy.1) First time was a lesson for rock climbing. The instructor was very helpful, teaching commands, how to tie the rope and how to be a belayer. There are a plethora of routes to choose from.2) Second time was for an abs class. Brutal for somebody who doesn't regularly work out abs. No pain no gain! It hurt to laugh afterwards and for the next couple days. Thankfully, the instructor offers tips for people who are at different levels.Lockers are clean and showers are available too.This place also offers slacklining, that thing where people use their hands to climb up narrow grooves/crevasses, cardio (facing the climbing area, which makes it fun to people watch!) and weight-lifting equipment. Parking can be difficult especially on weeknights.Verdict: if I lived in the area, I would visit more often

I'd give it a 4.5 star rating. Service (5/5): everyone's super helpful and patient. Don't be afraid to ask questions! I recently took the belay training and the employee who trained us was very patient and nice. Rock climbing/bouldering(5/5): even though it gets crowded sometimes, there's a lot of different levels offered for both bouldering and rock climbing. Gym (3.5/5): honestly, the main part of PG is the climbing part. The gym is only there for people to do some cardio, but none of the machines look super nice or new. The whole gym area kind of looks dull. Monthly membership is pretty expensive, but as long as you go a few times a week, it'll be worth it!

I enjoyed rock climbing.  There, I said it.  And I really mean it.After an incident many years ago that involved me climbing up a pole, standing on top of it and  then jumping off the thing to reach for a trapeze bar, I never thought I could do anything that involved climbing or heights again.  I have a fear of heights.  Yet I love hiking, go figure.I came here for a team building event.  Like others in my group I approached this activity with trepidation and angst.  Sweaty palms anyone?  However, I figured I could go up a few feet then come back down and call it a day.We were split up into groups of 5 or 6 people and received a lot of instruction on how to tie the ropes, how to wear the harness and plenty of instruction on stay safe.  Our instructor was the BEST!  He was patient and tested us constantly to ensure we knew what we were doing.  We had to practice a few times, which helped a great deal.  With all this repetition, I felt better about what we were going to do.  While watching my colleague climb up first, I slowly started to feel more comfortable.  When it was my turn I took my first step up, told myself to take my time and go for it.  Honestly, that first step was the hardest and slowest.  After that I started to head on up at a pretty decent pace.  It wasn't as hard as I thought and I knew the ropes were there to catch me if I fell.  Trust the ropes and trust your partner!  Once I slapped the wall at the top, I told myself to relax and sit back.  Rappelling down was the best part!  Woo hoo!  Most of us were able to take 2 climbs before our time was up.  Some made it up all the way, some made it up half way.  Everyone had fun and that's all that mattered.Parking was easy for us as we came in the late morning on a weekday and it was relatively empty inside.  Signing in was a breeze and the staff was friendly and helpful .  Make sure to wear socks (thin is better) if you are renting their shoes (they are meant to be tight).  Wear comfortable, stretchy clothing to allow for movement.  We didn't use a locker but stored our stuff in the cubbyholes.They offer fitness classes and have standard gym equipment on site as well.  I did not try them out so I cannot comment on those features.I look forward to trying this again (did I really say that?).  Hopefully their other locations are just like this one.   This is a great place to hold team building events, parties and social outings.

I climbed for the first time EVER, and I'm glad I got to do it at Planet Granite!Climbing has always been something I really wanted to try out, so my friends and I finally decided to check out PG. We came around 3pm on a Monday and were able to get the the student price ($18), which didn't include shoe rentals (an additional $4).My group primarily stuck to bouldering and didn't do the top ropes. Although it was my first time climbing, I didn't feel intimidated by the crowd at all. Many of the people who came were actually extremely helpful when I was working out different paths and different levels during my time there. The staff was also extremely friendly - whenever I had a question, they were always ready to answer my questions! Couple of downsides that I observed:- Some of the holds were faded, so I had a hard time distinguishing between colors, especially when I was mid-climb trying to figure out where to go next. (My mantra for the day was if you can't tell up close... it's whatever color you believe it to be! Hahaha, oops!)- As the night continued on, it got more and more crowded so there was sometimes a wait to do a route, but I guess the bright side is that they're open pretty late (11pm).Overall, I think this was such a fun experience, and I would love to go again very soon!

A great gym in many respects!I enjoy their Sunnyvale branch then Belmont then San Fransisco. Never been to their Oregon branch.  Mostly, size matters in this industry. A 20' by 20' wall is going to feel short and boring quickly where as several 70'+ routes will feel refreshing.Sunnyvale provides enough wall space that their route rotation can effectively bring in new routes. (such as you will see new routes about every 4 weeks) The other plus is how diverse their setting team is. Typically I try to be blind to who set the route before I have ascended it enough. It is nice to get to know who are making your problems.  --------------------------------What do I get out of Sunnyvale that Belmont doesnt have?: Belmont is smaller, shorter and generally just a mini version of Sunnyvale. Sunnyvale gives you more similar routes so you can train at several levels on vertical no overhang vs having major overhang and everything in the middle.Belmont does have more specialized sections, 2 vs 1 chimney and cracks and flakes that are better integrated and better representational of real world rock formations. Often Belmont has fewer climbers per their wall space which can be attractive when you are almost armpit to armpit at Sunnyvale (comparing weekday peak to peak times).The bouldering is clearly healthy and vibrant at Sunnyvale. Belmont just doesnt have the real-estate for bouldering. --------------------------------PRICING: I've strategized with their owner on how to diversify their audience and sadly that isnt something that can be agreed upon.  This is where I'm split on the fence. If you can pay out right for monthly memberships on an ongoing basis, that is the best plan (assuming you are climbing at least 2 times a week + other activities at PG).  That said if you want to get price to not be contingent on frequency then the price point is quite significant towards your pleasure rating.

I am so happy I joined. Love their hours, staff is always super friendly and helpful. The sauna is clean and usually empty and amazing, and there are always clean towels handy. They gym is awesome, there's plenty of space. I've only gone to one yoga class so far, and that was one of the main reasons I joined. Surprisingly, I've gotten really interested in rock climbing. Bouldering mostly, and top rope when I have a friend. They change routes frequently, and the place is huge, so there's always something new and exciting. I try to go before work or during the day if I can, to avoid crowds. It does get crazy during their peak hours (5-9 on week days), and I avoid those times.I'm excited to be able to try out their other locations as well.

This place is stupid busy. And there are literal lines for bouldering. The routes are too close together, my partner got nearly knocked down when the person next to him had to catch their climber. The place is big but it feels like a scene. That being said the selection of routes is great and it's nice and roomy once you're on the walls. I can't say I'd buy a membership here. I miss Utah and Colorado climbing gyms.

Great routes and friendly staff. Took a class here and the beginner training was very easy to follow. It can get very crowded so try to go extremely early or during the day to avoid the hippees, purests and grass eating Whole Foods shopping elitists

For anyone who's ever been to a Touchstone gym (specifically, Great Western Power Company), you will quickly realize that this place is extremely disappointing in comparison. I've been trying to give it the benefit of the doubt and am happy just to have a climbing gym near Palo Alto; but if you at all have a choice, stick with Touchstone. My reasons are as follows:After being a loyal GWPC member for 3+ years, the first difference I noticed was the people. While GWPC was extremely diverse with lots of hip, young, fun, and FRIENDLY people, I couldn't help but immediately notice how fratty and white-washed PG was. Many of the staff appear to have more of a sense of entitlement than a sense of humor (which is my least favorite attribute in a human). They also play absolutely god-awful 90's crap rock (like MatchBox 20) that makes you want to slit your wrists instead of getting pumped in the evening for your climb/workout.Similarly, the weights here suck. I appreciate that they have a bigger space where you can do weightlifting/crossfit-type exercises on your own; but the hand weights, pre-loaded bars, and weight machines all appear to be older pieces of crap. A bit disappointing seeing how much money you drain each month for the privilege of being there.Next, the place is quite messy. I went into the bathroom and two of the three toilets had mountains of paper/excrement sticking out like a small, disgusting island. There is also always piles of dark hair in the sinks, and the weights are never in the right place when you're looking for them. Perhaps if the attendants spent less time putting gel in their hair and more time focused on the gym, this would improve.And finally, there are so. many. damn. kids... and they're all seemingly out of control. They run around screaming/stepping on things and do whatever the hell they want. This is probably why PG forces everyone to use Grigris instead of ATCs while climbing (which is a HUGE eye roll/pain in the ass), because of all the clueless, idiotic kids running around. I'm afraid for what the next generation will look like if this sample is any representation of how they're all being raised. But perhaps that's a reflection of this part of the Bay Area itself rather than the gym...To add a few of the good parts, they do have much more climbing space than was at GWPC, and it is significantly bigger. They also have many more yoga and workout classes, which is a plus (though I've yet to attend one). The locker room is also larger and has a sauna, and there's plenty of parking as well. My favorite bonus was that they let you split your membership with your "partner" if you're living together but not married, which was fantastic. If you lead climb, you can also test on any climb in the gym as opposed to one designated area.So all in all, it's a good, solid gym. But for the human interactions and "bang for your buck" in comparison to anything Touchstone Climbing offers, I gave it three stars. They need to make some changes and up their game a bit. That, or perhaps I should just lower my standards.

One of my friends started rock climbing regularly a few months ago and I've joined him a couple of times here. It's always a great experience here, minus the slightly pricey entrance fee (which isn't too bad if you have a membership). But since I don't come here enough to make a membership worth it, I go for the $30 one-day fee every time. $24 is the day rate, and you can get a harness and shoe rental for another $6. Even when it's crowded here, you can always find space to climb. It's a gigantic gym with so many different walls and a variety of difficulty levels. If you want to climb the taller walls you do need someone who has a belaying permit/card thing to belay you. I know they offer lessons/training for those who want to learn. I've heard that passing the test is pretty easy. And it opens up so many more climbing options! The people here are also super awesome. Everyone is very respectful/mindful of those climbing around them, so I really like the environment here. Climbing is more of a workout than you would think--and it's not just arms! But for those of you who don't want to climb for too long, you can also take advantage of their gym equipment in the back. I think they also have yoga classes? Overall, it's a great facility and I'll definitely come back again every now and then to climb :)

One of my buddies is a member here so he invited me to climb one day. I had fun the first day and so he signed me and my fiancé up for a baley class. The following weekend we had Reinhard as our baley instructor. He was super awesome! After our lesson we were able to climb on our own, even up up to 5.6 and 5.7. We bought the 5 day passes for $55. We came back this past weekend to climb again. We had to take the test for a temporary card, and we couldn't remember what to do. Thank goodness they didn't give us a permanent card because it's good to refresh our memories. Safety is the number one thing here! Luckily one of the girls was nice enough to go over it with us! We have 4 more passes to use before October so we are looking forward to getting some climbs in before they expire. It's such a good work out! It's a fun sport that we can do and try together. Since neither of us have done this before it's kinda cool that we can start on the same level and grow together. It's also good for relationship or team building because learning to baley and climb is built upon trust! You have to trust each other, be able to communicate effectively and safely, and help each other make it to the top! You also have to encourage and help one another if you see him/her struggling. It's a perfect sport for couples and would be fun for dates. If you're single, there's always someone looking for a partner. It's connected with the Crossfit Sunnyvale so I'm sure you would meet lots of people working out here!

Been going here for over a year now and PG is the best gym I have been to. So many climbing walls for beginners and experts alike. The weightlifting area is decently spaced and has plenty of pull up bars. The weightlifting equipment is great for power lifters, well taken care of, and plentiful. Don't worry about not being able to find free weights to work with, there are tons of them! Only complaint is that during rush hours there is a weightlifting class which takes up almost all the free space in the area, be sure to check out the schedule if you want to work out there.

Not really a climbing community | great climbing facility$$ - $$$If you're looking for a challenging gym with a tight-knit community, this is not for you. If you're looking to climb casually to meet other singles, this is probably for you.I've been climbing for 7 years and have climbed at several gyms around the country and internationally. If you've ever been to one of Planet Granite's gym locations, it's no surprise to expect a big hub of people to meet other people after work (and/or school). It's big and they offer a lot. It's a franchise. At this particular location, it draws a bunch of well-paid engineer guys (duh, silicon valley) and 20 to 30 something aged women. I've stopped by a handful of times and enjoyed climbing here but realizing that I'm climbing above my normal grade than at my home gym (Santa Rosa's Vertex Climbing Gym). An example is I'm usually working V4's and V5's solidly and I came into this gym flashing V4's / V5's and working on a V8. Community? I don't see it. I think if you're 'really good' you'll end up striking a conversation with the crowd that looks like they're 'dirt bag climbers', but every time I step in there, every person looks less than welcoming. I walked past a person or persons that I smiled at because I'm just a friendly person and they avoid eye contact, giving you the impression that they're a complete snob. Huge gym. I don't feel cramped the times I went since there's a lot of accommodating open space (indoors and outdoors). Lots of rope routes and an indoor and outdoor bouldering spot. Despite the open doors and fans, it's still REALLY hot. Excellent gym work out area, too. Bathrooms are clean and spacious, which is similar to the other gym locations by them.Couldn't believe we paid $48 total for day fees for the two of us. (Vertex's adult day use fee is $16) Well, if they have the nice facility, you know where your money is going to.

This is a review for yoga and fitness only. They no longer have Crossfit so my boyfriend cancelled his membership. I still come for cardio and yoga. Pros:very close to where I workFive stars for yoga instructors Lorraine, Joanie and Nick who lead great classes that leave you feeling strong and centered! sauna in the locker roomsbig parking lot, easier to find parking than Belmont or SFCons: They recently raised prices again. Why is Sunnyvale is more expensive than the other PG locations? Cleanliness needs work. Since they are charging more they should at least clean the place consistently. I come to yoga several times a week and the mirrors and floors are usually dirty. Men work out barefoot in the weights area so the place can reek of stinky feet. Other gyms like the Y and 24 hour fitness require footwear, wish PG would do this too.

I had a really positive experience here and I would recommend it to anyone. You definitely have to be ready to step out of your comfort zone. At first I was terrified and intimidated. The staff greeted me and was very friendly. Signing the waiver form was pretty simple and self explanatory. They emailed me a copy right away which was great. The video they showed was very informative and helpful to give me an idea of what to expect. There are many different rocks to climb and many different levels to offer. I went with friends that were more experienced than I was which was a major plus. Having rock climbing shoes and the right equipment was very helpful too. There is plenty of staff to help and assist which was also nice. There is a gym with machines and weights to offer. This place also offers different classes, including yoga. I was able to choice a vinyasa flow yoga class. It was fun and relaxing but also challenging. I can seem myself coming back and referring other people!

Fantastic experience for my daughter's 10th birthday party. The staff were fantastic, the two coaches that were assigned to us - Nicole and Daniel - were super attentive to the kids, and the venue was awesome. Couldn't have been a better, more positive event. Will go back for camps and other activities!

It's a new year and I need to try a new sport, so why  not rock climbing! My friend has a membership here so I was able to use his guest pass. I did pay $4 for the shoes though. Shoes are not mandatory but definitely recommended. The place was kinda packed at 11 am on a Sunday morning. The belay classes were already full, so we headed over to the bouldering wall. There's 3 bouldering structures I think. Plenty of belaying too. The place is very well maintained and the staff was friendly. They also have a small gym in there, mainly for compound exercises with quite a few barbells. Parking can get a bit tricky depending on the time of the day.

I was really looking forward to going to Planet Granite today because I had been here before and had a great climbing experience. There are so many different problems which are super fun and challenging. However, my experience today was not acceptable. Elaine, the front desk worker, was super rude and disrespectful to me and my family. When I came to the front desk, I could already tell she was going to give me a hard time. She lacked patience and gave us a lot of attitude. When we asked for a harness, she said we could only use one if we knew how to belay. My sister told her that I could belay, and she goes "Oh well she needs to be belay certified here and we don't really feel like giving the class now." I don't care if you don't feel like it, it's literally your job to do so. Even though I was already belay certified there, the fact that she said that was just so shocking and rude. She has a condescending attitude and really needs to quit it. I don't care what time of day it is or if your shift is about to end. I have been to many climbing gyms and have never met such unprofessional and rude staff. Climbing staff are usually upbeat and happy, she was just the opposite. I would give this place a 4/5, but I'm gonna drop it down to 1/5 because of Elaine.
Nice alternative for my regular workout routines.   Fun outing with a friend to try.  Definitely a work out that you feel afterwards

I love this gym. Only wish they had one in SoCal where I live! Bummed the Culver City location didn't work out, but hoping they find a place near where I live in Long Beach! *hint hint*I first came here using a Groupon for a week trial, including belay lesson with my brother. We called and made an appointment for a belay lesson the next day. Our instructor was super nice and made it really easy to learn and remember tying the knots. He had a great metaphor with choking & poking the alien eye.I'm pretty scared of heights so I honestly wasn't looking forward to actually getting up there climbing and top roping. However, I did get better at it and I felt pretty safe up there. There's plenty of top rope and bouldering routes (the gym is huge). Everyone, including staff members are really friendly and kind. Plus, they have Crossfit and yoga classes! If I lived in the area, I would totally get a membership! Way better prices than any other Crossfit gyms.Wish they gave their members more frequent guest passes!

Wow what a great place, I went here with my daughters and watched them climb.  One does a lot of rock climbing around Bishop and Mammath and I'm sure elsewhere, and it was the first climb for my other daughter.  I chickened out, I never get higher than I am tall, about three feet.The staff was great, I was impressed with how safety conscious and professional everyone was.  They treated everyone well, especially the novices!  Which is probably why they are so popular.I think I saw a sign for Yoga, maybe I'll try that next time.  At least I'll be on the ground, for the most part.

A long overdue review for Planet Granite...I love this place.  It has just about everything I could ask for in exercise equipment (except a swimming pool).  Every time I enter, I feel like a kid in a candy factory.  There are plenty of cycling machines, free weights, and equipment for gymnastics/chin ups/dips.There are plenty of walls for climbing (100+ ropes to choose) and bouldering with varying levels of difficulty. On weekends, the walls can get crowded.  So, it pays to call in advance to make sure there aren't party events.  The staff are very friendly and extremely helpful.

This is my rock/fitness gym of which I am a member. Can't go wrong here. Great staff, atmosphere, and amenities. Yoga is great, bouldering is my favorite, and the gym itself has everything you need.Despite the crowds, this place is great!

PG is a 2in1 package that gives people access to their enormous rock climbing walls and it's gym. Yes, it's a bit more expensive than your typical gym but it's worth it if you really enjoy rock climbing or if you want to add some flavor to your fitness routine! I enjoy having both features because I can get my cardio on the elliptical and work my muscles on the walls!Beware! At around 7-9pm on weekdays, the rock climbing/bouldering walls get overcrowded. Also, the cardio equipment is pretty old. I'm being a little picky but I wish there was wifi here!

Wow! I had a great experience climbing at Planet Granite while visiting San Jose. Disclaimer: this is only for bouldering. I didn't bring my shoes, but no worries, the rental shoes were much better than average. They're definitely used, but not the ice skates I'm used to when I have to rent climbing shoes.Plenty of routes for bouldering, nothing to complain about the setting or wall. What sets this place apart is that half of Planet Granite's bouldering is in an age 14+ section. This really helps to limit the danger and up the experience when bouldering. All in all a great gym to visit. Nice facilities for a decent price. Oh and they do student discounts in the morning so don't forget your ID.

Came here for the first time last Sunday with my bestie and had a blast!!! Our instructor was so fun and helpful. My group was all smiles and giggles thanks to David! A+ for dealing with us crazies.Pro's:- lots of walls to climb in all levels- ventilation is good, they keep all the doors open- workers are all nice and helpful- bathrooms are huge with lots of room and kept very clean- prices are fair for non-members at $26 a day (w/ harness and shoes)- no meatheads working out.Con's:- it's a teeny bit smelly up in this joint...Overall it was an excellent first experience.10/10 would come again!

There's a reason why day passes & membership is the most expensive here vs. SF and Belmont. I loved being a PG member and feel that the quality of the 3 PG gyms is higher than other climbing gyms in the Bay Area (ie. Mission Cliffs, Iron Works) in that the routes are regularly swapped and the grips on the rocks are not worn down from overuse or dirtiness. Staff has always been friendly, helpful and efficient. One of my friends dislocated his elbow once (very poor landing from bouldering) and the staff reacted very quickly and knowledgeably.Benefits of Sunnyvale: best parking of the three gyms (SF has a metered parking lot and Belmont is free street parking). It's a larger gym with tons of bouldering options. Good amount of regular gym equipment. Comparatively, SF is sort of hard to get to without a car, and the cherry on top is you have metered parking when you finally get there. Belmont is nice, but smaller.Cons: working out in the general gym area (ex. ellipticals, treadmills) is very stuffy and air circulation is not good at all. Even if you had the simplest workout of your life, I am certain you will end up sweating just from the heat.Notes: It gets REALLY crowded, at the predictable times (weekdays after work). Weekends is a ghost town at opening hours which is when I would recommend coming. Weekend late afternoons also die down a little and you have to find the sweet spot that avoids the children's rock climbing parties. Unfortunately, a membership doesn't make economic sense unless you come more often than just the weekends, so you are going to have to suck it up and brave the crowds at some point.The most annoying thing about PG is their membership offerings and that you must either fully cancel or else pay to have your membership frozen when you are away.

How did it take me 2 years to finally sign up for this place.  In summary:1) Rock climbing: This place is rock climbing mecca - I'm new to it, but it's a pretty non-intimidating environment to climb.  I'd recommend you come with a friend, but they also help you find someone to climb with if you are going solo.2) Yoga: they have free classes here if you are a member - so great!3) Crossfit: again, free classes if you are a member.  This is SUCH an awesome deal.  Any other crossfit gym is SUPER expensive, and here you get a 3 in 1 sort of deal (that is, if you like all of the above sports..)

There aren't that many rock gyms in the South Bay, and I believe this is the biggest one. It has a ton of bouldering and 2-3 story top-rope areas. It's certainly the most popular rock gym. On weekday nights, it's way too crowded. Around 80% of the top ropes are in use at any given time. It gets a bit smelly, and the staff isn't all that helpful. Sign-in always takes several minutes if you don't have a membership.Pros:- It's the biggest rock gym. There are a ton of routes of all difficulties- You probably already have some friends or coworkers who come here regularly- There are climbing classes you can take- They change up their routes a couple of times each month- The walls well-maintainedCons:- It's the most popular rock gym. The place is completely crowded on weekday nights. Weekends are much better- The staff are slow at getting things done- Day passes are expensive- It gets smelly in the restrooms

I love this place.The staff is extremely friendly, the climbing here is challenging for newbies, and even veterans of this sport. I've found that the general consensus here is that it's an extremely welcoming place with loads of friendly people and folks who are just masters of their craft.I went here to book a belaying lesson for my girlfriend and I. We decided on the spot to go ahead and give bouldering a try as well! Everyone was friendly, and everyone kept offering us tips on how to improve our climbing!Now on to the belaying lesson. It felt a BIT rushed, but it was a very effective class. My girlfriend and I were able to learn a lot, and we really enjoyed the entire session with our instructor. We never felt endangered, we always felt safe and taken care of.Despite all this, it's still really expensive to climb here, but I can gladly say it's well worth it!

My life and love! I am pretty much miserable if I spend more than a few days away from PG and will be longing to climb something; anything! I've always loved climbing everything I could get my hands on since I was a child and when I encountered my first wall at the age of 15, it was love at first sight.I spend majority of my time bouldering around here. It's a decent sized gym with lots of options for all levels. Both the staff and the patrons here are super nice and not a single creeper in sight (Unlike a gym such as 24 HR Fitness...). If you're ever stuck on a problem, you can always count on a nice friendly stranger to help you out or offer some pointers or tips. Don't have a belay partner? Go to the front desk and they will help find you someone to pair up with. How can you not love this community?!? Did I mention that everyone here is like your cheerleading squad? Just walking through the gym, you will hear tons of praises and words of encouragement as they try to pep up someone to power through whatever they're struggling on.I also take some of the fitness classes here with Zeus. I've been taking his Abs + Core class for about 2 months now and somehow managed to drop 13 lbs. It's a challenging class to me and you WILL be sore the first time you take it, but I promise it gets better by the 2nd or 3rd class. He also teaches at Total Body Fitness class which completely kicked my butt, yet I'm eager to return to the next one to see how much better I can do next round. I haven't tried out any yoga or spin classes but I'm told those are great workouts as well. Classes do fill up quickly so it's good to show up 15 minutes before to stake out a spot.I really didn't think it was possible, but I've somehow grew to love PG more and more. It's where I go to feel good, relax, unwind from stress, and submerge myself into a positive community.

I've been a member for about a year now.  I have a few observations.The Good:- excellent fitness classes including crossfit, yoga, cycling, core with flexible schedules- excellent weight lifting amenities (endless barbells, weights ,squat racks etc)- best top route / lead climbing gym in the Bay Area bar none- formidable bouldering problems- excellent instructors for climbing and fitness- great, helpful environment and community for new climbers- many members only perks and social events- walk-ins allowed on a member guest pass or paid day pass- free climbing lessons for friends if you are a memberThe Not So Good:- peak hours are incredibly busy; there are waits for every climb- sometimes they run out of lockers during busy times- parking is horrible; there is no better way to put it; way too many cars and way too small of a lot during peak times- may be a bit of a wait for lifting equipment during busy hoursOverall, my experience here has been incredibly positive.  I've made lots of friends, learned to be a better climber, and have increased my overall fitness and quality of life.  At first, I thought the membership fee was a bit steep compared to somewhere like 24 Hour Fitness or City Sport, but PG really has a much more community feel and the caliber of instruction here is just so much better.

First timers who want a day pass.. I suggest signing up for the Belaying class if you want to climb the walls! I didn't know this, showed up, and couldn't participate because the classes were full.I called prior and wish that someone told me that information.

My buddy Harold aka James L told me "Yo Kumar check this spot out yo, this place is like bad medicine, bad medicine is what you need, not those dumb white caste burgers you keep eating"...so i obliged and said hey why not i'm always up for exercising cuz the ladies like it when you stay fit and active.  This place was pretty dope, and I'm not talking about the scratch n sniff kind of dope you filthy mc-nasty!!!Breakdown:- Private Parking Lot (plenty of space to park, even for a busy friday night)- Pricing ($20 for normal climbing and $40 for the big walls which you have to take a class for, they also give you the rock climbing shoes)- Rocks (Really nice rock courses from flat rocks to rocks shaped like boulders which are really hard to climb, they also have levels that you can try to conquer from V0-V4 where each rock is colored and you must follow that path)- Gym Area (they have a real nice gym area, almost every gym exercise machine and free weights you want to do you can find here)- Bathrooms (they have towels and a huge bathroom so you can wash up or even shower with a locker room, make sure you bring your own lock)So I can't wait to come back to this place, I'm pretty athletic but I have to say this place really tested me as I could not conquer all the levels on the rocks that and the ladies wouldn't stop checking out my badonkadonk as i climbed my way to the top but that's not here or there....rock climbing in general is something you should really try, i had muscles hurting the next day that i usually never work out, definitely coming back here again!!!

Expensive, expensive, expensive.Planet Granite is a fully functioning climbing/fitness gym with a variety of amenities attached to your monthly/daily membership. Aside from bouldering and belay climbing, you get yoga, fitness, functional fitness, personal trainers, as well as access to their gym area lumped into your membership.And here is where I find fault in their pricing model. I am an avid boulderer, so I come here for bouldering/belay climbing, not yoga, not a weight gym. And for me to pay $24 for a day pass or $69 for a monthly membership, I feel ripped off. And their student day pass of $18 is only valid Mondays-Fridays before 5pm?? AIN'T NOBODY GOT TIME FOR DAT. Ideally, they would divvy up their accesses so people who only want to boulder could pay a lower fee instead of offering a one-size fits all deal. Because those one-size fits are usually the worst. In Seattle, I would pay $12/day for a student day pass, but that's another story.Aside from that, the routes are well-maintained, and even some of the V1's-V2's make me sweat. The routes here seem a bit more challenging per level than they seemed to be in Seattle Bouldering Project. Some routes here feel inconsistent; some V1's feel easier than V2's, and some V2's feel easier than V3's. There is even an age-restricted area that offers much more difficult routes with challenging overhanging routes for experienced climbers. The gym is huge, and good for it because this place gets busy during weekday nights! For members, they offer a free informative belay lesson where any day after, you can get "certified" if you pass a belay test, thus granting you access to the roped rock climbing area. Their belay system is centered in a device called the Grigri. They give announcements to the entire gym if there's a solo climber looking for a belay partner. The rock climbing walls tend to test your endurance more. On the bouldering walls, the difficulty is more sustained and concentrated and the bouldering problems are always interesting. The staff is friendly, but often slow and forgetful when it gets busy. Great gym overall, terrible pricing model.Strong 3 to a Light 4

Oh my, where do I sign?!??!This place is magnificent fun for the adventuresome!  Rock climbing, gym, Crossfit...it's all here under one roof for most to enjoy. Even children can partake in the rock climbing fun.There are classes available to perfect that rock climbing game of yours too.  Shoot, I'd love a man who can get to the top faster than I can say....Ahem. Anyway, there's lots of parking. Probably not enough if you're trying to get your sweat on during weekday after-work hours.  Like a true fitness establishment, there are snacks, refreshments, gear sold here in case you happen to forget something essential - so don't you worry your pretty little head. Staff is friendly and really willing to help. They easily explain how they operate and share what is necessary for participating which makes you feel a little more comfortable especially when you're a newb. So stop reading this now and head on over......see you at the top!

Holy crap... This place is amazing. Today was only my first time and I fell in love!Two of friends have membership here so they were able to hook me up with a free belay lesson. Evan was my instructor and he was pretty cute ;) In about an hour, he taught me and two other beginners how to attach the belay device, how to do a safety check for the belayer and on other climbers, how to tie the necessary knots, how to demonstrate correct communication, and how to demonstrate correct belay technique. Before today, I've only done rock climbing at city beach with the automatic belay systems which was so much easier compared to this. Afterwards, I rock climbed for about 1.5 hours. There are a variety of difficulty levels. I started with a 5.6 and was able to do a 5.9 too! After a belay lesson, they offer a deal: 5 all day passes for just $55 (not including rental gear). I had to buy it!!! The deal is only valid if you purchase it the day of your lesson. What I also loved about this place was that they had a whole gym set up inside. If I had the money, this would definitely be my choice of gym. Maybe someday :)TIP: "Pulling harder is not always the answer". Really use your legs and balancing skills to get you up there or else your arms will be dead!Can't wait to invite all my friends to try this place out!
Yo my fucking boy nick at the front desk he a straight g if u ever hit that mo fo up, never disrespect him.

So many hipsters unite. I am definitely not hard core and I've prolly gone three times ever. The first time I took a belay lesson but I couldn't remember anything so I opted to not dotage belay lesson and would just climb. I had to get a day pass and then rental equipment. It was super crowded around 7 on Wednesday so just find a rope and squeeze in. Man I was beat even with only 5.8 or something. Weaksauce. But just keep swimming!! Climbing hehe.

I'm so happy to have come here and work with Melissa D. She helped me out as the core class instructor and I also worked with her-- she is also a total body fitness coach. PG is so fun and special. I've never been a rock climber, but my confidence soared as I worked with Melissa. She is friendly, knowledgeable, and keeps safety as priority #1. I would highly recommend coming here to wall climb and to work with some of the best trainers and instructors in the Bay Area :)

I've been climbing here for many years and enjoy the place, but recent events have made me air out some grievances.1) The front desk staff tend to shirk away from helping customers.  At the Belmont and San Francisco locations, the staff is pretty attentive and makes sure you've been helped. At Sunnyvale, they treat me like I'm inconveniencing them and sometimes straight up avoid me.2) The price difference between Sunnyvale and the other gyms makes me feel discriminated.  I don't think your message about higher cost of operations justifies anything.  Employee wages in SF match south bay wages, so why isn't SF set at the same price point? If you're going to raise prices, keep all your gyms priced the same.  Otherwise, you anger a lot of your customers.3) Your staffing schedule needs some work. I come in some nights and see 5 front desk employees just standing around behind the counter doing nothing.  Combined with my previous points, I get angry that I pay a premium for worse service and dead weight.

I normally climb in Raleigh, NC, but purchased a few day passes here while home for the holidays. I like this gym a lot. The staff is all really friendly, especially for a Bay Area joint. The location is really convenient with a huge parking lot, and not in a super high trafficy area like downtown. They have a significant student discount, so I was able to keep in climbing shape while visiting my parents for 3 weeks without burning a hole through the wallet. I only use this gym to boulder. The routes are challenging and there is a good variety of easy ones and difficult ones. I do feel like the walls are slightly over crowded, but that could just be because I am used to the opposite back in Raleigh. I definitely challenged myself here and worked on some different looking routes.The only thing is that it gets super crowded and chaotic. Last time I was here there were four kids running around in circles going crazy right under me while I was trying to focus on climbing. I also think that a tour of the facility (or at least a small mention of "locker rooms are back there", "we have a sauna", etc etc) would be helpful for first timers. I didn't realize there was an entire back bouldering room for ages 14+ until my second visit. Speaking of which, I LOVE the idea of the age restricted bouldering zone, especially with those crazy kids running around the main part. Overall, this is a great community to be part of in in the Bay Area. The other climbers are considerate and may even offer suggestions. They also have a TON of yoga/climbing merch with tons of variety available for purchase.
Great route selections for all levels! Friendly staff! Nice weight and body weight equipment! Additional parking at Lowe's.
Facilities are extensive; staff and atmosphere are exceptionally fun!

I'd say 3.5 stars, but I rounded up because you guys are just too awesome. ^_^ I love all the positive vibes, camaraderie, and supportive environment. Come in here with a good attitude, and that will be reciprocated.Enough of these reviews say what Planet Granite has; including decently high walls, various classes, cardio and strength equipment, an oft-ignored sauna, events, BBQs, all that stuff. Let's talk about what's missing:- No features wall.- No traverse route. Hard to free climb a traverse with the amount of people as well.- No auto-belay system.- And no "buddy program" for top-roping. If you come alone but want to top-rope, they will just make an announcement over the speaker. If you're female, you'll be good to go. If you're a dude, you're SOL. Such is life.- No beginner bouldering routes (VB), so it's hard to introduce first-timers to it. You have to go straight to top-roping which has a lot of kiddie routes.- Only whole number ratings for bouldering. I prefer the more specific + and - system, which gives you a good idea of what you're getting in to.- Bouldering routes are taped, but not nearly as organized and easy to read as the top-roping here. And putting a red taped route next to an orange taped route is all sorts of confusing.Biggest qualm: Don't come here after 3 pm / before 8 pm. There are kids running around unsupervised, crawling on routes with bare feet or sneakers, touching other people's stuff, and just generally being obnoxious. More adult supervision needed in this regard.Membership: $75 a month. Access to all Planet Granite locations. One guest pass every other month. Guest night on the first Friday of every month. Free belay class for up to two friends anytime with advance appointment. (Great way to introduce them to climbing). Access to all classes. Small discounts to save you a few quarters. ***Downside is that you can only charge your membership to a checking account.Safety: PG appears to be very strict in enforcing appropriate belay technique, which I applaud. Safety first :) However, I have seen LOTS of people belaying who were NOT resting in the brake position and no staff ever appeared to have a problem with this. I understand that PG uses only gri-gri's, so it's not too much of a problem in-gym. But as someone who had a pretty bad belay experience with an ATC, when you get used to resting outside of the brake position, you are developing a bad habit that could definitely come back to bite you in the future.
The membership is expensive, and it's insanely busy on weeknights, but this is the best gym, and one of my favorite places in the south bay.

Yeah sure, it gets crowded during peak times, but that's like most gyms. So what if you have to wait for a rope for your next climb? You're bound to be waiting amongst positive people that are staring down their next challenge (5.10c anyone?).
