That's the kind of culture you can expect here; everyone is nice and challenging themselves.Speaking of nice people, the staff here is great, too. And you can tell it's not a front or let-me-be-nice-until-my-shift-ends. The staff are really there to help you out if you need anything. So if you're the type to have lots of questions and tend to start off with "this may be a stupid question, but...", leave off that part and ask away!Planet Granite also offers cross fit, cycling, abs & core, and yoga classes. I got a chance to try out cycling with Max and yoga with Melody. Cycling with Max was interesting in that I never had an instructor that closed his eyes for most of the course. Power yoga with Melody was amazing and left me feeling refreshed -- I highly recommend! Now as for membership costs... it's quite steep. It's very much understandable why, though... because any cheaper, we wouldn't be able to waddle through during peak times haha. You are paying for value! If you can afford it, by all means give it a try. If you are considering the full year membership, I would give Planet Granite a monthly membership trial unless you could dedicate 4 days out of the week with a one-week membership. With all that said, climb on! And... namaste (seriously, power yoga with Melody is worth every one of those 90 minutes!).

PG has really made me enjoy working out. They have a lot of walls for climbing (both bouldering and top-roping), as well as crossfit and gym equipment. The climbing routes are well-maintained and changed fairly regularly, so there's always something new to work on! The membership also includes free fitness and yoga courses, which is nice. The locker rooms are kept very clean and provide showers and a sauna for post-workout relaxation. If you're just looking to try out the gym, they do offer day passes and rental climbing equipment. It can get pretty packed on weekdays after work hours, but thankfully the parking lot is huge. You may have to wait a bit on certain climbing routes or fitness equipment, but it generally isn't too bad. Overall, great gym and would recommend climbing to anyone looking for a fun, new hobby. (That also helps you be more fit!)

My friends and I came here a couple times now, and we definitely love Planet Granite. The place itself is very big, and it's a great place to come for fun and for a good workout. The place itself can get crowded, but we didn't have a problem finding a place to climb or boulder at. I love that they not only have areas to climb and to boulder, but they also have a full gym with weights and other machines. They also have yoga classes and cross fit classes that had me interested. They have monthly and annual passes with student discounts and other plans, so definitely worth checking out. We took the belaying class with Kevin. He is an awesome instructor and definitely encouraged me to not back out (didn't realize I was slightly afraid of heights until I got up there). He showed us tricks to remember for all the important things to know as a climber and a belayer. We all passed our belay text the week after, so I definitely recommend taking the class with him! (4 for 4 Kevin!)Overall, most of the staff was very welcoming, helpful, and professional. Customer service is key for me, and Kevin and the other employee that tested us the week after were great. My only con was from one of the front desk employee, Evan, that checked us in. I don't think it's necessary to be rude to your customers, no matter how busy you are. Also, giving me the wrong shoe size and telling me that one full shoe size won't make a difference didn't seem necessary as well. Other than that experience, Planet Granite definitely topped my expectations.What was supposed to be a place to just "try out" turned out to be the place we will definitely be regulars at.

I started climbing a few months ago, and I've been steadily improving. This place is amazing, lots of climbs on all sorts of levels. I never get bored, they are constantly changing the routes. Their bordering section is great. I tried both SF and Belmont and this is by far the best.

Your chalk balls are huge, mind if I dip my fingers in them?My significant other has a membership here so he was able to get me a free belay lesson. Daniel at the register was very friendly and pleasant to talk to - I signed my waiver and went to go change into my work out clothes. Ford was my instructor and he was very friendly and thorough with the lesson - taught me and five other beginners how to attach the belay device, how to do a safety check for the belayer and the climbers how to tie the necessary knots (there's two kinds you have to do), how to demonstrate correct communication between belayer & climber, and how to demonstrate correct belay technique. After our lesson, we were given a day pass to practice our belaying and do some climbing.. the next time we come back would be a belay test so you can get your official belay card. Test was straight-forward and of course I passed it. I only bought the 5-pack after the lesson for $60 to see if I'm going to like Rock Climbing and if I'm going to commit to the monthly. The deal is only valid if you purchase it the day of your lesson. I'm afraid of heights so I wanted to climb easy ones to gain climbing confidence little by little. I was only doing 5.fun (super noob status) and now I can do 5.7, heading towards 5.8. I'd belay you all night long.SHIYETTTTTTT, I'm in love.

First the pro: Based on my limited experience, PG seems to have a good selection of climbing routes. Now the cons - these by far outweigh the positive: This place stinks! Go on a hot day and everything will smell like feet. Their rental shoes will very likely give you foot fungus. The facility looks like it's in dire need of some deep cleaning.  Everything is old and/or dirty - it's sometimes hard to tell.  The shower fixtures are rusty in lots of areas and the drains looked clogged every time I was there.  Don't go into the showers without wearing slippers, as your feet will be soaking in other people's shower water while you're taking a shower.  The lockers have probably never been wiped down, ever.Prices are ridiculously steep for what you get. PG is obviously milking the fact that climbing has become such a popular pastime and there aren't really any other noteworthy facilities in the South Bay. I don't blame them but wished someone else would open up a new place in the area soon, as PG's customer service could clearly benefit from some healthy competition. Lastly, beware of the boy instructor with the Napoleon complex.  If you had an instructor who was impersonal,   condescending and accusatory, then that's probably him. Clearly, this guy needs to take a customer service 101 class.  Or maybe he owns the place, and he doesn't care about your business.

This was awesome! The walls are super high!!! and they have varying levels of difficulties (from 5.6 to 5.11) so noobs and pros alike can enjoy themselves. Belaying test - FREE You pass the test if you intend to belay a friend. They give them out in colors of white and red. White = approved for belaying for just that dayRed =  approved for belaying forever? I think. *Belaying classes are also provided at $28. I think it's a 1 hour session? But it's really not rocket science. I think it's one of those things you can just pick up from a friend. ***Note: They are super strict about no peer-to-peer teaching at their center so do it discretely if you must. Otherwise, coach at home? Learn to tie 1) figure of 8, 2) check harness, 3) belay commands and you are set to go more or less. Price - $26The day pass costs $20 + additional $6 for rental of shoe and harness. I would strongly recommend going in pairs. Preferably if both people can belay otherwise it won't be much fun for one person.

The BEST climbing gym!  WE absolutely love climbing here!  There are so many climbing routes, bouldering walls and exercise equipment.  Truly, this gym has it all!  We are true climbers from Lake Tahoe and must say, that next to climbing outside on the Sierra Granite, Planet Granite will do!  :)

This is a perfect spot for a first date.I've been here once, but I have been wanting to go back. I'm thinking about taking a belay lesson with a few people some day.  If you want to boulder and rock climb, I would suggest rock climbing first. Bouldering takes a lot of energy and you might be too exhausted to rock climb after. Anyhow, make sure to use chalk for your sweaty hands when you climb so you don't slip. You'll body will probably be sore the next day so be prepared.

Lots of walls with many different levels. I've been to a few gyms, both here and in Canada, and Planet Granite is a great one, I'd give an 80% if the best one I've been to was 100%. What it lacks:- Routes are a bit crowded, so sometimes you'd be on a pink route and it'd be intermixed with a red one and cause some confusion- Some holds are old and faded, causing similar colours to look even more alike- Lots of people during weekdays- There aren't many V1 and V2 in the caves, it's either V0 or impossibly difficult ones- The gym area should have a belt with a chain (for doing weighted pull ups and dips)- Day passes/10-passes are a bit pricy ... In Canada the going rate is ~$17/day or $140 for 10 visits, here it's $24/day or $210 for 10Some of these are very specific, but overall it's a great gym with lot of options and people are generally very friendly and easy to talk to.

I've been here a few times before, mainly for bouldering. My friend got me introductory rock climbing classes for my birthday, and it was a nice experience. The instruction was really good (Amy was our instructor) and I had a nice time. One big perk is that you get your belay certification out of the way, so you're ready to climb when the classes are completed.The facilities are top notch, there are plenty of people to buddy up with, and it's large enough to handle the throngs of people that frequent this very popular fitness subculture. (I was shocked to discover how popular this is!)There is also a nice gym facility, and yoga classes are available.Overall, this is an excellent one stop shop for many different avenues of fitness, but I feel as though climbing is first and foremost in the heart of the building.

This place is amazing!!! I've been going to mostly rock climbing gyms in southern california which are only 1/4 the size of planet granite. This place is HUGE!!! About 4x the size of climbing gyms i am used to.  There are tons of top ropes, lead climbs, and bouldering routes. The walls are very tall, which builds great stamina. Its great that not all the walls are 50-60 feet tall which is great for beginners and people who tire out. Honestly, i only had about a couple big wall climbs in me. Routes are really well thought out and have a lot of creativity in them. The variety in the top roping walls in amazing! I couldnt climb all the routes in a day if i tried. I have to say the ratings on the wall are a bit easier than i am used to, a 5.10a at a climbing gym in socal is somewhat difficult, but here I felt like the 5.10s were equivalent to some 5.8s at other gyms.. or maybe i'm getting stronger?The bouldering area is a really good place to bring beginner friends. The routes are challenging, yet very doable. I love that the floors are made of up really soft mats across the entire bouldering area, which makes it feel extra safe. The area is plenty big so it doesnt get too crowded.The gym area is an actual gym, tons of treadmills and weights. I can totally see this doubling as a climbing gym/regular gym. Everything was clean and there didnt seem to be a huge wait for any of the machines. The shower/locker room area is really big, and clean, there were showers and a sauna!Overall the facility is great, i only give it four stars as the staff was rather off putting. When i came in, there was only one person in line, and i had to wait about 20 minutes as the three people behind the desk, seemed to be pre-occupied. When i did finally get serviced the staff was rather rude when requesting that i take a belay test, they told me to tie in, and then wave them over, easier said than done, they were ignoring me. During the belay test, they seemed to come in doubting my belay abilities (i've climbed consistently at other gyms i know how to belay). Rude staff aside, i had a great time at the facility and i would definitely come back again when i am in the Bay Area
Fun place, but need to reserve far in advance for the belay classes. $1 for chalk (which is usually included at other spots). But all in all, fun place.

Planet Granite is not your typical gym. There's so many different ways to be active here and the people here are really nice! Climbing, yoga, crossfit, pilates, spin classes, and more!My bf is a member here and I always try to come on their free guest days (every first Friday of the month). Members also get a free guest pass every odd month so I try to use that pass whenever he gets one :DThe majority of Planet Granite is the rock climbing area. There's bouldering walls and top roping. They change up the routes on the walls every once in awhile so you won't be doing the same thing every time you're here. Other members here are really friendlly which makes it seem more like a community. Every time I've come here, a stranger has helped me when I'm stuck on the wall by guiding me to the end of the route! Thanks to a random guy we met twice, I completed my first V2 after only climbing like.. 5 times :D I LOVE the yoga classes here! I've only taken the Power Yoga and Partner Yoga classes with Doris and both are great! She is super nice and charismatic and will help you with your form. Her power class is pretty challenging at times and will push you to new limits. The partner yoga class is super fun! I highly recommend it if you have a significant other :) It is a great idea for a date! You also don't need to come to the class with a partner. Sometimes people find partners there in class! Usually when I come here, there's people outside the yoga class practicing AcroYoga which looks SO COOL. A friend of mine has learned some moves just by asking these people to teach him! Maybe one day I will too :DThere's also a weights and cardio machines area. So if you want to just lift weights, use the elliptical or treadmill, those options are there too! And since most people are usually there for climbing, this area is not very crowded which means you don't have to wait to use anything.If I lived closer to PG I would totally get a membership. You get SO MUCH from it! Getting a membership at a yoga studio or crossfit gym cost much more than a membership at PG and at PG, you get BOTH and more! If you're interested in climbing at all or any of the other activities PG offers, definitely try it out for a day by getting a guest pass or going on the first Friday with a member! :)
Nice employees. Nice climbing. Nice gym. Nice sauna. Nice yoga. Nice classes. Nice clientele. At the risk of making his place more popular, it is definitely a 5 star facility.

The best year-end camp for my kids!Kudos to Nicole, the camp instructor, who made a wonderful memory that not only do my kids learn to love rock climbing, but they will remember this spectacular week for the rest of their lives. One little detail about Nicole I noticed is that she can quickly tell apart my identical twins on the first day.Regarding to the gym, it has different levels of challenges kids can try. Guests and staffs were kids friendly during the camp hours (not sure about other periods.) Facilities seem to be clean as well. My kids were very comfortable spending their entire afternoon there for the whole week.Lastly my kids have tears in their eyes whenever they think of the camp, starting the day before the camp ends, and even the days after. They will be back there soon.

My first time trying out rock-climbing. I'm not a pro, but it was easier than I expected. Then again, I stuck mostly to the 5.5-5.7 walls and climbed up any way I wanted instead of following a strict color so that probably eased the difficulty.It is definitely more fun to come with a friend or groups of friends since you get tired pretty fast from climbing and it'll be good to take breaks and let others have a go.There seems to be a gym area with cardio equipments, but I didnt check out the area. The day pass costs $20 + additional $6 for rental of shoe and harness. I felt that it was a little expensive, considering that a monthly membership is only $55. I'd probably consider coming back again if I have friends who want to do regular visits so we can get the monthly membership instead of the day pass.

Your eyes will immediately light up as you walk into this gym. PG has climbs for everyone. From first timers to seasoned vets. There are bouldering walls all throughout the gym with enough variety and problems for you to never get bored. I haven't top roped much but there are alot of top roping routes as well as lead climbing.  Climbing is not enough for you?? There is a gym section with weights so you can lift to your hearts content. But PG is not without its flaws. Mondays-Thursdays this place gets packed. And they recently bumped up the prices for the Sunnyvale location. If you're planning on making climbing a hobby, this is the best place in the area by far. Climb on!

Not going to lie, my first time here I was coming to take a workout class and got a bit of a grimy vibe. But a few minutes after talking to the staff and watching the hilarious required video and I was already loving it.If you climb, this place is clearly the tits. And if you go to Nicole's total body workout, like I did, you will be sore as hell the next day and more than a little impressed by the bad bitches next to you in class. I swear I got more help on my posturing and form here than I have at any of the $25 yoga/ spinning/ weight classes I've taken in Palo Alto.Something about this place has a good energy, and I'd recommend finding a friend who can quite literally show you the ropes. $12 entry isn't that bad, and there's all kind of amazing lovable freaks to watch if you just want to use the treadmills or weights.

Came here a week or so ago, I was recommended to come check this place out and I definitely will be coming back. My friend and I were hoping to get a belay lesson, but when we walked in they told us that they were booked. But the lovely lady at the front desk, I believe her name was Jess, or Jessica (don't quite remember) told us she would be off in a few minutes and would be willing to give us a belay lesson once she was off! We were not expecting that at all. Throughout our time with her she was nothing but patient and taught us so much, she made me feel so welcome and I just absolutely loved her teaching style, she was very clear and didn't hesitate to go over things again if we didn't quite understand. I have nothing but positive things to say about my experience and I can't wait to come back! Especially thanks to Jess because she completely went out of her way to help and even after she was off, you don't see that often. I look forward to coming back!

MMM I think I would give this place a 3.5 stars just comparing it to my other rock climbing experience, This place was overall more packed, more smelly ( I know its inevitable because it's a workout place) than this other place I've been to in dtsj.However, I think those things didn't really as much since I was mainly there just to have a good time with friends.I paid about $30 for shoe rental and a day pass and unlimited climbing, but I have really dinky arms so how much climbing could I do anyways.They also have a weight area there so since I worked on my arms and paid for a day pass I did my daily squats there too lol.
I wish I have this closer to my home.. Will you open one in near downtown San Jose or near the airport of San Jose in the future please?

Short Story:This place is a playground for Spider-man!Long Story:I've been here several times the past few years and it's been a good experience.  There are lots of people there every day.  The instructors and all knowledgeable and mostly friendly.  Sometimes it gets really crowded and you have to wait your turn to climb the particular course you want.

I've been to a lot of gyms and this is a personal favorite. Of the PGs around the Bay Area it seems like the biggest. However, this means that sometimes, it's the busiest. It can be packed some nights, full of climbers, but there are always lots of routes to choose and the gym does a great job keeping it fresh and changing routes up. The front desk staff are knowledgeable and pretty speedy.  The coaching staff are tough and push you confidently out of your zone. A great place.
Absolutely love Slow Flow Yoga taught by Danae Robinett on Sundays at 9:30AM.   Light hearted and challenging and encouraging yoga appropriate for all levels.   Highly recommended.

-Parking is plenty.-This is an awesome place for Yoga and for taking fitness classes.-Price is very reasonable considering it is Sunnyvale.-The front desk staff is very friendly.-It's been just a week and took few Yoga classes. Have attended three classes of Dorris. She is very good and gives individual attention. I assume other instructors are like that and will attend their classes also.-Attended few F10 basics and fundamentals. It was lovely. Will take up F10 classes.-It doesn't have a full fledged gym like 24hr fitness or F19.

First time in a long time since i had visited the place, and i can guarantee it will be a weekly destination from here on out! I workout and consider myself a very strong guy, but i was quickly shown just how weak i really am! My grip strength and upper body gave out a hell of a lot quicker than i thought, but that only served as fuel to keep trying harder!The smaller free climbing walls are a great challenge for novices and pros alike! I witnessed some amazing athletes pull off hand holds that i thought were impossible, again, just fuel for inspiration. For those of you who want a greater thrill then the 60' walls are perfect for you! You are tethered to a person who is grounded and controls the tension on the rope as you climb your way up mountains made of plywood and jutting hand holds. There are "easy" lines and very difficult ones all engineered to challenge any and all!A great place for a team building exercise or even a first date!

I love climbing, which is important because this gym is very expensive. It's the best gym in the area if you like to top rope as well as boulder, and the gym equipment, yoga, crossfit and other fitness classes further justify the price. The only other options in my area are City Beach and The Studio which are not a good fit to what I want (all the extra recreational amenities unrelated to climbing) and lack of top roping, respectively. They're also similarly priced for memberships, so it really is a matter of deciding what you want to get out of your money. It is currently $85/month, but I go ~3 times/week every week (day passes are $24 without gear rental).PG Sunnyvale is really busy during the weekdays after work. If you don't want to wait between climbs or cannot go off hours or during the weekend, this place is not for you no matter how awesome it is. I love going off hours, but sometimes I like climbing during the crowded hours too--you can get some good beta and the atmosphere is always friendly and encouraging.Routes are rotated in sections every week, so routes will stay up ~2 months. I'm a frequent climber and haven't run into issues with variety. They're pretty good at keeping the mats clean, although they get a little chalky in the evenings (they're cleaned in the morning). I've taken a few yoga classes with different instructors and found them all excellent, but none of the others. Definitely a nice perk of the membership.They host several events you can take advantage of if you're a single climber looking for a partner or just other like-minded people to climb with--Beta Babes, Trivia Night, Singles & Swingers (this one gets really crowded) are the ones I've participated in at one time or another. They host two climbing events a year: Bloc Party (bouldering) and Friction Series (top roping). Loads of fun for amateurs and more advanced climbers, but they do disrupt your routine for about a week as routes are set up and taken down.

I had only been rock climbing twice before my visit here and both times were fun, but it was my visit here that really made me want to get a little serious about it.There is plenty of options for beginners and experts. I did the bouldering, but am going back in a few days to take the belay class. I really liked that they have a bouldering section dedicated to different techniques. They are clearly labeled so you know what you are learning, which is great fir a beginner like me.  There is plenty to climb(sorry I don't know the different names for different types) abd on top that there is the gym aspect. It's not a regular gum, but it's good enough. Plenty of mechanisms to improve the strength needed for climbing. They also offer different classes like yoga. I know that Crossfit Sunnyvale is also located inside, but ask not sure if it's included in the membership. I would LOVE to become a member, but unfortunately it's too far a drive to make on a regular basis.

I love this gym - everything about it. The routes are varied: I'm a beginner, so I appreciate that there are still enough bouldering routes to keep me from getting bored. The actual gym equipment is great, too. There are treadmills, free weights, weight machines, and more cross-fitty equipment, too. The showers are also fantastic. I worked in Santa Clara over the summer, and I would stop here before work each morning: they have shampoo, conditioner, soap, towels, blow dryers, lotion, etc... SOOOO GREAT. The lockers are clean - everything is clean - and there is a spa.Yoga classes were great, although definitely geared towards climbers (which makes sense). But as someone coming here for cross-training, I would've appreciated some leg work ;) Also, the teacher was really hands-on, which I normally like, but she (literally) pushed me a little to far in a couple back bends... not so hot.Tips: Go early. It's crazy in the evening (at least for me).I got the beginner package - it was a good deal. I would recommend it.Talk to people - everyone is nice. Ask where the easy (or hard) routes are. There's a technical wall that has a lot of good options.There's a flat running route around the neighboring office buildings - the area was safe and it was nice to run outside.

This place is really fun! My friend has a membership here so he was able to invite 2 friends (myself and Katherine N) to take the belay class & rock climb! The class was quite informative for first time climbers like me-- it definitely prepared us and gave us confidence. I climbed level 5.2, one of the easier levels. Let me just say the first climb up I barely moved a few feet before "TENSION ON," lol. But the second time Katherine and I made it all the way up top (without looking down of course). Afterwards, we tried bouldering as well. I was a bit too eager and lost my footing up top. Pretty sure I sprained my ankle. But was it worth it? Heck yes!!!! :) Will be back again!

If you love climbing the rocks/boulders this is ideal for you. They have plenty of weights, kettle balls.I don't. So it receives one star as a gym.1) The place is cold. Yesterday I measured it. it was 54 F inside. When I asked them I got answer "Here we don't set any temperature; we open and close windows; that is all".2) I don't believe the answer (1) as there are not many windows, and the yoga room surely has some heaters. But I am forced to believe (1) since the sweat smell prevails throughout campus since they don't open windows in winter. (if you don't feel this place is not stinking, consult ENT doc)3) 90% workers there are white; Among them two displayed racism. 4) Yoga sessions are not calm and instructions are not clear compared to cindys etc. Yoga teacher did not even turn up to the class and front office did not care ( on 1/5/2015 7:30 PM class).5) treadmill, ellipticals are good, but some are rough and needs fix.6) Dirty everywhere needs vacuum.

I have been a member for long enough now to finally write a review. Great gym, great staff. Tuesdays are too crowded, lots of activites. Weekends are not busy - cool. I wish they weren't so busy during week nights and also opened up another gym in San Jose :)

I like this place, and I come here every time I'm in town for work to climb with a work buddy. It's not too overcrowded even during peak weekday hours, though finding a parking space can be challenging since the parking lot is shared with an adjacent tech company.The routes aren't actually that difficult compared to many other gyms, so I wouldn't recommend it for super experienced climbers. I climb a 5.10b at Mission Cliffs, and struggle with 5.9 (!) at Brooklyn Boulders. At Planet Granite 5.10c is readily approachable. It's because the routes are very very tall and so the ratings factor in endurance as well as complexity.The bouldering here is extremely plentiful and quite fun, it's a shame I'm pretty terrible at bouldering!I wish there was a place like this in NYC.

Great place to work out. Rock climbing isn't for everyone but it's something - like most things in life - that gets better with experience. Membership includes a gym, sauna, fitness classes, yoga, spin classes, and more. A membership is pricey but we'll worth it for the great community and equipment. The showers are well stocked and you can get locks for the locker room at the front desk. Everyone who goes is extremely friendly and did I mention there's a motherfuckin SLACKLINE in the back? The absolute most frustrating and rewarding thing that's sitting in the back. Seriously if you're a regular or a visitor you have to try it out. No regrets about a membership and great to being people too. 6/5 stars.

This is the only gym membership I've ever stuck with. If I didn't switch over to checking in with foursquare, I would have been the freaking duchess here. /cry I'm back to checking in with yelp now. If only they changed their UX for checking but oh, I digress. $79ish a month and you get top roping, bouldering, lead climbs in addition to yoga, crossfit, and a decent gym as well as access to their locations up and down the coast. This location even has a slack line. Imagine yourself coming out of the 6:30 90 minute yoga class at the peak of summer to the slack line where the breeze is just right and you're in good company. The sun is just showing the light of dusk and you can see the moon peaking behind the trees. It's like a dream.

One of the biggest climbing gyms in the area, but what I found really interesting is that there are subcultures within this gym that makes it so diverse and dynamic. The cross fitters, yogis, cyclists, and of course climbers. I'm more of a climber, so my assessment is more on the functionality of a gym that has various setter styles that definitely cater to beginner, intermediate and advanced. They change them quite often and have challenging/interesting aspects to the climbs that make it fun to go to every other day for me. The only thing I dislike at times is that it gets so busy on weeknights.. but I guess when you have a gym culture that is open and dynamic, it draws people in... LOVE this place. Also, there's always a few out of order treadmills - which can get a bit frustrating on a busy night. One suggestion, keep some bottles of lysol in the locker rooms for member use, some of those climbing shoes can stink up the whole place!! EEK!

I used to go here and the best rating I could give it would be 4.5 stars but since Yelp doesn't do that I will round up. Rock climbing 5 stars Their rock climbing is great. They have varying degrees of difficulty and change the walls often so their users don't get bored. They have some huge walls that go up very high. There is one wall that is pretty close to an exposed support beam that always made me feel uncomfortable but I usually just choose not to do that one. Other than that one they all seem pretty safe. Gym 3.5 stars They have a decent selection of gym equipment but it gets pretty busy like most public gyms. They don't have a bench press so you have to hog the squat rack if you want to bench press. The membership also included their cross fit classes which seems like a tremendous value since those can be pretty expensive. Catch is if you have never done cross fit you have to go through their orientation which costs extra. All in all this place offers a good value and a great experience. If you are thinking about rock climbing this might just be the best place to start.

This is by far the BEST climbing gym I've ever been to! I'm from southern California, and I went up north to visit some family and decided to check this place out. I WISH THEY OPENED ONE IN THE LA AREA!!This place is great for people of ALL ages. It's a little pricey -- $20 for a day pass. The rentals are extra. I got tested to belay, and the staff member taught me some things I did not know. He was extra friendly, and was super patient with me since I was used to belaying with an ATC. If I lived closer, I would definitely get monthly membership because not only is there climbing, but they have fitness machines and weights as well as a sauna, locker room, and showers. THIS PLACE HAS EVERYTHING IN ONE! Of all the climbing gyms I've been to, they either have more bouldering, climbing only, or more top roping. This place has top roping, bouldering, AND lead climbing. They have climbs of different levels from V0 to even V7. They probably do go higher, but I didn't really look around for all the different levels. The top rope climbs are pretty awesome, and there are lots of people take classes the day of who can belay you.Overall, this is honestly the BEST climbing gym I've been to so far. I REALLYYYYYY hope they open a place in southern California because I would be there almost every day!

It's crazy how many people are parked in front waiting for Planet Granite to open on a Saturday morning! So happy that I came as early as I did! I came with a friend and it was our first time - sh, don't tell anyone but we got a student discount on a weekend day! My friend and I wore our regular workout shoes - which I don't recommend doing. Rock climbing with the appropriate shoes would've made gripping with our feet a lot easier. None the less we still had a blast. We joined in on a yoga class after we got our climbs worth and I must say I've never attended such a long yoga class! I think that it was an hour and a half class? I could be wrong because that class literally kicked my behind. It was a great way to start the day! Can't wait to come back here.

I'm taking the Beginner Rock Climbing Class with a friend, and so far it's been pretty good. Our instructor Amy is pretty chill, but informative and amiable. It is, however, really packed during the class time (I'm in the 7pm class), so it can be kind of difficult to find a spot for me to climb, since I'm still stuck doing somewhat low numbers. (I am the confirmed climbing dunce of my class.) My friend has an easier time since she can tackle higher numbers, and there are understandably few routes below a 5.5 for awful climbers like me. It seems like everyone rockets out to 5.7 or higher after their first week... except in short bus special cases like me, LOL.Overall, the place is really, really expensive. This may simply be coming from someone who doesn't do gym memberships because she typically can't stand the overpowering smell of the cleaners used in many of them (not a problem here, it smells more like old leather shoes all the time, almost certainly because of all the rental climbing shoes). I also make a pittance compared to the average Silicon Valley resident, so there is that as well. Take it with a grain of salt, as what I consider expensive may be quite reasonably priced for you. They do try to be an all-in-one gym with the rock climbing at the forefront and a bunch of cardio equipment and some free weights in the back. I haven't tried any of the classes yet, but I hear they're not bad.Also, it is REALLY COLD in there in the evenings, at least during February. I'm originally from Hawaii, but even my East Coast-born friend finds it a little cool for her tastes. There's a sauna in the bathroom, but I haven't tried it yet--I keep meaning to, but end up leaving too late in the evening.I'll probably be back, although I suppose I can't afford to do it too often after this. My work schedule would make coming here regularly enough to justify the membership tough, because I am frequently stuck working overtime on projects that probably should not have been planned out by folks two levels above the actual grunts, but I would like to at least make it back a couple of times a month. Climbing is a fun sport, if tiring. If you haven't tried it, I suggest you give it a shot!
Excellent facility, happy and encouraging set of peeps working here. We had a great first experience and will come for more. Points for 'Riley' who trained us.

Let me start by saying this review is for yoga and Pilates ONLY. Climbing just isn't for me! :)The GOOD: I love the instructors here! Misako is awesome, Lorraine kicks your butt every time, and all of the other instructors I have had I have really liked as well. Their lunchtime yoga classes are a perfect break from the workday. The Tuesday evening Pilates class was great (when the instructor didn't have the sub that gets confused with her lefts and rights) but I'm not sure if/when it will return. The class times are also very convenient and the staff at the front are always friendly. The locker rooms are simple but nice and clean and the rates are really reasonable considering everything that is included.The BAD: The yoga studio is nice, but cleanliness is iffy. I always have to check the floor around me when we do poses that are hard to keep on your mat because there is all sorts of hair and other stuff on the studio floor that will stick to you quite nicely when you are working up a sweat. I don't expect it to be immaculate, but who knows when the last time they swept/mopped was (and by the looks of it, not recently) not to mention the thought of all the heebie jeebies that you can get from the gym (ex: ringworm) it would be nice if they would clean the floors after each class. Also the weightlifting area is right on the other side of the wall, so you hear the burly dudes picking up and dropping the heaviest barbell they can find while you are trying to meditate or get your nap on during savasana. I absolutely get that Planet Granite is a climbing gym first and a yoga studio possibly last...but with the classes being more and more packed every month, I would give it 5 stars if the yoga studio got a little more TLC and the cardio equipment were on the other side of the wall instead of the Crossfit folks.

I love this place. I pretty much live here after work and on the weekends.$20 for a day pass excluding rentals.$73/month for a membership. $55/month if you're a student. Memberships have a few perks like 10% off their gear, guest passes, and access to all PG gyms. It's worth it if you're there 3-5x per week like me.This place is great. It has a huge variety of bouldering problems, top rope and lead routes. If you don't feel like climbing, there's a full gym area. If you don't like that, there's a huge variety of fitness and yoga classes you can take.Staff is great, friendly and helpful. And most of all, I love the people here. They're generally really cool and open to giving/receiving tips/pointers.All in all, great freakin' gym.

Planet Granite is just amazing. It's hard to describe, so here is a list...Why is Planet Granite amazing?1. TALL 60 ft walls! This not only makes it more fun, but also helps with building stamina and mimics outdoor conditions.2. Cleanliness and organization! Planet Granite is well-ventilated as opposed to smelly, and the holds and ropes are all in great condition. The routes are all well-labeled and unlike at most OC/LA gyms, the colors of the holds are obvious and placed in ways to reduce confusion. This helps with concentrating on the climb instead of trying to figure out which holds you're supposed to use.3. Interesting routes! Planet Granite is SO HUGE so there's the luxury of setting all sorts of routes using all sorts of space. I pretty much never have an issue with climbs that are simply too reachy for me (I'm 5'2''), unlike at certain other gyms where either they do not have enough holds to build a route for short people, or they do not consider this. There are also all sorts of interesting rock features here and different types of holds, so climbers can develop all sorts of climbing techniques! In terms of the difficulty level, Planet Granite is definitely on the easy side. It might be hard to climb outdoors after only climbing at Planet Granite. I mostly climb around 5.10d/5.11a here, but have climbed 5.11b. 5.11s are too hard for me outdoors.4. Variety of climbing AND other activities. There is a spacious lead area, crack climbing area, top roping area, and bouldering area (with super cushy floors). There is also slacklining, rope climbing, and a bunch of cardio and strength training equipment (for crossfit!), as well as acrobatic looking things. People on the cardio equipment face the climbers, so they will never get bored! There is also yoga!5. It's a community! Planet Granite hosts interesting events and competitions with food and everything. Also, they will announce over the intercom if someone needs a belay partner. That seems so helpful!6. Family-friendly. There are a lot of easier routes, so people can bring their children or perhaps those who may be less strong. Some of those easier routes look so cute, like the alphabet ones!7. Amenities. You can borrow towels! And there is a water fountain! This may not sound like much to some, but there are some gyms that have neither :/ There are also showers and saunas. Sooooo nice.8. Rates: Okay, the day pass rate isn't great, but the membership is a steal. If I lived in Norcal I would get the membership...it is inclusive of access to the gym equipment, crossfit, and yoga. Lucky people up North!Verdict: Planet Granite Sunnyvale basically has everything.

In addition to having a climbing gym: they have yogis, cross-fitters, former gymnasts, and just about anyone else in functional strength endeavors.Their hours are pretty nice and they do a good job of keeping their facility clean. Their fitness classes are great ways to build functional strength in climbing and they have lots of neat weightlifting and plyometric equipment used by their crossfit program. For me, functional fitness was the most fun and fastest way of getting in serious shape, and they do a great job catering to these people.For new climbers, they do offer beginners classes and events where you can network with other climbers to get into the community.

Staff is great, super friendly and helpful-- thanks guys! The routes are good, climbing is great, the teachers of classes (yoga, spin, etc) are awesome. However, the prices are through the roof, especially since they raised them this year. Many classes are overcrowded, and on weekday nights, the gym is overcrowded, to the point that it's just unpleasant and not always the safest. That being said, there aren't very many options for gym climbing in the south bay area, so...

Its a great place to relieve your stress - after work or after school or bad breakup with your girl friend or even take your date. Its got everything - CROSSFIT, Yoga, Fitness classes, Rock-climbing (they keep changing courses on the walls every other week it seems). Its an interesting place to be. They got some kinda specials going on to bring in free guests or for belay lessons. Its little expensive but definitely worth a visit for every month.

Prices = moderate.  I get the 10-pass for $165.00  Service = friendly.Atmosphere = well lit, clean, and organized.  Their climbing walls are marked mostly by color of hand/footholds, and occasionally, colored duct tape.  Trust me, it's easier to locate, rather than trying to look down for a piece of tape that's under the said hand/foothold.  Ohhh, and their grigris have painted numbers to match the trails...Smart! They have a beautiful outdoor area too.  Some seating, a tightrope area, and rubber 'chips'!  The bathroom is immaculate, gorgeous, and has a sauna!I think we're getting spoiled by the cleanliness and spaciousness of this place!

Although it could get really crowded at times during peak hours, this place is awesome.  The bouldering walls are well-maintained and changed often enough to provide a new challenge every few weeks. The staff is always friendly and welcoming. The top-roping walls look fun to climb (although I haven't gone on many myself). They also have crossfit equipment and cardio machines for use. The bathrooms include lockers as well as showers and saunas and is kept clean. I have noticed that there are generally more guys than girls bouldering. Overall, a good place to go rock climbing and workout while you're at it. The membership prices are not too expensive and could easily be paid off within a few trips. Love this place!
I came for the bouldering but stayed for the classes. I used to climb a ton but I got tired of having sandpaper for hands. I love the classes especially MELISSA! She'll make you work your tail off!
Love that this guy has yoga & rock climbing.  I moved away and am back now for a few months and rejoined.  It's so good to be back

Climbing team has been fantastic for our son. Great gym and even better coaches. I would  be remiss to not give a special call out to Isaac - Thanks!PG also has some fun fitness & yoga classes if climbing isn't your thing.

This is a great gym, but I must give them the OK rating. The problem: it gets too full on most weekdays in the evening. I think it's time to open up another gym closeby. This is already a huge gym, but it makes it less pleasurable with so many monkeys trying to climb the same rock :) Planet Granite in San Francisco is comparable, but less packed...

Oh Swow! I LOVE Planet Granite so much! Climbing, gym, classes. They have it all and then some! The price of a membership is higher than other gyms, but that's because they offer so much. I came here on Sunday to meet up with some friends and go climbing. I had been meaning to take the belay class so I could get certified and they happened to have one last spot, so I grabbed it.Evan (the instructor) was great. Friendly and helpful and explained everything in detail. I really felt good about all I had learned and passed the belay test the next day without problem! :)My only real complaint is how freaking busy the climbing walls are Mon-Friday anytime from 5-9pm. It's just ridiculous. At some point I wonder if they will start turning people away because having to wait to climb anything is not fun, especially when you're paying so much to be there. I highly recommend checking them out on a weekend or during the day. It's super fun!
PG has made learning how to climb very accessible and there the selection of walls is immense. It is very popular on weekends ( I go Saturdays) but it's more potential friends. Highly recommended!

This review is for the after school class. We really loved this class when Jessica taught it. But not so happy with the new guys leading the class. Yes the are good with the kids. But not good at keeping the class moving. My issues:1. They start CONSISTENTLY late. A couple times it was 15 minutes after before they started over to get harnesses on. 2. There is to much goofing around. At first it was a little but then quickly became a lot and took time away from class. 3. They are too slow, my child was only climbing top rope 2 times in 2 hours...with the new guys. 4. They raised the price. Used to be 125$. If you're going to raise the price you need to hire efficient teachers, that use the time wisely and start on time. We haven't been back since our last session...and not sure if we will. I hate to waste time...especially when you're paying that much and your child spends 2/3rds if the class waiting around playing rock-paper-scissors.

I've been coming to planet granite for almost 2 years and it's the best climbing gym that I've been to. The walls routinely get fresh routes every week and the facilities are pretty nice. There is a large variety of different climbs that you do with excellent top roping walls also. There is also a nice gym there where you can get a good workout in after your climb. They also have a cross fit area where you can choose to lift with bumper plates also. They also give a nice student discount for full time students !

Today was my second visit to Planet Granite in Sunnyvale.  I'm new to climbing and the staff has been very nice with answering questions and the facility is well designed.  My second visit was for a belay lesson, after some confusion regarding what time I reserved, they rectified the issue and class was completed.  The instructor, Daniel, was very knowledgeable and is excellent!  I will be returning here!

Went here for the first time on a Friday and boy was it crowded. Thanks to a friend for getting me in on his guest pass!The place is ridiculously huge and too crowded for my taste. I had to wait my turn to boulder every corner I went to so I didn't get to climb as much as I wanted to. After two hours, I just left. It would be good to check what are not peak times and try to go again. The staff there is very friendly and helpful when I had questions. I don't live in the area so I won't be going frequently unless any of my friends want to climb.

I'm so happy that I went here because it definitely exceeded all my expectations for a rock gym. I got a membership about half a year ago because I wanted to get back into bouldering, and OH MY GOODNESS. This place is TOO FUN. The facility offers so much. Not only can you top rope and boulder, but PG offers fitness classes and a pretty good variety of exercise machines. Peak hours are definitely in the evening time. It gets preeeettttty crowded, especially when routes have just been changed. The people there are extremely friendly and helpful. No need to be timid going up the wall. If anything, people have great advice for you. :) My favorite time to go there is definitely in the morning before it gets busy.Special thanks to Nick. I believe he's the assistant manager? He has always been very efficient in helping me out when I e-mail him. He responds super fast and gets the job done without any hassle. I had to freeze my account at some point because I knew I wouldn't be going as often, and he took care of it quicker than I had expected. Awesome place, workers, and crowd. Check this place out for yourself!

Absolutely great Crossfit gym. Plenty of space and all the equipment I need. I don't run much tho so you'd be on your own as far as finding a place to run. The climbing is everything I would have hoped for in this gym.Minus 1 star, and maybe even 2, for the smell. Not the smell of the gym, but peoples feet. I know the gym is clean because I've been there when its empty on the weekend, no smell whatsoever. But when its packed, and everyone is barefoot this place is pretty tough to tolerate. it actually turned me off from joining for years, im actually still not a member. I think PG should make shoes mandatory at all times. not only does it smell when people are barefoot but it's also just not hygenic. I did a burpee the other day and [jokingly] wondered if i would get athletes chin from hitting my chin. im sure all it took was one person to walk around with athletes foot. then 100 other people did, and now it smells 100x worse because everyone has athletes foot. So great gym as far as equipment and routes to climb, but they should really regulate dress code here. Shoes should be required. Also, the whole shirtless thing from the scrawny guys is kinda weird, but i guess i'm ok with that compared to the no shoes. i saw one girl with flip flops once. im glad she at least had that decency not to spread her foot sweat everywhere. no bare feet people, COME ON MAN! pretty gross. well im about to go climb, need to get prepared to hold my breath.

Yet another place where I have decided to buy a membership because I love it!! I've gone rock climbing when I was young but never came back. Then I bought a groupon and woo hoo this place is awesome! I've never been to any other rock climbing gym but I heard this one and the one's in SF are some of the best indoor gyms ever!! Not only do they have rock climbing but they also have a full gym, nice locker rooms, yoga classes, spinning classes, etc. I know some of the yoga instructors that teach at my favorite regular studio that also teach here and they're amazing. It is not your typical lame yoga classes like at the YMCA. I've topped roped (the one with the rope) and I have bouldered (shorter walls but without anything helping you. I'm a huge fan of bouldering. If you want to top rope you'll need a belay partner. Which can be tricky if you go alone, but they'll always help you find someone. And you'll need to take a belay training and a test before you are certified to belay someone. Btw, they don't let you take the test the same day that you take the class. They get very crowded in the evening starting around 4-5pm all the way until about 9:30pm. In the afternoon and mornings it is really quiet so if you like to be in your own zone then I'd go at the earlier or super late hours. If you want some help and want to socialize with hundreds of climbers come during rush hour! The only problem with that is that you have to wait your turn. So you don't get a lot of climbing done with time that you are there. Check the website for rates but they're pretty reasonable! If you just want to try this place out and have a friend that has a membership then ask them to get you in! We get day passes and get a free guest the first Friday of every month after 5pm! Oh and one more thing I recommend. If you take the belay class, buy their package deal for their gear. It's something like $120 for harness, shoes, and a chalk bag. Great deal for beginners and then you don't have to wear their rental shoes which, if you ever stuck your nose in them, are disgusting!!

The people here are inconsistent with their customer appreciation. It varies from smug to annoyed to simple pleasantries. The clientele is something that they cannot help, but I never feel all that comfortable around them. I rock climb to have fun and relax, but I can't really do that here. The rental equipment is very uncomfortable. I always bring extra things for my friends to use, because their harnesses cut into your legs when you fall. The lines can get really long, but at least the gym has many routes. Good place for beginners who are not taking a class.

I give Melissa the Total Body Fitness and Abs /Core instructor 5 stars and the PG facility 4 stars.  I love Melissa!  She is super friendly and makes working out fun!  All of her classes are super packed so be sure to get there early.Overall PG is a great place to climb. Big and clean, but the locker room / showers could use some work.  After work this place is a zoo.

My review is only on the climbing part of the gym. I haven't taken any fitness classes or used any of the other facilities. I've been climbing for more than 25 years, much of that time indoors. I've been to gyms all over the world, and I've never been to a place that doesn't tape their routes. WTF? This may work for roped climbs, but in the bouldering world it's almost impossible to tell what holds are part of which route. An orange hold and a red hold covered in chalk dust look exactly the same I'm sorry. I spent more time trying to figure out routes than I did pulling on stuff. Not sure what the motivation was for ditching tape, but if you are a serious climber this place is not for you.

Pros:  It has everything  -climbing, yoga, weight training, crossfit, etc.Love their yoga classes and instructors.  They have many levels and variety.The staff are nice.  Cons(minus 1* for it):Expensive Crowded after work hours It smells like "feet" and I mean stinky sweaty feet in there.  It's understandable but can be unbearable to breath sometimes if you're sensitive to scent.Worth the membership if you can go a lot!  I wish they would enforce shoe policy in the weight room though.  Some guys lift weights barefoot and it smells.. WOW!

Great place to spend a few hours. Excellent varied climbing terrain for both toproping and bouldering, big gym area with ropes, pull-up station, Crossfit area, slack line area out back.Not a ton of free weights, but there are plenty of other toys to play with.My favorite thing about this place is that it feels like a big fun playground with something different to play with around each corner.For context: My regular gym is Mission Cliffs, but I've been to GWPC, Ironworks, Dogpatch, and the Studio.  If I lived in the South Bay, Planet Granite would be my second home.

This place is SOLID.The staff is really friendly and responsible. I didn't bring my minor liability waiver but they let me fax it from home and were polite about it. I came with a friend in the morning, when each pass is $15. Seems pricey but it's worth it once you start exploring the gym.The walls go up to 60 feet and vary from slab climbing to crack climbing to lead climbing to normal, fun top-roping. You can belay each other as long as you get tested near the entrance. Awesome arete problems.....awesome holds.....(I love how most of the routes are color-coded by hold, not tape.) This place is so big and beautiful that I thought I died and went to heaven. Planet Granite also has extensive bouldering areas indoors and in a semi-outdoors area. Didn't boulder as much as I toproped but the boulder routes I did try seemed reasonably rated and creatively set. I'm grateful  that the whole ground of the bouldering area was padded...no shifting of crash pads necessary! Just hop on to the wall with a spotterI love the gym equipment/yoga rooms. Plenty of treadmills, monkey bars, and even a rope attached to the roof. And the music was awesome. Mumford and Sons, the XX....good tastes, bud. ^__^My only complaint: there's a lot of friction while belaying with the topropes. Might be because of the anchors. It's a shame that my house is 27 minutes away from here. But if I could live here, I would.

Oh Planet Granite. It's been a while since I've been to any other climbing gym, but this is really as good as it gets. The location is great, the desk people are helpful and super cool, and the walls are changed up pretty regularly for different types of challenges. They have bouldering, top roping, and even lead climbing; all in different difficulty levels to suit everyone. The only warning is that because it's so good it does get really crowded at times (especially after work).The day passes are $20 and rentals are $6 (harness and shoes), which is a bit on the pricey side, but is okay if you don't want to do the membership (which runs about $70 a month). If you know someone with a membership, they get free passes every now and then if you want to give it a shot without actually committing. The only thing you need to belay is the belay card, which you can get by taking the test at the before you climb. If you don't know the knots/how to belay, they offer free lessons which also mean you get to climb for the rest of the day for free (just have to sign up beforehand for the class).The staff seems really cool though. There was one time I only brought cash (left my wallet in the car), but was a dollar short and the guy still let me get my rental equipment for a "discounted" price instead of making me go all the way back to my car. Very cool.They also have "normal" gym equipment there as well (treadmills, weights, etc.) for people who don't want to climb and yoga classes I believe. This place is really huge for what it is (3 bouldering walls and really long climbs, which I absolutely love!); even then, you might find yourself waiting for a wall to free up every now and then. Since it's so crowded, you should always be aware of your surroundings too, cause there are always people dropping down. If you don't have a belay partner, you can always go to the front desk and ask them to find you one (they'll make an announcement for you to find someone who is looking for someone to climb with.

Planet Granite is definitely as good as it gets!  You get an amazing bouldering, toproping/leading climbing, yoga , crossfit, and other cool activities for ONE AMAZING LOW PRICE! The best part is PG is only 5 minutes away from my work! Whoo! Doesn't get any better than that!  Since finding PG, i have not renewed my 24 Hr membership and i have no plans to do so... ever.  Come check it out! there are a lot of cool people that hang out here!

PG is the best .I have been coming here regularly for the past few months for Climbing and also to use the gym.Coming down to the pros and consPros:-The Staff:-As a person who has not done any rock climbing before,PG staff made me feel really welcome .They are always very pleasant and ready to answer any questions with a huge smile.For me that shows that they really love what they are doing and it totally translates to how the business is being run and the overall ambience of the place.Cleanliness:-Its always clean and well maintained.I wouldnt say its the most stylish looking gym but its always well maintainedChanging routes:- The climbing routes are regularly changed and updated to keep the climbers explore more.Gym:- Has a ton of equipment which can be used and are available.Unlike many gyms which have way too many things which are not so useful and always too busyCrossfit:- Need i say more.The pure torturous workout is part of your membership feeCons:-1)Not too many cardio classes.I know its not that kind of gym but still some Zumba would be super 2)Crossfit intro:- The intro classes are cool and could be done with  4 crossfit intro classes instead of 8..Other than than my family and i totally enjoy the gym and hope to do so for many many years ahead

Is this place a climbing wall and gym or a day care facility? Seriously!? Way too many unsupervised kids here has completely turned me away from renewing my membership. It's a shame because the facilities are great.

This place is probably the best location in the south bay for rock climbing. They have lots and lots of walls to chose from and a small gym area with the standard equipment you'd see at any other gym. I was going to cancel my gym membership and sign up for this place, but I felt the gym area could have been cleaned up and the clientele that visit this place really isn't there for the workout equipment. If you are into climbing this is the place to checkout in the south bay.

Today, I'm giving PG another star.  Why?  Over the past year, I've been going to this gym and have come to appreciate a few things.  Last time I complained about pricing.  For day passes and then rentals, it's still pricey, but for a membership, it's kinda a STEAL.  For the price of your monthly membership, you get access to top roping routes and two bouldering sections, access to workout machines and free weights, AND classes-including yoga, pilates, spinning, and crossfit.  That's just crazy AWESOME.  I really don't think there's anywhere else that you can access all of that for one price.  I also appreciate the set up a lot more.  Having been climbing out East last year, I now understand that they've taken extra care to set up the ropes for safe environment.  Yay!I'm still withholding one star because it gets crazy packed and we continue to spend hours upon hours there because of the downtime/wait between climbs.  We've even tried going to Belmont instead, but we Sunnyvale just works better in for us because of the variety and difference in climbing skills.  This isn't exactly their fault, but it sucks.  I wonder if there was a way to expand and add more top roping routes, without having to put them closer together.  Too bad there is not another location in between Sunnyvale and Belmont, or even in San Jose to help alleviate the "after dinner rush."

Planet Granite is one of those places where there is rock climbing, a gym, yoga, and cross-fit all in one. It is similar to a 24 hour fitness where you pay a monthly membership and you can access the facility at your convenience.  If your not a member then you can pay a drop in fee of $15 to do use the facility for the day. If you do not have rock climbing shoes and a harness you can rent both for $6. You have to give them one of your shoes to make sure you don't run away with theirs. As a newbie like myself you NEED to come with a partner because you need someone to belay you. I've seen some pros just go up by themselves which is crazy.  They have classes to learn how to be a certified belayer but if your limited on time you should come with someone who is already certified. They also have bouldering and crack climbing which is super difficult. For a newbie I suggest doing the 5.8-5.10 which is not that bad. The higher the number is the rocks becomes smaller and fewer. Rock climbing is about technique and not about strength, I learned that the hard way. It can get busy during 5-7 pm just like any other gym. As for the weights and equipment, it is decent, a bit worn out but still usable.  If I lived in the area I would probably join this gym. The staff is very friendly and best of all they have towel service. Parking is plentiful. Lastly every first Thursday is free rock climbing at night.

Planite Granite day passes are expensive, but membership is not bad for what you get.  The equipment/gear packages they sell are also a great value (harness, shoes, etc.)This location, like all others, smells like stinky feet.  It is something I had to get over, as there is no way to avoid it at these places.The staff is really awesome, and the members are pretty awesome too.  Everyone is so nice, friendly and helpful.  The locker rooms are sufficient, as are the climbing walls and and standard gym equipment.  Parking is plentiful in this location, as they have a large free parking lot.

After about 2 years of on and off climbing here I feel like I can recommend this place. The gym is fairly large with plenty of climbs to try out, and there is a good amount of both top roping and bouldering. The routes are changed regularly, so there is always something new to try. The weight gym is not too big, but it gets the job done. I only tried the yoga three times, and while it's not my really my thing the instructors led a great class that kicked my butt. I've also never had any negative experiences with the staff so that's another plus. Overall it's a fine place to come and practice, either alone or with friends. Just make sure you come before it gets super crowded.

I go to this gym mostly for their yoga classes and enjoy them very much. I frequent Lorraine's, Jill's and Misako's classes most. I have had classes with subs before and haven't been disappointed. Seeing that the gym doesn't really specialize in yoga I understand that they are more lenient on students being late. I do wish the studio was in the back of the building since it can get loud due to the parking lot. The gym itself consists of mostly climbers since it is a rock climbing gym but I haven't tried it once despite being a member for about 2.5 years. The staff keeps the gym clean but it does smell funky sometimes and can get overwhelming. The equipment is pretty decent...and when I say equipment I mean the treadmill and elliptical because that's all I use. The monthly fee is pretty cheap compared to some yoga studios I've researched so even though I don't climb I still feel like I'm getting a good deal.

I took the belay class with my friends and Kevin was our instructor. He's super nice! Don't know if you can choose instructors but get Kevin. And the test for the belay certificate is super easy and we all passed!There's a lot of people there on Sundays but its not too crowded to the point you have to wait to climb.There's so many differnet levels and walls. Really like it here. They also have a gym here so you can work out here and also there's yoga. I almost didnt want to give a 5 star because one of the staff,  Evan was very rude to us from the beginning. He had a "uhhh what do you want" attitude and looks at us like we were dumb. He asked us if we were renting gear and automatically charged us for both harness and shoes when we wanted just the harness. When he gave us shoes he gives us completely wrong sizes and didn't even tell us he didnt have our sizes or anything. We were really upset and in a bad mood because of Evan.But because Kevin and the other staff were so nice to us I give Planet Granite a 5 star.

PG is a great place to learn how to rock climb and belay. We took belay lessons and our instructor Jennifer was very helpful and friendly.The belay lessons are $34 which include rentals and a day pass. After, you have the option of a purchasing a discounted 5-pack if you took the belay lessons. I recommened going for that since if you got belay lessons, you probably plan on going several times more.They have a good amount of courses ranging from beginner to advance. The courses are changed from time to time to keep it challenging. They have bouldering courses, cardio equipment, free weights, selecterized weight machines, even Olympic lift bumper plates for crossfit goers. Awesome place to challenge yourself and to have fun!

Silicon Valley yuppies ditch their suits and dresses and the monotony of the 9am-5pm work schedule to become super hero climbers at Planet Granite.THIS IS WHERE ALL THE YOUNG PEOPLE ARE.  On a weeknight, PG is flooded with 20 and 30-somethings -- I just fit right in.  Climbing has become an incredible stress relief outlet and a healthy hobby!  No wonder it caught on so well.I started off as a young grasshopper of a climber.  I am by NO MEANS a natural at rock climbing.  I can't position my body well, the lack of dexterity in my fingers is largely unhelpful, and I have little arm strength to contribute.  But man, oh man.  After one month (2 climbing sessions/week), I improved leaps and bounds.  PG has plenty of courses and you can always find a challenge.  The Belay Course:  1 hour course, offered at 6, 7, 8pm on most days.  First, you learn how to tie-in, learning the knots, the safety check system.  Next, you learn how to belay: hook-in, safety checks, feed the rope, and brake.  My friend and I were the only ones in this course so we received personal attention.  The instructor had a bit of trouble accommodating for a lefty (myself), but it was a-ok.The Belay test:  line up!  It's a lightning fast hands-on quiz of everything you learned in the belay course.  Don't flinch or you may not pass.  :O  No pressure though.  Just refresh the basics and you'll earn the red belay certification in no time!The top-rope climbs:  there are so many!  Varying heights, difficulties, and features.  The courses are altered monthly.TIPS for 1st timers:- It's gonna be a blast. - If possible, I recommend you eat a light dinner beforehand so you have some energy to devote to those muscles.  Or bring a Cliff bar (ya know, cuz you'll be hanging off cliffs?).  - I don't recommend that you wear shorts just bc it may result in an embarrassing wedgie.- Find solace in the steam room.  10 minutes and your muscles will thank you.- The parking lot gets pretty full just FYI.  It's unavoidable.Overall, after one month of climbing, I'm hooked.  After one and a half months of not climbing, I vow I will return soon.  The people here are incredibly inspirational and I can only strive to do what they can do!  No complaints.  :)

The facility is ginormous.  I kinda felt like James Franco in 126 Hours when I first walked in.  Mom, Dad, I love you...where the heck did the front door go????My group from work took a 60min, private belay lesson ($28/person, max of 6 ppl) with Luke and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  Luke was laid-back, knowledgeable, patient, and very detailed.  Elliott, who helped set up the lesson, was friendly and professional over the phone.  The women's dressing room is awash in light and decked out with hair dryers and mirrors galore.  The floors are squishy and fun. In contrast, aside from a few, the routes are rude, pissy bastards who have extreme mood swings (the routes seem to get re-set pretty often).  I can see how rock climbing gets addictive.  Ah, the spirit is willing, but the flesh...keeps having muscle spasms!  I'm in awe of all the lithe, limber women who were virtually waltzing up the freaking wall.The $19 drop-in and monthly rates are a bit steep for me and, judging from the increasing foot traffic by Friday lunchtime, I'm guessing it gets pretty busy, so I probably won't become a wall-waltzer myself.  But I think this is a great alternative to dinner-and-a-movie.  Whether romantic or platonic, there's nothing like stringing someone up on a rope to really get the bonding going.

Planet Granite is the best. I dont know how any climbing gym could be better than PG. I've been to a few climbing gyms in both So. and Nor. Cal and this is by far the best. Why? PG provides a number of places to boulder as well as top rope. Most gyms focus on one or the other or even have limited numbers of each. But, not planet granite. They have a number of each for all levels. I'm always in awe watching people tackle harder climbs. You learn a lot watching people and tend to push yourself more after seeing the dedication from the people around you. PG also offers a full gym with classes like crossfit, cycling, yoga, etc. I havent taken any yet but they seem to be well received amongst my peers. While membership seems a bit pricey at first, its actually a great deal. Considering you pay $20 each time to climb w/o a membership, it could quickly add up. But if you take into account that they offer a full gym w/ classes, its well worth the money. I plan on continuing my membership @ PG for years to come.

Planet Granite is a great rock climbing gym!  They have tons of rock climbing routes that regularly get updated.  They have rock climbing classes for those of beginner and intermediate skill.  Their route setters are good, and so is their community.  They even have a workout area, and yoga and crossfit classes.So why the average review?  A couple complaints.  First, they get absolutely packed in the evenings.  Second, their rates continue to climb.  The 2015 monthly rate is increasing to $85/month, with no monthly discounts to long time members.  Finally, a lot of their fitness equipment is old and run down.In short, if you're an avid climber, going to PG is a no-brainer.  If you are going there to take fitness classes or work out, there are better options for less.

My favorite climbing gym so far! They have a great bouldering wall setup and many toprope climbs as well. They even have a slackline, which is quite uncommon. Their gym is pretty great too, since it's never crowded. I definitely recommend this climbing gym!

My poor fingerrrsss! I had so much fun climbing, only to realize afterward that I can't even carry a drink because my arms were super beat!! My partner in crime and I love coming here to climbing as a team and cheering for eachother compared to other/regular workouts. They have plenty of available gym equipment, sauna, yoga, and even trapezing! ITS A MUST go if you never safely fallen from 50ft high or went bouldering before..

They have a lot of climbing options, and regularly change the routes. I go mostly for the workout classes bc I have a shared membership. The workout machines are never full since this is a climbing gym but it can get hot in the middle of the day if you're not positioned under a fan just right. Not a lot of people use the showers or sauna which is also a plus.The yoga classes are legit. I have done yoga here and there, and most of the classes are actually too fast-paced for me. Either way, the teachers are accomodating to any skill level, and recommend alternate positions for varying skill-levels and injuries. I really like the ab class with Zeus. The music is upbeat and the class is always full. You will be sore for a few days after but it's worth it. Zeus is nice and always willing to give suggestions for pain management as well.

Surprisingly crowded during the week.  We came on Wednesday after work and it was basically busy until around 10pm (they close at 11pm).  $23 for day pass + shoe rental to go bouldering.  Extra $2-3 for a harness if you opt to rock climb.  $1 for chalk bag.  They have a good number of bouldering walls and courses.  Definitely had a good workout here!There's also a regular gym in the back - treadmill, weights, etc.  Makes me want to get a membership here!!!

Been coming to planet granite now for 4 years, I can't get enough of this place. -The staff is super friendly -- Mitch and John always greet you with a friendly hello-The walls are top notch (I've been to many other climbing gyms)-The routes are changed regularly so it's always fresh-The weight equipment is good not great-Lots of awesome classes available (yoga, spin, crossfit, etc)I also go to the climbing comps which are super fun. They blast pump up music (usually house), set a whole bunch of killer routes, feed you, and even give you a free t-shirt. What more could you ask for! I love this place.

I have been climbing at planet granite now for just about 12 years. I was a member at the original Santa Clara gym and I even route set at the Belmont gym back in 2006 briefly. While slightly corporate feeling compared to smaller gyms of the 90s planet granite is an impressive step forward in the development of indoor climbing in America. The grandeur and scope of the engineering and construction makes you awe at the walls even after a hundredth visit. Fitness, yoga, and climbing what more could you need? This gym and the entire family of Pg gyms get 5 stars from me. My only complaints would be the subtle yet persistent encroachment of screaming macho crossfit people in the fitness areas, maybe one summer we can add-on a crossfit only wing to the gym complete with acoustics to make all the screaming even louder and more impressive. Lastly I think the planet granite family needs to consider some additions into its route setting philosophy by considering the inclusion of routes that are maybe more dynamic, more sequence intensive, and in general more extreme. Too many routes feel almost the same as the route they just took down.  Continue being awesome planet granite! And don't play to much rap music.

Fun, challenging way to get a workout!Got a groupon for a week membership, including the belay class in which you can get your permanent belay card. Our instructor was awesome and patient. Everyone who works there is pretty down to earth from what I've experienced.I definitely gained a new respect for rock climbers haha. People here are very hardcore! This gym also has regular gym equipment like weight machines, treadmills, etc. and also offers classes such as yoga, crossfit and kickboxing.It's not the cheapest membership, but if you're into rock climbing and other forms of fitness, this place may be for you :)
