This place is super crowded during the week.  It is a bit annoying.  On the plus side, they change their routes a lot.  So, you always have new problems.  There is also a gym.  But, it is reserved for cross-fit during the most desirable hours making it virtually useless.  And, the cross-fit people are not nice about sharing the space.  It is like a cult.  If you are in the cult, everyone is nice.  But, if you are a free thinker, you are treated poorly.  The attitude is all wrong here.  But, it is bigger than twisters and it is the only game in town for sport climbing.  If you can, get a friend to teach you.  The classes do not offer much instruction beyond the basics.  You will learn more from doing it yourself with a friend.  The classes are kind of a waste of money.The yoga instructors are good.  Much better than 24 hour.  People either love or hate Eric's power yoga.  He does some really hard stuff.  It is almost ridiculous.  Some people like it.  Others think he is showing off.This place was so much better before everyone jumped on the cross-fit band wagon.  Now, this place kinda sucks.  They charge a lot for what it is especially because access to the gym is so limited.

Come here very regularly. Been here since January and it's great that I'm keeping in shape, especially now that I'm working a 8-5 job and sitting on my butt all day. They change the walls pretty regularly and it's always fun here. Sometimes it gets really packed though. I also recommend a sweatshirt cause they sometimes keep the giant windows and doors open and it gets windy and cold. Now that I'm getting to V4s-V6s, I have to use my legs more often and it's difficult with my PCL tear in my right leg. I can't do heel hooks or toe hooks to well. I rely a lot on my upper body, but it's still enjoyable. I can't wait to top rope. If anyone wants to go to Castle let me know!

I'm a fan of the Sunnyvale Planet Granite and the San Francisco one. Here's a review:ClimbingI'm not a top-roper so I occasionally boulder but this place has a lot of bouldering walls and routes for every skill level. The only downside is that the popularity here means on weeknights, you're going to have to wait your turn and climb with a lot of other folks.Machines and Weight LiftingThey have Crossfit classes here and a really great weight lifting area with everything you can think of including kettlebells.They have a limited selection of Precor machines which includes about 6 treadmills, a bunch of ellipticals, a few Concept 2 rowers, and some bicyclings/spinning machines. The great part is since most people are here to climb, I've never had to wait for a machine.Locker RoomsThe locker rooms (at least the mens) has a few hundred lockers for day use. Bring your own lock and these guys fill up quick. There's a shower area and each stall has pump dispensers for soap, shampoo and conditioner with names like "spring rain" etc. The sauna is nice as well and the area is kept really clean.ParkingParking lot is shared with a technology office so there's tons of parking but you might have to park a bit further away if you come after work.Finally, the staff has been helpful and nice and there's a great selection of climbing gear that's discounted for members. They also host a bunch of different parties/events throughout the year here so it's a great place to meet new friends and get a great workout.

This is for the customer service at the front desk: I arrived to take my first yoga class and asked to rent a mat. The person at the front desk said there were no yoga mats because they were all dirty and had not yet been cleaned. I waited for him to offer to clean one, but he just kept looking at me like I was out of luck. He could have given me a mat and bottle of cleaner - I would have cleaned it! So I left. They didn't seem to care that they lost out on a new customer.

The only thing I do not like about this place is that it costs me $74 dollars a month for membership.  That costs is pretty steep but its definitely worth it.The routes are always fresh and as a beginning climber, I always have new routes to climb.They have YOGA and CROSSFIT classes here, which I recommend everybody to take advantage of.There is an area to LIFT WEIGHTS  and CARDIO machines are always open.I love the community here and people are always nice and willing to talk to you and smile.I used to come 2-3 times a week and now frequent this place as a guest.

It's hard to give 4 or 5 stars.Pros: Very tall walls/boulder areaExtensive wall featuresNice indoor gymFull bathrooms/showers/sauna/locker roomCons: -Place gets BUSY-Almost all of the desk staff are very impersonal, and don't talk to you when they're climbing or out and about. You have to be sociable and friendly so you members feel more at home!-Expensive (compared to local rock gym memberships)-the setting is very reachy. I'm 6ft, with +0 apx, and some moves are incredibly far, even for me!Overall, the gym is nice to come and train at. But if you're looking for any sort of fun, social vibe, you won't really find it here.

I love this gym.  The climbing, the fitness classes, collaborating with other climbers...BUT There are a few staff members that need to improve their customer service skills.  Don't get me wrong, most of them are great, but there are the couple who probably don't realize they are emitting an unfriendly vibe. This can be easily rectified with small gestures such as saying hello, smiling, or eye contact.Other than that, PG has many great amenities: the cushioned floors (which eliminates having to pull pads around), the sauna (which I have yet to use, but will), the slackline outside, great yoga and fitness classes, gym area, fundraising events, comps, etc.EDIT: Bumping it from 4 to 5 stars because of Monica, a worker.  She's friendly, knowledgeable and provides great service.

Friendliest, people, yet for this holiday season for me. They definitely win the award for best attitude towards customers hands down. The receptionist even noticed my domo keychain and made small talk about it which I thought was really cool since not many people know about domo!This place is absolutely hugigantic, one of the biggest of these rock climbing facilities I've seen. They have a gym attached to it and some yoga rooms as well. The rates seem pretty reasonable for the amount of equipment they have in-house and they have climbing walls from easy to difficult to please all types of climbers. The only complaint I have about this place is that they really need some better ventilation ... it smells ... terribly so!

Pros:- Huge climbing gym, good for beginners and experienced climbers alike- One of the few things that south bay residents can brag about- Staff is friendly, helpful, and always open to giving advice. Most of them are good climbers too, from what I can tellCons:- Could be cleaner, especially the shower room- Gym equipment (treadmill) breaks down often, sometimes taking weeks to get fixed- Kids running around, unsupervised- Kids violating every aspect of climbing etiquette- Kids shouting and being obnoxious- Kids.

I really like this place, good atmosphere. Chill people working the counter. They have equipment for sale, drinks, snacks, full yoga studio, full set of weight lifting equipment and exercising machines, but the best part are the rock walls. They have two bouldering rooms with lots of challenging climbs for all levels. As well as top rope stuff, lead climbing, as well as a calendar full of events. Planet Granite has been becoming the  highlight of my day, awesome.

Planet Granite is my first experience bouldering or rock climbing in general. The $20 entrance fee is kinda steep for a couple hours (who can climb after 2 hrs?!). Shoe rentals for bouldering was only $4 so that's a little bit more reasonable. For the experience it was fun.As other yelpers have mention, the gym gets really crowded, at least on the bouldering side. However people are very friendly and there's a unspoken line where people would take turns and all. I'm sure that's just common courtesy within the bouldering community.I stopped by the locker room and it seems clean and well maintained, but it was just a quick bathroom break.What I didn't like about the place was the BO the people in there would have. There's little to no air circulation in the gym so people's stench would linger around for minutes before finally dissipating. In addition to that, people have stinky shoes/feet and that doesn't add a pleasant smell to the gym either...I really don't want to take one star off for what people bring to the gym, but for a gym it bothered me quite a lot!

Of all the times I've gone indoor rock climbing, Planet Granite in Sunnyvale has been the least crowded experience. Located in what seems like an industrial part of town, there doesn't seem to be too much foot traffic nearby. Parking is plentiful and the weather almost always sunny. I don't frequent this gym enough to get a pass so I usually go with the day pass. What's great is that your belay test verification lasts a year from your last visit so that allows me to start climbing right away instead of having to deal with that stuff. The setup is similar to other indoor rock climbing gyms with varied levels of difficulty spread out throughout with a bouldering area as well. I've never used the workout equipment there, but they seem to have a good assortment. Also, like most other climbing gyms, they offer yoga and other classes.

This is really a great place if you're into rock climbing or want to be into it. We got a membership here for a while and went several times a week with our friends. The thing is, like others have said, it gets insanely crowded with the after work crowd. Parking is impossible and the routes are so crowded you hardly get anything done. I never used the gym equipment or the classes, but the locker room and the rock climbing areas were both really nice. The staff is very nice, and we did have fun here. I recommend going on the weekends if you can because it is much more pleasant without the crowds.

Great gym to be a member of. Cons are it's extremely packed from around 5 to closing. If you're there to lift weights there isn't much to work with and have fun fighting for a spot with all the climbing kids and crossfitters who take up all the space. Would be great of those two groups didn't exist. Definitely not your traditional gym.  If you're a climber you will definitely love it here. I think I'll go back to a regular gym now and pay less and also deal with less people with more equipment.

The climbing gym is huge! You can also lift weights and work on other aspects of your strength or even do yoga. I tried Planite Granite via my friends free guest pass and I had a kick with the climbing routes; I was extremely disappointed with the Vinyasa Body Flow yoga class. The instructor was unnecessarily wordy at times making it hard to follow the postures and that frustrated me, often thinking I should leave climb more. The most annoying part was that I did not break a sweat in yoga, but did so while climbing.I'll definitely go back for the climbing and the weights, but not the yoga!

I have always wanted to try rock climbing and bouldering.  I went with my friend during the middle of the day and it was perfect, not busy and a lot of open space.  The $20 entrance fee was a little steep and the shoe rental was around $5-$6?  Which was still a little high.  Bring your own socks as they do not have any for you to borrow.  hehe.  The staff is really friendly.  I tried bouldering and I tell you it was so fun and what a workout.  Im not as light as others who were there, I have a good amount of muscle on me so it was a good workout!   Rock climbing is as tough as it looks.  But I am proud to say I made it all the way to the top of the boulder during my first day after my first 4 tries.  :)The gym inside is simple but they do have treadmills if you just want to do cardio.  I am definitely hooked and my goal is to start bouldering the more advanced routes and then top roping.  Be sure to bring chalk or borrow some from a buddy.  :)

Just wanted to give a shout out to Evan Pierce for providing a terrific private climbing lesson. Bouldering V2's were normally impossible or extremely challenging for me but after less than two weeks after his advice and technique tips I am climbing V2's like they are V0's. I recommend anyone who is interested in improving their climbing to take a lesson with him.

I am a huge fan of this place!!!! Planet Granite, is awesome! not only do they have one of the best customer service i have ever experienced, but they have so much activities to choose from! My friends and I decided, what the heck lets go rock climbing one day. I wasn't too quite sure if it would be fun, but whoa did my aspect of this rock climbing changed when I first tried it out. It LOOKS easy, but its very challenging. As a beginner i suggest you getting lessons or tip from fellow rock climbers, it really does help. If you get tired of rock climbing they do have a in door gym as well? WOW kill two birds with one stone kinda deal here. They have it all from tread mills to weights, and equipment that will help you become a better climber. But thats not all, what probably blew my mind was the bathroom..LOL! it is VERY VERY VERY clean in there and it looks cool too. haha. Only thing that bummed me out was this place closing at 11pm. But i will definitely be coming back here again!

This place rocks! haha ;) But seriously, this place is awesome. They have a huge amount of lead and top rope routes to climb at all sorts of difficulties. They also have a lot of bouldering routes with all sorts of variations. The workout facilities are well equipped and they offer cross-fit, yoga, and fitness classes. The lockers are always clean and the sauna is a nice plus. The staff is always friendly and willing to help. They also have a store with a decent amount of climbing gear. Definitely worth the monthly membership. Everyone is super friendly and welcoming. PG is a great place to climb, exercise, and meet cool people. Buy a day pass and see for yourself!

Mannnnn, If I can describe a perfect rock gym, this is defintely it! Unlike many rock gyms, What I love about this place is that they don't just focus on top rope and sport / lead climbing, but they have an extensive area for bouldering. They have many routes for all levels of difficulty. It's even spread out enough to not look like a clusterf*** of a wall. The abundant walls itself is fantastic by the pure complexion and geometry of it. They also have another bouldering section in the back that scales pretty high, but don't fret, the pads make you feel secure enough to not worry about falling flat on your back (Even if you need a spotter). BTW you will see some dudes that climb with their shirts off. I honestly don't mind, but if you're doing a freakin' v2 with your shirt off, please put it back on. Nobody wants to land in back sweat on the pads where you recently fell.Their gym is obviously not as big as a regular gym, but it gets the job done. They have cardio equipment, barbells, a full set of dumbells to improvise anything they don't have, and boards/bars to help improve your grip. They also have rubber bumper plates for explosive workouts like power cleans. There's climbing rope and rings that hang from the ceiling. Their locker room has a good amount of lockers, 4 showers and a sauna. Their showers have a mounted body wash, shampoo, and conditioner dispenser.Oh yeah, they have a freaking 1in slackline in the outside in the back. Really? Now they're just showing off..

** I came here on a Friday evening when there was a special Friction event, so I experienced Planet Granite on steroids. I haven't been climbing since Outdoor Ed in elementary school (so pretty much since never) and was curious to see what it'd be like over ten years later and a few feet taller. Since there was a special event the place was PACKED and a little intimidating with all the hoards of people standing around. But you know, I ain't no b__ch, so I put on my game face and carried on. It was a sweet deal because members can bring a friend for free on the first Friday of every month, so I only had to pay $6 to rent a harness and shoes! Regularly it's $19 just to drop in. I was impressed by how large the facility is and how many different colorful routes of varying difficulties you can take to reach the top. My friend and his climbing buddies taught me the basics of bouldering and then decided to throw me onto my first route even though I had no idea what I was doing, plus while looking at the wall I remembered that I'm afraid of heights. I made it to the top of the wall however, then realized they didn't explain how to GET BACK DOWN. It's a little difficult to trust the idea of letting go of the wall when you already have a fear of falling but the nice guy climbing right next to me was able to explain it. I noticed nearly everyone who climbs is more than willing to help a homie out which made the experience even better. Because there was an event going on that night I was able to watch a climbing competition, grab a slice of pizza, chop it up with some Red Bull girls, participate in a raffle, and get a free t-shirt. COME UPPP. Overall PG is like a giant playground for adults and kids alike. Tons of boys competing with each other and bouncing off the walls and falling everywhere on the cushy mats. Girls doing the same but less recklessly. Three routes later and a few attempts to boulder, my delicate fingers couldn't handle it anymore but I am now convinced that I need a membership in my life in the near future.
Fantastic gym!  Best rock wall and even unique activities like slack lining.  I have not utilized equipment or classes in recent years but they look fantastic.
Fyi this place smelled bad when you walked through the door.  And charges 16 bucks to just try it out.

This is definitely a top notch climbing (and other) gym.  If I lived or worked in the area I'd definitely become a member because I could use it as a climbing gym AND a weight gym AND practice some light gymnastics AND take yoga classes.  In fact the quality of the gym would anchor me toward living near here if I worked in this part of town.The weak point is certainly the top roping in that the roof is low and so the routes are short.  The bouldering more than makes up for it in my mind: the area is large, the routes are good and plenty, and the grading is fairly accurate.  I will say that it's kinda crowded and there are lots of kids...I like kids and encourage them to get in involved in climbing, but they are not the best people to have around when your bouldering because1) they tend not to follow the rules, 2) they are also noisy and undisciplined, and 3) they are usually better than me.

I know nothing about climbing but my 5-year-old is interested in it so I took a belay class with him. The class was great, the instructor was good with my son, gave me honest advice about classes and my son had a great time.Since then we've been back twice. My son had fun both times but the staff at the front desk is completely hit or miss. The guy at the front the first time we went was helpful and nice enough. The second guy was unfriendly, clearly annoyed at my confusion over the pricing (I used a coupon) and just generally unpleasant and made me feel like crap.The whole point of trying out different activities like this is to hopefully find something my son will enjoy for a long time, something separate from school that's fun and will build his confidence, so I'm not swearing off this place or anything since he still likes climbing, but I'm not going to be suggesting we come here, I'll wait for him to bring it up.

I am still annoyed about my visit here over 3 hours later!! I called to check whether this place was suitable for a 4 year old, and was told "absolutely - children of all ages are good to come here", so, off we went for our first try out for my son (my husband and I used to rock climb outside a lot...).Anyway, we arrived, I re-explained that my son had never been before, how I called in advance and was told right now was a good time. The girl told me that he could just climb any wall and I should stay with him and help him etc. So, $16 later, off we went. No special kids area, no help from any staff, and quite frankly, no room for any child for their first time.We managed to find one small spot for him to try, but it was way too advanced. He tried to reach a handhold, and couldn't do it. I helped, but to no avail. So, we walked around together looking for a spot for him to climb. I got told rather tersely by two climbers that we should be "careful". Really? Careful? I didn't let my son go out of my arms reach, and I am well aware that people are above and pointed it out several times to my son. So these childless people think we parents are so stupid we are going to risk our childrens lives and let them walk under people who could fall? There was no rhyme or reason for this "advice" from these people... they clearly could tell we were trying to scope everything out and they could actually have been helpful. But no, they just wanted to tell me something that was pretty obvious to any parent.Anyway, my son started to get super-upset. People were being mean and  unhelpful, there was nowhere for him to climb. it was too hard, etc etc. Not a great first experience for him and I was livid because I called to check in advance! If I had known it would be this bad, there is no way I would have put him through it.After persevering for another 10 minutes, the final straw came when a guy who was only 1 feet off the ground (he probably thought he was super manly and really high on the wall!!) yelled "give me some space". We would have needed to go outside to give him any more space because we were already about 6 feet away. It became obvious kids were NOT welcome here and the only support they had for children were the rental shoes...I would strongly recommend you save your money and take your child somewhere friendlier or go outside to learn climbing. We got no help anyway, so we would have been better off outdoors!!! I was so annoyed when I left, I ended up give the guy at the desk a long rant to let him know how upset I was and how they could have been more helpful on the phone and told me the gym was full of snobs!I'll never go here again. I hate this place. They've probably ruined my son from ever wanting to climb again.

My friend, who is a member, booked a free belay lesson for me and our other friend. To be honest, the idea of climbing up a wall and coming back down didn't seem that fun to me so good thing my friend was able to let me try it for free or else, I probably would never do it. Our instructor, Martin, was super patient. I was confused about looping the figure 8 and struggled to push myself off the wall but he was always helpful and encouraging. After our lesson, I found myself eager to climb up the walls and even challenge myself to a few of the high leveled ones. I have to come back to take a test (it's free btw) in order to climb on my own again. Bathroom/lockers/showers are really nice and clean. They also provide 2 working blow dryers in there. Apparently, they have group exercises classes as well. MAJOR PLUSES. Overall, it was a really good experience and PG does have a good deal for newbies but I already have a gym membership elsewhere. Oh well...

I attended this gym for 6 years and i wish they were closer to me now.  I loved it!  Not just for the rock climbing, but their yoga program is amazing.  I learned to belay and chataranga here under the watchful eyes of their knowledgable instructors and would highly recommend trying this place out to anyone.

This is my favourite gym. The pricing isn't bad. If you're a student or get to the gym early enough, the day rates are discounted. New climbers are always welcome, and if you're a beginner then you won't be for long. Everyone is willing to help you develop your skills.The environment is great. They are keen on energy conservation as evidenced by "be mindful of waste"-themed signs around the place, newly installed skylights, and an energy efficient outdoor bouldering area. The patrons are friendly and so is the staff. The events that they host are a blast and a great way to meet new people who share the same interest in climbing and fitness. A big plus is how clean everything is, which is a group effort participated in by the staff as well as the patrons. This gym is like a second home to me. It'd be foolish not to try it out.

Highly highly recommend, I've been to a few rock climbing gyms, but this is one of my favorites. I only went as a one-time-thing with a bunch of friends (great place for a group activity, by the way). Great variety of walls, the guys working the front are really helpful, and the gym in the back is very complete and has everything you need for a full workout. If I had to pay for gym membership (I do not because I'm a student), I would definitely get one here instead of  a more traditional gym like 24 Hour.I believe the place DOES do group lessons for belaying, but otherwise people are not allowed to teach others how to belay. This means that if you have climbed before but just need a quick refresher on how to belay before taking a belay test, you should either look it up before, or refer to the quick reference card that they have available. If you HAVE climbed before, the reference card should catch you up to speed well enough. If not, you should call and book a lesson or something. The guys running the belay tests are not super uptight though, and very good about recognizing when someone clearly knows what they're doing even if they don't' know the exact words.

My friends and I came here last week for the belay lesson and returned yesterday to get belay certificates. Kevin was our instructor during the lesson and he was absolutely amazing. I don't know how the teaching rotation works there but if you can get him then make sure you do! The whole process was easy and fun and I am now belay certified! Thanks Kevin! 4 for 4!There are many options for both bouldering and wall climbing and the place is kid friendly! I would recommend this place to anyone looking to start climbing. They have monthly and yearly deals for students so if you have a student ID come here and check it out. I love love loveee this place. I got the 5 days for $55 dollars but when I'm done with that I'll be returning for more. Everyone here was pretty nice. Staff is welcoming and easy to talk to/open for questions. They have beginner climbing classes I might go back for sometime. Definitely picked up a new hobby. Seriously, if you're looking to climb, come here! This place is awesome!

I've only recently discovered this wonderful place, and surprisingly to some perhaps, i don't go for the climbing! I go specifically for Jill's yoga class on thursday evenings. Last night's class was uh-mazing. I can't for the life of me remember what yesterday's practice was specifically called, but I loved it. The focus was to stabilize your breathing no matter the intensity of the move or position and to calm your mind. Despite being crammed into the room with 51 people, the extra 10-15 being new years resolution-ers, I got a) an awesome work out and b) actually was able to feel very still and calm after the 90 minute class ended.Today I am not at a shortage for soreness anywhere in my body...except my mind :). I will definitely continue taking this class and who knows, maybe someday I'll get over my fear of heights and climb a rock wall!

Awesome place!I was visiting California and had the urge to learn how to rock climb!  We headed over there around 4pm and found out that before we could climb, we would have to learn to belay first.  I just wanted to climb but took to the challenge of learning a new skill.  We set our appointment and came back at 7pm.Our instructor was very sweet and patient and taught us very well...the belay class was a little over an hour.  We spent the next hour or so using our new skills and climbing up the walls...They had bouldering too, which does not involve ropes and just climbing huge rocks...not something I wanted to do at the moment.  Some people here are seriously hard core.Loved every minute of this place!I like that it's also a gym.  So even though I am anti-gyms, this would be a viable option.  If you pay extra, you can do the yoga and weight lifting classes.  Love me some yoga...

The climbing is great. It's a lot of fun and challenging. Everything seems really well-maintained.I took the beginner class, and it was a lot of fun. I didn't learn much or significantly improve my climbing as a result of it, but I was exposed to all the concepts. It also comes with a month membership, which by itself pays for most of the class.The exercise equipment leaves much to be desired. There's a few treadmills and a few dumbells, and that's about it.The staff is totally cool and knowledgable, but fairly out of it.Something this gym desperately needs is a better way to match belay partners. They have singles nights once a month. Otherwise, they'll make an announcement over the PA, and you just have to cross your fingers. How hard is it to set up a mailing list? This place feels like an exclusive club. People come in with their friends and people there know each other. Some of them are snobby about climbing.

I've climbed in Nor Cal and in So Cal and this is still the best gym I've been too.  There's a lot of bouldering and top roping climbs there and the staff is usually super nice.  It's also got a lot of workout equipment so if you want to lift weights or do some cardio there's that option too.  I've never taken any of the classes, but my friends said they really like them.Prices aren't bad comparing it to other gyms and it's easy to get to and parking is easy as well.They also have fun events! :)  A great place for beginners.

I LOVE this place.  In a good week, I make it out here 4 or 5 times a week!  It's definitely my gym of choice, and I wish I lived closer.  Their hours are pretty good too, for those who work and need a place that stays open fairly late on weekdays.Yes, the initiation fee is kind of steep, but they do have membership sales about twice a year!  Also, ~$70/month is a great deal considering the variety of exercise options they provide.  You can climb, boulder (indoors and outside!), work out at their state of the art gym with the cardio and weight machines and free weights, or attend one of their yoga/core/spinning classes.  The layout is pretty awesome as well.  The high ceilings make for a very open feeling and there are garage-type doors throughout that can be opened or closed for ventilation.  The doors are great for warmer days when a few strategic gaps can create great circulating air flow! And there is enough space so you can watch other people climb and boulder without looking like a creeper.If you haven't checked it out, give it a shot.  Yes, it's an expensive one time visit, but you can also hit up your friends who have membership.  They have guest passes, and PG also hosts a Guest Night on the first Friday of each month when each member can bring a guest for free!

Every time I go on one of those eating trips, I have to find a way to burn the calories off. Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to lose weight (at least not on my vacation), I'm just trying to get hungry so I can eat more!!So, my cousins dragged me to planet granite in sunnyvale. I was excited to go rock climbing. The only problem was that they all signed up for a yoga class. I certainly couldn't climb without anyone belaying for me. So, I decided to try yoga for the first time. After 1 hour and 15 minutes, I realized I should have done yoga in some type of a tub. I was sweating like a pig! Wait I AM a pig, so I was just sweating like myself. This is one impressive gym. It has a class room inside for yoga, cardio stations and weight stations. It also has all kinds of rock climbing walls and boulders. I wish our gyms in NJ are half as nice. The prices are very reasonable. If you go in the morning, you can get in for 13 bucks. After spending over 5 hours in this place. I was sore from rock climbing for 1-2 days. I was extremely sore for yoga for the whole week. You know what that means? I signed up for yoga classes as soon as I got back to NJ.

We came here on a Sunday and it was packing full. The walls and boulders were decently high but because of the general small size there was no ways you could go bouldering or rope climbing at your own leisure. In addition you need to have a spotter for when you boulder which is unnecessary IMHO. We decided to go somewhere else. Maybe we will try it out during weekdays.

Huge, spacious gym tucked away in Sunnyvale filled with friendly, passionate, and fit people.  Besides the colossal climbing walls, there are treadmills, multiple bouldering areas, a large mat/mirror area with resistance balls for stretching, yoga classes, weights, and a sauna(!). Daily drop-in fee is $20 so $70/month membership for all those things above is really a fantastic deal!!Brownie points for dropping dubstep after 10pm.There's something incredibly metaphorically euphoric about rock climbing:Something about reaching beyond your limits with the security of someone there to "fall back" on, about transcending the challenge of the rock/hard place, defying gravity and defeating the rock obstacles in your path. And finishing on top. Tip (for all newcomers): Remember... a Carabiner is NOT someone from Jamaica!!

As someone that loves working out and loves his beautiful wife and kids, this is ideal.  We go to Planet Granite, my wife does Yoga, I belay the kids and work out and then she belays them while I finish working out.  AWESOME activity for all 4 of us.  Note the kids are 8 and 10 and not the type you would expect to be climbers, they are getting better every time we go.  There are all levels of climbers here, so you (yes even you) will fit right in.  People are nice and helpful and seem to encourage the "rookies."  Also very international, Europeans must climb a ton, you will hear French, German and Italian accents every time, (duh the Alps)The Gym side of the equation is under valued and awesome, cool stuff like climbing ropes, rings and such as well as regular free weights and treadmills. I have not seen the gym side crowded yet and they have the amazing CrossFit classes.For a family of four, it is a bargain, check on the monthly price, that works out best and encourages you to go early and often.

You get what you pay for.....and then some!  This place has the best indoor rock climbing and numerous yoga classes.  Sure the membership is pricey, but what you don't get are those trashy douchey douche bags that literally look like they live by the GTL lifestyle that swarm 24 Fitness.  Very nice and decent people who come to this gym (most of the time).  Most of them are here for the rock climbing although recently it has been extremely busy all the time for climbing and regular gym equipment.  Decent amount of gym equipment and machines that are always working and cleaned.  Parking lot is huge but it's been so busy you have to park all the way next to the front door of the building on the other side of the parking lot.  Also you have to deal with idiots who park in the fire lanes and no one can get by.

If you had told me five years ago that I would be toproping 50 foot high walls and bouldering rocks sans any sort of protective device I would have called you bats**t cray. I was deathly afraid of heights (and they still make me nervous), but I started rock climbing about 8 months ago and I haven't looked back since! I try to hit up PG 2-3 times a week if I can for a good climbing workout, but let me tell you -- it gets crowded with a capital "CROWDED" if you go during peak hours around 6-9 PM. Parking becomes pretty scarce and it might be difficult to even find problems that are open during some days. If you're lucky enough to be able to beat this rush or go early in the mornings (I recommend Saturday when it opens - you'll practically have the whole place to yourself!) then I say go work out then. PG also offers other things besides climbing. Good old stationary bikes, treadmills, stair steppers, rowing machines, weight machines and more sit alongside an open stretching area and a Crossfit area. There are also 2 rooms that offer classes such as yoga, cycling, abs and kickboxing. I've tried the Vinyasa flow and kickboxing classes and they KICKED. MY. BUTT. I was out of commission for a good week after taking those. Not for the faint of heart. Even my guy friends who took the kickboxing with me were completely annihilated by it haha. 4 stars for a great place to be and a whole lot of options for everyone! Bouldering in and of itself is a very social activity --it's very easy to bond while standing around waiting for other climbers to finish up problems. I've found that everyone I've met has been super friendly :) Had to subtract a star because of how ridiculously crowded it can be but I would still highly recommend the place.

A new kind of workout!  This was crazy fun... and fear inducing at first.  It was pretty packed on a Thursday night (and they were open until 11pm) but there were still enough ropes to go around, all at various levels.The best way to do this is probably to go to a class or with a friend who knows what she is doing... but it's easy to learn the basics and kind of addictive.

I am not a fan of climbing indoors, but having climbed for over 10 years, and being friends with tons of gym owners, I've been exposed to my share of climbing gyms around the country (probably 20 or so). Last month I found myself practically living in the Bay Area, with no outdoor climbing in sight. So when Gregg told me that I needed to climb at Planet Granite, I obliged. Gregg has owned and designed nearly all of the top 10 gyms in the country... so I knew he wouldn't steer me wrong, but when I walked into PG, I was just floored. I practically declared my undying love right on the spot without having climbed a single route. For starters, the wall height is one of the great distinguishing features. The only other gym I've ever been in that even comes close is Carabiners in Massachusetts. The gym was apparently designed from the ground up and features abundant space for hundreds of routes (although on a crowded weeknight, you definitely get traffic jams on every convergence point on the walls). The ratings are sugar-bagged and nearly all holds below 10D's are super juggy, but who couldn't use a little encouragement? And there are yoga classes, a full gym and outdoor bouldering - seriously?? Beat that Boston, Seattle, San Diego, Austin, Houston and Philly! I'm sooo in love it's not even funny - but not enough to want to move to the Bay (much to the chagrin of my employer) - outdoor climbing will always be better in So. Cal. and I wouldn't trade that for a thousand Planet Granites. Still... mad props to the PG!
I highly recommend the Beginners Rock Climbing class (BRC) if you're new to climbing. Less busy on weekends and in the mornings during the week.

Came here for a Groupon which included the belay lesson and climbing for the day.  The facility seems well maintained and has a great atmosphere with supportive, experienced staff and patrons.  Lots of areas for climbing and bouldering at all levels!It's pretty scary for a first-time climber.  You spend all that time staying close to the wall and finally get to the top, then they want you to repel from the wall??? WHAT THE HECK!  Nah, just kidding, it's cool. :)  Thank goodness I have a climbing partner I can trust!

Such an awesome deal, especially if you have a family membership. $50 a month for unlimited use of a huge gym, yoga classes, and rock climbing walls? Yes please!Each time I've come in has given me a hard dose of reality of how out of shape I am :(. The people here are ridiculously cut...unlike me. I am determined to look like a regular!

***BEST YOGA IN SILICON VALLEY***This isn't just a climbing gym (although they have a fantastic one!).  The classes are designed for climbers so they are very core-focused which I love.  Yoga mixed with a little pilates!  What a concept!  The class times are SO convenient and work very well with my schedule, which has always been a challenge with other gyms.  The instructors are great- are very dedicated to making sure your form is correct and that have a successful class.  My favorites are Vinyasa Flow with Joanie on Monday night and Vinyasa/Yin with Lorraine on Thursday.  (And FYI, if you're not a memeber, their drop-in fees are noticeably less expensive than most other studios in the area!!).

I love this place. A friend introduced me to indoor climbing and to Planet Granite. I've been in love ever since. I also started taking Yoga classes as well. I love it!! I definitely recommend it for anybody who wants to work out at a great environment.

Mathis a really nice climbing gym, the walls are really high, they have slack rope outside, and a bouldering wall. Also they have a bunch of exercise machines (they need to get one of the six running machines fixed), weights, and a studio room. It's really nice how open the gym feels.

This place is awesome! Staff is super friendly and helpful; as a member have the option of rock climbing, cross fit, yoga, weight lifting/cardio and more. I also like the friendly community that this place attracts.

My fortune cookie suggested that I try a new sport and incidentally, a friend invited me to go to Planet Granite so I took it as a sign.  This is just the coolest place on earth.  I used to go wall climbing a lot when I was much younger but since I moved to the US 11 years ago, I haven't really done it.   My love for climbing just got rekindled.  I went for my belay class which was supposed to be an hour class but it got extended to 2 hours.  Our instructor was very thorough and I really learned a lot.  We also did a practice climb during that time.   The class was $34 which also included a whole day of climbing, rental of shoes & harness and the use of the gym.  Totally value for money!Now, I am seriously contemplating getting a membership at the gym itself.  It's only $55/month - cheaper than ClubOne - plus the added bonus of indoor wall climbing.  The only reason why i am hesitant is because I live in South San Jose and also, I need a friend who can commit to doing it with me regularly - obviously.  But then again, the day pass is $18 (which I think is pretty steep)!If you are looking for a serious work-out that will guarantee building your upper body strength, wall climbing is it!  I have very strong legs (runner's legs) and it helps a lot to build an equally strong upper body as well.  The walls are as challenging as you want them to be.  One of these days, I'm gonna try bouldering but for right now, I will focus on wall climbing.  By the way, the front office staff are very nice too - they know everything!.  Currently, they have a $130 packaged price if you buy the harness, shoes and chalk package.  I may just as well do that considering that I really enjoy doing it.   God, please give me a partner please:))

The belay class for beginners are thorough, detailed and affordable (under $40).The place is grand and the graded terrains varies from easy to advance.  If you are planning to climb regularly I suggest a monthly membership, which includes the gym coverage. It's really a good form of exercise but you do need a partner for belaying.However, it's not my favorite place because of poor ventilation so it smells horrible and secondly the gym section is pretty small with outdated machines.

This is a pretty nice location and is my main gym. The gym itself is pretty nice. They've upgraded the crash pads from actual crash pads to an entire floor of softness. My problem with this place is that it is run over with engineers who think they're the shit. They don't follow climbing etiquette, and are really only interested in impressing the girls.

Every couple of months or so I have the need to climb. I'm grateful that one of my friends is a good climber, so I always ask her to accompany me to Planet Granite. I usually like coming here around 10-11am on a weekday because there aren't that many people compared to the evenings (it can get really busy). I usually stick to the v0/1 routes, but some of them are situated for taller people (which is totally fine). My friend and I probably climb for about 2-3 hours, with breaks in between. I run for about 20 minutes afterwards, and she goes and attempts to walk the slack line in the back. This place is family friendly and a great place to try something different.TIP: They offer discounts for students!

Yoga, rock climbing, crossfit, cardio and weight machines.  The monthly rate is extremely reasonable as well as the initial fee.  The patrons are lean and fit and have bodies that look in balance, not all beef caked out.

When I moved from the East Bay to the South Bay I was worried that there might not be a place to go rock climbing. I never felt so glad to be wrong. Planet Granite has two great rock climbing gyms in the South Bay - Sunnyvale and Belmont. Sunnyvale being the larger sibling. Planet Granite makes climbing easy. My first concern was finding a partner to top rope with who might work the odd hours that I do. That's when I saw an advertisement for climbfind.com. It's so easy to post and find someone. I know I did! My previous gym only provided a sign up sheet where I had to call lots of numbers and ask for hours, which was a lot less convenient. I'm really impressed with the arrangement of the gym and the frequency that they change routes. There's always enough to climb and they usually leave it up long enough for me to re-attempt a route if I don't get it right the first day. This gym also turned me on to bouldering, which I was previously not a fan of but the routes look way too fun to pass up! As Yelp says, Planet Granite is "as good as it gets!"

Spacious rock climbing space, but very pricey...I have membership here and I haven't made the most of it yet. However, I enjoy going here for the gym because:1. I have the option to rock climb if I ever feel like it.2. The community here is great! Everyone is very friendly.3. There's a sauna! Isn't that awesome???4. I didn't realize that not all gyms have this, but they provide towels for you to use too!5. I shouldn't publicize this, but it's something I enjoy... Going here during the daytime on the weekday, it's empty! That means less smelly!So, I can see myself coming here more often. Definitely try rock climbing if you haven't--it's fun!

I can't believe I've been doing yoga here for over a year and I never wrote a review! This space is awesome. You can boulder or top rope, or do yoga, or run on a treadmill, or take a ridiculous spinning class, or lift weights, or take a ridiculous weight lifting class. There's a good size locker room with a sauna and showers with a fresh supply of towels at all times. And since day passes are like $20 it's sort of worth the monthly $70. You can also get a discounted beginner's package for climbing gear when you're a member.I never got super into the climbing, but I did take the belay class and got certified. The class was very informative and taught me the basics I needed to know to belay others. I have two gym memberships, one at work which has state-of-the-art machines, and the other here mainly for doing yoga (machines here are sorta much older). Yoga classes here are great (and therefore the 5 stars). Jill and Eric are both fabulous instructors.If you happen to have a friend with a membership, bug them to take you one day as their buddy! They have one freebie a month and it's a good way to check out the space.

The best & most motivating gym I have been to yet- & this is after trying several bootcamps and fitness programs! This gym is so versatile and unique it always keeps me coming back . They have your standard cardio & weight machines, free weights, Crossfit equipment, balance boards, yoga, fitness classes (kickboxing, pilates, spinning), & of course- rock climbing! I have literally spent all day here & not done everything I wanted to. Always something fit & fun to do, and something for everyone!The cons: it's an older facility, so it does smell like sweat & gym socks. Yes, I realize it is a gym. But still, you will always get that wave of scent crashing over you when you enter the door. However, once you are in you become one with the place so you no longer notice. In the summer they open the warehouse doors so it helps with the circulation, but otherwise... be warned! It is one of the most expensive gyms around, but it's still cheaper than a bootcamp subscription & it does have many inclusive options so I think it is worth it. However, even with the membership fee paid you will still be paying additional to rent climbing gear if you don't have your own. If you come here regularly I recommend investing in your own harness & shoes. The rental shoes are um, moist sometimes & the cheap harnesses cut into places a lady doth never be cut into. This place is also so awesome that it gets packed on certain weeknights so you have to wait for machines or climbing routes. Lastly, I wish they would have more fitness class options that you'd see at 24 fitness, like U-Jam & Zumba.With all that, it is still my favorite gym in the area & the only one that has kept me coming back on a regular schedule, even at 6am, on my lunch break, and after work!  Check out the San Francisco location also. It is smaller, but is in a beautiful location by Crissy Field!

I went here yesterday with a friend to try out their Yoga class with Annika.  I had a very good first experience yoga-ing.  It was a lot more rigorous than what I expected!  We would hold poses for a long time, working out almost every inch of our bodies!  Annika was a very good instructor and she would often come by and correct my movements and position.  The total duration of the class that I took was an hour and half, called the vinyasa flow.  I recommend this class for people who want an intense and challenging work out!  It's definitely a stress reliever after a hard day of work! =D

I'm used to Mission Cliffs where it gets so packed, I have to wait for routes which gives me time to rest between climbs.  PG was nowhere near as crowded so we were on an accelerated climbing schedule and after several months of only cardio or laziness, it was challenging and humbling.Still, it was a great place to climb, maybe a better place to boulder.  You don't need your own caribiner or belay device since you have no choice but to use the ones already placed on each rope.  It's convenient but also a little nerve wracking.  The cardio equipment and weight areas were fairly spacious and they also offer several classes.  The locker room was surprisingly large and clean.  Since it's close to my office and the facility is great, I can't complain about it but I kind of miss the grunginess of MC.
Great place to go climbing. Very challenging routes that get changed almost every month. Gets too crowded at times but other than that it was awesome!

I'll get to the point: the parent/child belay class could be a little shorter, especially with young kids in the class. The climbing part was fun enough, but on the weekend there are a lot of people with kids on the easy wall, so it's not the best time to climb at all. The secret cave running under that wall is a hit, so plusses to PG for putting that in. For families with the under four set, I can barely recommend PG. Kids who love to climb can try bouldering on the easy verticals, but there are zero options for toddlers and crawlies who could really benefit from just climbing over hills and ramps in a toddlerspace or dedicated tiny climbers space. Go to another place, you say. Well, the idea is to do a whole family outing here. PG is a much better place for those families with kids 4-5+ who are independent climbers and players. Also, this place is BUSY on rainy days. Be prepared to wait if there are lots of kids climbing in one area. The gym smell is also really noticeable. No lockers, only cubbies. The gym doesn't seem to be heated, so on cold, rainy days, be prepared to dress warmly.

After being a member for a number of months now, I felt the need to update my review of PG. Needless to say, like fine wine, PG has become better with time. I find myself going climbing nearly 3x a week and meeting new people and getting to know the staff a little bit better.The events that they host like free guess fridays, competitions, or lights-out for halloween makes the PG community feel like a family. Everyone who comes out to climb or workout are here in good spirits. One thing that PG does consistently well is to always be updating the routes that they set. This I can be thankful for since it gives me new projects to work on!

Pretty Expensive for my tatse... Once you become a member you also have to pay for gear (to rent or buy) and even to borrow a yoga mat it costs $1 per time. Just seems like they find creative ways to make extra money. The staff is iffy at best. Most of the time they seem to either be in a really bad mood or act like they know everything. Yea, I know they know about rock climbing but that doesnt mean they need to act like it and be rude. The fitness instructors are wonderful I must say. Front desk could really learn a lot from them on positive attitudes and customer service. The facility itself is nice. At rush hour it tends to smell weird but other then that it's cool. I like that they have a gym and yoga in house though, makes me feel like I'm getting what my membership pays for.

"There's a nice set of jugs you'll have to bump off of before you go into a layback, to transition to a fist jam in this really nice crack. And trust your rubber with the smear at the end." Such is the advice (beta) I might be offering to a fellow climber here at the wonderful world of Planet Granite.  So yes, if you would like to join in on similiar conversations with other half naked or scantily clad climbing compatriots about cracks, nuts, rubbers, racks, sloppy holds, jugs, finger jams, fist jams, foot jams, bumping, smearing, sticking it, slapping holds, strapping into harnesses, etc., come on down... or at least come and find me and we can have a wonderful wee chat about the colorful terminology we use to communicate with one another here at this planet of faux granite.  The Planet Granite family of climbers seems to be growing quite steadily since the old days at the former Santa Clara location, so it can be quite crowded and busy during peak climbing times in the evening.  But for the most part, the other fellow climbers tend to be friendly folk, so it's a genuine pleasure for me to get my climbs in here several times a week.  I also love the fact that yoga classes are included in the membership.  Score!  If you can wait until Jan. to sign up for a membership, they usually waive the membership fee for all the New Year Resolutionistas.  Also, if you have a friend that's a member, ask them to hook you up with a free belay lesson if you're new to the sport.  Come on thru and git yo climb on!

As soon as I got my latest cholesterol reading, I bit the bullet and finally joined PG after dabbling here and there. Sure there is weight equipment, a spinning room, and yoga, but just about everyone is here to climb. Weekdays are really busy. Tues and Thurs are days favored by those that like to climb outdoors on the weekend. The real hardcore 0 body fat types. Our group usually climbs on Wed just cos it breaks up the week.  The outdoor climbing is still not open apparently because the City of Sunnyale hasn't approved the safety features yet. When it does, it will be awesome tho, because none of the climbing gyms in the bay area have an outdoor climbing area. My only complaint is that the rock surface is new and subsequently still really gritty. I constantly get scraped up after a climb. Some friends of mine came across an owl when they reached the top.  It would be nice if they served beer.

Overcrowding is a problem here. The evenings are esp. bad. Either you want to get here early or show up really late. Another complaint I have is the grigris tend to stick to the ropes (either that or some ropes are just sticky). I favor the ATC over grigris though the autolocking is a nice safety feature.Other than those, it's a great facility. Good gym and a number of trendmills to keep you busy when you are not picking at fake plastic rocks.

I initially thought this place was a bit expensive and help off on joining for a while but eventually gave in since I cold take yoga, work out and rock climbing all in one location. I later looked into other climbing gyms and they did not offer nearly the selection or the price for what I got at PG. Additionally the yoga instructors were top of the line and the abs workout kicked my butt... the rock climbing was pretty awesome as well. One criticism I have is that there is a rush hour during the after work week day hours particularly towards the end of the week best to avoid would be nice if they managed that better.

Wow.. this place was so cool!  I have coworkers that are super into rock climbing weather indoor or outdoor and they come here every week- its their gym!  They invited me to come and was nice enough to let me use their accrued guest pass so I can do some climbing for free!Went on a Tuesday night at 8pm and it was packed!   Its pretty overwhelming walking in and seeing all the high high climbing walls and people everywhere.  I can see how this can be addicting for sure. Its also a gym so there are machines, free weights, and I hear good yoga classes as well. So with the free pass all I had to do was rent climbing shoes and a harness so that put me back a whopping 6 bucks! Awesome!I learned so much about climbing with all the terminology being thrown at me.  I did some bouldering which I thought was way hard and maybe ascended once on the V0 level. The boulder problems are pretty hard!  When you're up there the stickers should be more prominent!I enjoyed the roping a lot more.  Like I mentioned I had two experienced rock climbers with me so they belayed for me but I want to become certified soon as well.   Even though the wall is super high I felt totally safe with the harness on.  I started on the 5'3 level and went as high at 5'8 which apparently is good! It was hard though and I felt out of breath a fourth way up.  I have no upper body strength and find my arms still sore even though I went two days ago. This place is sick though and makes me curious about how much it is to come on a semi-regular basis. I guess I'll have to find out.. the guest passed done worked on me!
Love this place, lots of gym equipment as well as rocks to climb. large bouldering area. this gym also has yoga and crossfit.

I LOVE this rock gym!Very fun atmosphere and musicPrices are fair and if you are a student you get a discount. There are Beginning, Intermediate and Advanced routes for top roping and leading. The gym is pretty large which makes for lots of fun routes.Lots of bouldering, a fun little workout area, and outside benches for lunch if you want to climb for hours on the weekend.They use grigris which make it easier for beginners to belay.Classes are at a fair price if for those who want to take them.

Me being a first timer with a bunch of OG climbers, I must say, I had a grand time even though my tendons on my forearm were about to snap off any minute...They close pretty late so we started at 9pm-11pm. I had to rent a harness, shoes, and pay for a day fee and it was around $33. For a warm up I did a 5.3 climb and my arms were shaking but I made it to the top. After another 3 more climbs, I was ready for the long 5.7 climb. That was soooo strenuous but so satisfying. I think that levels they make are on point and this place is good for the avid climber and even the newbies.

Take a break from free weights & treadmills and get your workout on at Planet Granite. You will soon realize how sore muscles you never knew existed can get. Rock climbing and bouldering challenge you mentally and physically, but it is a blast trying to puzzle through the best route in getting to the top. They offer the gear (harness, shoes, etc.) for rent if you are not ready to make the investment and just want to try it out. Remember that for rock climbing you need a second person to "belay" you, while bouldering can be done solo.Planet Granite has plenty of routes that accommodate the beginner and intermediate/expert alike. Also, if you need a break from climbing they have a pretty extensive "traditional" workout area (treadmills, weights, etc.) and climbing specific training equipment.My favorite thing about this place beyond the solid facilities and exceptionally friendly staff, is that they have bouldering outside! Also, if you really want to humble yourself, try their slack line (basically wire walking three feet off the ground). It is way more difficult than you would imagine.

Good Place. If you are new to climbing, they are most obliging in providing you ways to find a partner. I give it "only" 4 stars because I wish they had more diversity in the type of bouldering. Also, the rating system seems a little easier then east coast gyms. But overall, it is a fun place.

Came here for a belay lesson.  Bought the 5 visit for $55 package.  Peeps that worked here were engaging and friendly, respectful and competent.  I went on a Sunday, so it wasn't that crowded, the doors were open to let in a nice breeze.   The rock walls were so high!  And people were climbing all over them!  Planet Granite is a jungle gym for adults.  LOVE IT!  Will update after trying the yoga and Crossfit, and more bouldering.

This review is strictly toward the staff. I have never been treated so rudely by an employee of an establishment that wanted my business. I walked in with my Boyfriend about a week ago and the guy at the front desk looks my bf up and down and starts off by asking us condescending questions. Since we had never been there before its safe to say we needed a minute to understand the choices, this guy, instead of helping us just continued to make condescending  comments. I'll be calling the manager. If your looking for friendly service go somewhere else.
Great equipment, great staff- helpful and friendly. Never been climbing ever, and they had me and my partner feeling like a pro in about half an hour.
This place has great bouldering with a wide range of problems but there are no auto-belays on the walls and it's is definitely overpriced.

The craziest thing about PG Sunnyvale?  It's really empty during the weekend!  I guess all the crazy climbers that come every single weekday afternoon take it outside to climb real rocks while I adoringly look at my pink plastic ones. I started out with a beginner's month course with Mike, who was totally awesome.  Despite him being a lot younger than me, he was a really good teacher.  It was a perfect combination of push and praise. I should know.  I'm a teacher.  After my course, I was hooked!The weekdays are pretty busy, and you'll have to wait around often.  But! It's big, it has a mini gym, and they have yoga!  I don't really use the gym section that much since it's mostly comprised of super built athletic people that seem to be running leisurely at 6 miles per hour, but I like having the option.

I think it's weird when people rate a place with a lower amount if stars because its crowded. It's popular- what do you want them to do? This is the only place I can truly lose all thought and focus on the task at hand. What fun! Climbing is so awesome that it doesn't even feel like exercise but it is. Truly worth the price of a membership if you take advantage of it. Lots of routes. Towels for the gym and whatever else. It would be awesome if you got a guest pass every month with your membership instead of just every other month but what are you gonna do? I love this place! It seriously makes me very happy! And I've also met some cool folks here. Climbing to me is something I can do the rest of my life. And it's so fun to take someone new there and see how they handle it. An awesome challenge this climbing!

This is the smallest of the three locations. I like coming here because it's closer than the SF one if I want a change of scenery. I also like the contours of the walls here, so I look forward to the new challenge of coming here. My favorite is still the Sunnyvale location though!

The manager reached out to us after this incident apologizing and offering us a day pass. He told us this wasn't how his staff should have been and that they pride themselves in customer service. My boyfriend and I came in again on Tuesday to see if things have changed, and it has! We were helped by Eliot but since he was busy training, he passed us off to Nick. Both of them were so friendly and welcoming! We could tell that they really cared about us and wanted us to feel comfortable. They made the experience worthwhile because we enjoyed ourselves that day. Thanks guys! I really appreciate you reaching out to us and showing us how much you value your guests.

On a whim one day, I decided to sign up for Planet Granite's beginner rock climbing class. What I didn't realize was that I was going to fall in love with a sport that would take over a majority of my spare time and get me into the best shape I've ever been in (and I'm only getting stronger and more confident every day!).The staff are amazing. They're great people to talk to, and they're always willing to give you advice on the best outdoor climbing spots, the beta that worked for them on a certain climb, or they're just there to encourage you as you improve and struggle through climb after climb.The regulars are some of the greatest people I've ever met. The more often you go, the more you really feel like a rock climbing family. I spend more time with my rock climbing buddies than I do with my best friends I've grown up with. They managed to take a sport that I already loved, and make it even better, to the point where I look forward to going all the time.Plus, having a membership there means I get to take advantage of their extensive bouldering areas, tons of top-roping, gym equipment, dry saunas in the locker rooms (ooooh yeah...), yoga classes, and all the exercise classes you can take with their personal trainer Zeus (such as the painful yet rewarding 30 minute abbs-workout class).The only down side I can think of is that at night during the week it can get pretty crowded because everyone gets off work and flocks straight to the gym. Also, if you go climbing too many days in a row, you're guaranteed to hurt something, so be sure to take days off during the week (obviously that's not the gym's fault, just the sport's).

The rock climbing venue and the service here was great. I used my friend's pass to get one free belay lesson along with a day for free so that was incredible. I can see why people are in love with this place as the challenges are unlimited. They do have a small gym there as well in case if your muscles aren't sore from climbing alone. Only downside to this place is the bathroom smells like complete feet. I know it is a gym but for crying out loud, have a febreeze fan rolling in there or something. It is unbearable.

I've been climbing here for over a year now!I love the routes and the setters are all pretty good. My friend and I know which setters focus more on technique, focus more on strength or are just awkward climbs. Sometimes I feel like their ratings are a bit off.. but maybe that's just I'm stronger in certain areas and weaker in other areas. When you come, send out nerd alert... a lot of the members here are engineers since it is located in the heart of silicon valley. This is my favorite indoor rock climbing gym in the bay. I'm so glad I work near here! I'm hooked!

This place is awesome!  My friends and I took the class, and it was totally worth it.  They teach you the basics (how to do the knots, belaying, and safety precautions).  After the lesson, you can climb for the rest of the day.  You also have the option to buy a card good for 5 day passes for $50.  This is a good deal because a day pass is usually $18!  You gotta use it within 2 months though.I've already used 4 of the 5 days, and I can definitely see the improvement.  The courses range from 5-2 (easiest) to 5-12 (crazy hard).  I was able to do a 5-9 course last night thanks to the encouragement of my friends!  They also have areas for bouldering.  I've tried it a few times, but it's pretty scary to climb without a harness.   I really enjoy rock climbing at Planet Granite!  To me, it's like solving a puzzle and getting a good workout at the same time!

After graduating I really needed to find a place to work out, and my friend brought me here to try out the walls.  To be honest, I usually dread having to work a workout into my schedule, but I joined after visiting a few times and find myself looking forward to the next time I can get climbing.  The staff is great, and though the place is almost always busy, I love the friendly environment and how supportive all the climbers are of each other!  I'm really looking forward to trying out the fitness classes and continuing a workout in the gym area.

Super amazing place. Wish I could have remained a member and continued with the F10 fitness classes. I received excellent service when I had to cancel my membership from Gus. He was so helpful and prompt. I'll miss you PG!!!!

I have climbed in many gyms around the world, and despite I found this one in San Jose, big and with very friendly staff, I have a few comments on the bouldering problems and the top ropes.1.-When it comes to top ropes, I'm use to see two points of support. Normally a good anchor with two bolts, two chains, and two carabiners (opposed), but here, there was a big "hook". Probably this "hook" is super safe, but it's a ONE point of failure. To protect my life I want the safest piece of equipment, and I want to be as close as to 100% safe as possible, which brings me to the second point here.2.-The top rope "hook" was opened, in the sense that a weird movement on the rope may get it out of the hook. Maybe I saw it wrong (hope so), and probably the kind of weird movement of the rope is very improbable, but even if this is adding just a 1% down in my safety, I will rather have something better.3.-Having been around the globe, I found quite weird that they force you to use the Grigri when belaying... There's a lot bunch of people that doesn't use grigri, even when probably they provide better security, but this is something that many people find debatable.4.-When it comes to bouldering, most of the problems lacked the "puzzle" part of bouldering, meaning that the "how to solve them" was quite obvious, but the level was set by the strength needed to climb that problem. I have to admit I found a couple of puzzle ones, very funny to climb, but most of them were about power and finger strength, specially finger strength.I will definitely try another climbing gym next time I'm in San Jose, and if I would live here I probably will come again, but this gym is no where close to my top ten places to climb indoor.

I work out here more often than climb.  Although the climbing facility is awesome! Don't get me wrong, if you want to get a membership to climb anywhere, it's gonna have to be Planet Granite facilities.  There are tons of different paths and a boulder section.  There are hours with lots of people towards the evenings when people get off work, so expect quite a few folks.  The GYM facilities and yoga are legit.  Lots of machines, lots of ways to work out, and it's even got a Cross Fit group working in the back.  Not bad at all P.G.  Even the Instructors are welcoming and pretty good at what they do.The front desk STAFF has a mix of friendly people, to a few cocky ones.   It's a hit or miss if they will answer your questions in a helpful way, rather than the obvious 'yes-no'.  It's easier to pay and then ask a fellow climber, everyone is pretty chill.Overall, if you like climbing or working out.  It's worth it.  (Bring a friend)

PG Sunnyvale is BIG--there's an insane amount of boulder problems, top roping routes, lead climbing, and even crack climbing!  There's also an outdoor bouldering wall, which is great when it gets stuffy indoors. Their setting has a lot of flow, and is generally pretty consistent (quality and grade wise).  The only gripes I have are that there aren't any topouts, and that there are some problems with silly last moves (usually a big/reachy/dynamic one to the lip), which kills the vibe and flow of what would have been a good problem.  But there aren't too many of those, so I can live with that.The staff here are super friendly, and there's also a full gym, with yoga and Crossfit available.  I haven't done any of that stuff yet, so I can't comment on them, but there seem to be a lot of satisfied participants.  Besides the above, the only other thing is that I wish there prices weren't so steep.  I think $70/month is a bit much, compared to other fitness and climbing gyms.  But I go so much that I get my money's worth anyways.  Overall a good gym, and one that I'm proud to be a member of.

For my 2010 new year's resolution, I decided to try new things and be more active.. and boy did rock climbing fulfill that for me yesterday! My forearms are quite sore from the climb!My friends and I decided to start rock climbing.  If you are a newbie, I recommend you to call in for reservations for belay lessons to get certified, especially on the weekends.  The lesson is $34 includes lesson, gear, and day pass!  They only put 4 people in one lesson at certain times so check their websites for times! My instructor was named Karen and she was the most supportive instructor.  She was funny and made sure that we knew the information repeatedly in order for us to pass our belay test the next time we came in.  The class was for 1 hour.  They gave us vouchers as a "gift" at the end of our belay test.  I ended up getting a 5 visit pass at a discounted price. $10 each visit since the pass cost $50 if you think about it.  I was going to see how much I like it before getting any membership.  Staff there are the friendliest ever!Weekdays are open until 11pmSundays are open until 6pmSunday was definitely overpacked.   I was really surprised at how much people come in, especially on a rainy day!  There was actually a line coming out of the door at some point! PG has a variety of services to offer so you won't get bored.  There's a gym also on the right side of the building, which comes fully equipped!  Bouldering at the front of the building, and of course the wide variety of difficulty in rock climbing all around.  It comes in different heights all around.  I loved it!I can't wait until I go and pass my belay test tomorrow night!!!

very cool place, all different levels are available!  i  just got my first belay training and now able to climb as a beginner!  it's full of people, old and young, professional and amateur, hardcore and easy going.. my friends and me had a lot of fun! the only thing i would suggest to get prepared is the odor inside is not nice , coz so many shoes were taken off.... hope you will not be too sensitive!! :P

Heidi no longer teaches yoga here :( and the Tuesday 7:30pm Vinyasa class has been replaced by Power Yoga. The outside bouldering area has been redone and it's  now enclosed.The towels still suck.Partner's yoga with Doris on the first Friday of each month is awesome! I practice yoga regularly and my husband doesn't, so for me, I don't go for a workout, I go to connect with the hubby.Bring your significant other and be prepared to get all touchy feely. Oh, and as part of the warm-up, we usually do a balancing/group effort exercise of getting in a circle, one person behind another and then attempting to sit. Yes, it's intimate and yes you'll sit on another person's lap. You can come alone and get partnered with someone else, but be prepared to get all up on that person...it's just that type of yoga.

I just joined this gym recently, after having taken the Beginners Rock Climbing classes.  I'll have to update later as I get more use out of this place, but so far, we've enjoyed it.  I would highly recommend the BRC for newbies like myself, as you get some really helpful pointers on how to climb.  As noted by other reviewers, the staff really aren't there to help you climb, or even out on the floor much to check on things (safety, etiquette, etc), so for my husband and myself, taking the class was almost a must-do (and a good way for PG to make more money, that's for sure!).My biggest complaint, of course, would be the super crowded-ness during weekday evenings.  It's almost impossible to find a route to climb and makes it totally inefficient for getting in and out in less than 2 hours.  We've pretty much given up on weekday climbing because of the situation.  The weekends are great, though.I haven't taken many of the classes yet, although I am anxious to as soon as I get some time....Melissa's Total Body Fitness class is pretty good (based on one class).  I was not  impressed with Eric's Power class--I'm not sure if it was because of my expectations or the class itself; I was expecting a more flow-based power vinyasa style, and what I got was a very disjointed series of poses with lots of awkward rests and transitions that was neither a good workout nor a good stretch.

Love this place!Except after 8 Fri/Sat/Sun.  Gets SO busy! This place is huge with a great selection of climbs, although lately they've been heavy on the 5.11's.  I don't do the bouldering, but they just opened up what used to be their outdoor area as another bouldering section.  They even had free bouldering tip classes going on while we were climbing. Maybe when I get better I'll venture over there, but having no rope is a bit scary to me.It's really the only place around to climb, unless you want to head to S.F. which is too far of a drive from San Jose just to climb. So, show up early and you'll never have to wait for a rope.  You can even get a partner once you get there.Prices are pretty good, the membership is probably the best for your money.  Negative: Some of the guys climb without their shirts, and sadly they aren't very appealing to look at...

Definitely a great place!  It's Gigantic compared to other rock climbing gyms I've gone to!!  Lots of wall space to climb, with ropes already set up ready to go.  There's also a fairly large area for bouldering.I took the intro to belaying class here for $34 (i'm out of touch with climbing).  The class fills up (they have them every hour), so make reservations in advance especially for weekends.  Weekend mornings are best, it starts to get really crowded in the afternoon.  Plenty of parking space at this location too.They also have treadmills and weights, but it's mostly a climbing gym.  They also have a store for gear and gear rentals.

I love this place! It is the only gym I have ever found that I never want to leave. My fiancé has to shove me out the door every time so I can get to bed at a decent hour. They have so many different climbs that no matter how busy they get, you can always find an available one to do.

My boyfriend and I enjoy coming here.
