There's a lot of climbing space and fun people to meet.We've ran into a couple "rude" people working at Planet Granite, which is why I can't give them 5 stars.  They didn't seem like they wanted to be there, and were not very patient.However, we had our belay lessons with Ngan and she was really fun to learn from. She's funny and very thorough.

This is, in my opinion, the best place to do CrossFit.  Whereas most places only allow you to work out during class hours, Planet Granite has a gym that is available during all working hours.The hours themselves are good but not great.  The price, while steeper than most gyms, is well worth it to the enthusiast but will be a little steep for those who only work out 3 - 4 times per week.

We had our kids' birthday parties here. It was so much fun even for kids who have never climbed. The instructors were fantastic at both parties. They were energetic, patient, encouraging and a lot of fun for the kids. They don't have a place for birthday cake (a bit of a bummer) but there is a park about a quarter mile down the street where we brought the kids for pizza and cupcakes and some more play outside. There is even a water sprayer for those very hot days.

Ok. I'm in love. I was skeptical of a gym that charges you $70 per month for a membership. It sounds ridiculous. However, if you are in it for the climbing this is the way to go. If you go just 3 times in one month you will be saving money! The routes are great and change pretty often. There is nothing better than conquering that route that's been bugging you and then coming in again and finding a brand new challenge. When you are done climbing there is still a full gym with classes, sauna etc. As far as I know walk-ins are welcome for classes (once you are a member) and the membership is month to month. Signing up in January is the way to go because they waive the sign up fee. I haven't even mentioned how awesome the staff is. Knowledgeable guys that are super friendly. My friend fell from bouldering and hurt her ankle. They were immediately there with ice and support. Since she's all healed they always remember to ask her how her ankle is and strike up a convo with us with a certain amount of ease. Its very nice. I can't see the point of going somewhere else and doing the boring gym thing again. PG is the way to go. Try to go on weekdays before 5 and you will have the place to yourself. First fridays of the month are "free guest" days for members so its quite crowded, but still worth going!

if you have never climbed indoors, you will probably love this place.  if you do not have experience climbing intelligent/thoughful/challenging routes, you will probably love this place.  if you are going for fitness/yoga exclusively and you do not need to use the locker rooms, again, you will probably love it.  but, if you are not a complete novice/clueless techie who has never been backcountry or has a personal cleanliness standard to uphold.....well, then yeah....maybe not.

Just finishing up the Balance and Technique class and thought it was about time to get a review on the books.  I've been to all three of the PG locations and Sunnyvale is probably my favorite (SF is a close 2nd).  I'm climbing 5.10s and always have plenty of routes to choose from.  Slabs, overhangs, short climbs, or marathons, there's something for every level and style.  I only recently got into bouldering but am loving the outdoor area, especially when the rest of the gym gets crowded.The bathrooms are hard to improve on.  Clean and spacious with plenty of lockers (bring a lock!); throw in the sauna and showers and you've got a pretty great place to de-chalk after a climbing session.  Initially I agreed with some of the other reviews that complained about the staff at the desk being a little distant.  You have to realize that the staff put up with a lot over the course of a day, not that it's an excuse for poor service, but if you're friendly and outgoing they tend to be friendly and outgoing.  The instructors are pretty amazing and super willing to share beta whenever you need it, and most of the climbers are happy to help as well.  I've had random people cheer me on during difficult routes and coach me through bouldering cruxes plenty of times.

Ahhh...alas. I finally visited Planet Granite to climb.I have to say the place is pretty sick.It cost $18 to climb.Harnesses and shoes are available for rent.The ratings- quite accurate- kudos for that.There are thread mills, weights, for those who want to exercise.The place was filled with peeps so you must be careful of your surroundings whether you are a climber coming down or  a spectator.There were some climbs a bit challenging but...it just means another project in the works.

I first came to PG about 8 months ago when my boyfriend and I were out of volleyball and running with some injures.  I had never climbed before and now I am addicted.1.  The price is great.  As a student for $55 a month, I can climb, work out and take yoga classes all I want.  And get this, not only at one gym, but at three locations!2.  The route setters at PG are excellent.  No matter what level  you are at, 5.4- 5.12 you will find plenty of variety and the routes change quite frequently so there is always something new. 3.  What a workout.  Long routes for endurance, overhangs for upper body, slabs for balance.  It is a complete body workout.  4.  Guest night/passes and lessons.  I officially got my roommate addicted to climbing and I love bringing her for First Friday guest night and randomly with my free guest pass.  As a member you can get friends free belay lessons and access to the gym for the day.  I have set up 6 of my friends with free lessons, all in hopes to gain more climbing partners.5.  Excellent environment.  The people here are always very friendly and willing to offer advice on that one part of the route you just can't get past.  On warm days when the weather is good, the windows are open and the fresh breeze is just close enough to make you feel like you are climbing outdoors, and enough to make the smell of feet go away :)
Great rock climbing gym! I even got my husband, my brother, and my brother's friend to join and they all love it too! Great climbing walls, great climbing, cycling, cardio, palates, and yoga classes!

Honestly, I'm not much of a climber, but I came with the bf (who boulders frequently) to check out their gym and it's awesome! The glimpse of the gym alone has me sold and I am now determined to pick up rock climbing as an activity!

I rock climb here pretty frequently, They change the mounts a lot, and It has really cool rocks to climb,  price ain't too bad, the staff very young but very athletic and insightful, plus all the weight lifting equipment all the hard core cross fit people doing their bur pees haha what else is there to say? 5 stars?

I've been coming to Planet Granite several times a week to climb since August.  I like the services they offer (namely climbing lessons) and their facilities. I am even more appreciative of them after a recent trip to Taiwan where I did some indoor climbing. It made me realize how spoiled we are at Planet Granite with the pre-tied figure 8 knots, the pre-attached gri-gris, and the cushioned floor (I've never actually fallen to the floor while climbing, but oh does it look more comfy than falling directly onto cement). Anyway, I'm very happy with Planet Granite.  The parking is plenty, the routes bountiful and varied, the bouldering problems challenging, the staff friendly, and the facilities clean.  It does get quite crowded between 6pm and 9pm on weekdays when everyone gets off work, but there's usually always a route somewhere that's open and of the appropriate skill level.  They have a good number of treadmills and other cardio machines, as well as weight lifting machines.  They offer more classes than just the climbing ones, as well as short series of lessons for children to learn to climb. In addition, all of the Planet Granites (this one, Belmont, and San Francisco) host events like the Friction Series (a climbing competition) and specials for certain holidays (like headlamp climbing in the dark for Halloween). The only thing I wish Planet Granite would change is their guest pass policy. Currently, members receive one guest pass every two months and they do not accrue, which seems rather petty.Still, though, I love this place.

I. Love. Planet. Granite.Best indoor climbing gym EVER.  Almost all the routes are set really well, careful to avoid "reachy" problems - which, is really hard to do (in my opinion).  The bouldering is awesome.  Also, lots of different cracks to work on as well.  I also love the training areas - system board, hang boards, and the whole gym getup.  The yoga classes are great!!  Whenever I move back to the area,  I will be training here all the time.I do think the grades are a little soft (both routes/bouldering) as compared to ones Ive climbed in the east / midwest.

I LOVE PLANET GRANITE! I had a membership before I moved out of the area and would still if i lived closer. I have gone to 2 or 3 other climbing gyms just to compare and there is no comparison. Originally I took the beginning climbing class with my boyfriend and after that we were hooked. Climbing at every opportunity, 3 times a week.   The instructors and staff are totally awesome, especially Kyle O. and Mitch N. who were my personal class instructors. The facility itself isfantastic and the climbs are the best I have seen; there is something for every stage of climber. If you are looking for any place to climb, as a seasoned climber or an absolute neophyte, this is the place to go.

I'm not a physically adept person; not an athlete in any regard, and by no means graceful or finesse'd (...do I LOOK like a gazelle to you?!).  I weight train mostly, jog/run an iota, drunkenly dance, and lift ever-diminishing glasses of drinkydrink to my lips.  That's about it.  Oh, and flirtily chase girls... until they actually chase back, at which point I turn and run away like a world-class sprinter. [Digress.]But no amount of modernized, regimented exercise can quite prepare or compare to rock climbing [IMHO].  Strength helps, yes; but there are seldom used muscles and tendons that will groan at you by night's end.  Flexibility helps, yes; but climbs will demand unfamiliar contortions and dexterity for your ascent.  Balance helps, surely; but fingertip grips and precarious footings will make you question even your every position and posture.  And instinct?  Well instinct will take you only so far up a wall, but your mental acuity will be tested when "that's my next handhold" obviousness is met with "how the heck do I get up there?" uncertainties.And Planet Granite is a top-notch facility, ready to put all those things to the test...!The Sunnyvale location touts one of the largest indoor climbing facilities in Northern California, and with 25,000 square feet of climbing and bouldering surfaces, there are routes/difficulties for every skill level and challenge!As if that weren't enough, the facility also provides a serviceable workout area outfitted with weight training and cardio gym equipment as well as a yoga studio.With a relatively low-cost barrier to entry, indoor rock climbing  at Planet Granite is a great choice to explore as an outlet for regular exercise, as an activity-centered outing, or simply as a way to test and push yourself to new limits!Now if you excuse me, I've got new heights to achieve...___________________________________________And if all the "it's fun, it's healthy, its good for you" spiel doesn't sell you, then really, the people and physiques here are absolutely amazing.I mean AMAZING!

I've got Climbing Fever!If I can do it, you can do it... I've got tendinitis and the upper body strength in the less than 25% percentile of humans. There is a climbing wall suitable for anyone here.. and may I add that all the people I saw here were happy looking, healthy and shiny with sweat... all in a concentrated pool of good looking people (including my bf)I tagged along with the SB Yelp Elites, (thanks Mikey U. for the class).. i think you can get a free Belay class from a member.. but if not, the class is $34, not bad for 1+ hour of personalized instruction and coaching, there are four to a class and you get walked though it as many times as you need. My teacher, Kyle, was pretty awesome and fun. Mikey was saying this is an excellent alternative to Friday night drinks and I wholeheartedly agree. I have never been in a climbing gym before and by the end of the hour I was 40 feet up in the air, confidently climbing a wall with my buddy Donna belay-ing me. I got to smack the tape, at the top, and it was awesome!  Afterwards, you can stay and practice for the rest of the day. You can buy a discounted package ($50 for 5 in a 2 month period), then if you sign up for a membership, they will wave the initation fee ($35) then it's $70 a month, I think $50 if you are a student. I think it would be great to go with a group or with a buddy or two. Seems that you would meet fun people too, there is a lot of good smiling and vibes in there.. and who doesn't want to go back to their roots of climbing the jungle gym in the 2nd grade or even further back, climbing trees to pick fruit in the 9th century B.C? I can't wait to go again..ps climbing burns 660 calories an hour!

This is my usual climbing gym and i'm there 2-3 times a week. Going this often, i don't really feel like the routes are stale. The setters change them up regularly, and you don't see anything older than 2 months--and those that are there for that long are the really popular/challenging/interesting routes.Weeknights are really busy with the after-work crowd, but if you get there before 6:30, you should be okay. In my experience, wednesdays seem to be the busiest nights for some reason.And the membership? If you go once a week, it's paid off. The facilities aren't limited to rock climbing either--there are treadmills, weight machines, yoga classes, and even a tightrope and slack line outside.

So you know how there are those things in life you must try once...?For me, one of those things was rock climbing. It's you against the wall, competing against yourself.  Sure you have the harness to save you from a near death fall, but it's ultimately up to you to climb that wall.Some of my work pals had been asking me to go for months. This past Wed, I finally got my back and fears in check.  Armed with a free pass and some stretchy pants, I was ready to experience this exhilarating and challenging sport. Naturally I am fearful of heights and most rock walls at PG are about 30ft tall.  Lucky me. You can imagine where I am going with this right...yah.  I have never climbed and am scared of heights. Am I crazy? Sure.Arrived around 5 to meet up with a pal. Rented shoes for $4, got a harness(funky contraption, but the lifeline) and immediately noticed the FUNK.  The funk that was a smell of nasty toe and sweaty shoe.  You get used to it after a while, but that first whiff is priceless.  If you go, you do need to sign up for the intro belay class, to know what you are doing.  If not, go with a PG member and get hooked up with a pass!  Price are on website.Started on the baby wall of 5.3(the difficulty goes up). Was laughing my tush off, cause a 6 year old passed me on a similar climb.  When I looked down, I immediately felt this rush of crazy go through my arms and legs. It was awesome. I figured that the middle would be a great place to let go, to see what "falling" would be like. It took me a while, but I did. WEEEEEE. Crazy and fun for sure. I managed to evoke my American Gladiator and get to the top. I was looking for the bell and storm, but no such luck.  Did 2 and 1/2 climbs and got as high to 5 .6.  I tried my hands at bouldering-no harness and smaller walls. Definitely more challenging, and LADIES, if you want to see the HOT GUYS, this is where it's at.  But...the boys that come here are not about picking up chicks, and be advised, they are here to climb. Complete with weight equipment, yoga studio, and cardio machines, this is a great gym.  A little pricey at $70 or so a month, but if you like this kinda stuff....definitely worth it.   Healthy approved, and healthy endorsed!

Planet Granite is an amazing gym! I became addicted to rock climbing thanks to the tiny gym on Stanford's campus but that wasn't enough, and ended up getting a membership at PG Sunnyvale because turns out it's close to my house. I boulder mostly, and love the variety of their bouldering walls. I go a few times a week and never get bored with the problems - they change them enough to keep me interested. They also have some amazingly tall top rope walls that are fun.My biggest problem is how crowded the gym is in the evenings. I've gone right after work and it's zoo! Such a turn off. I mostly go early morning on the weekends now, and love having the gym to myself. I'm thinking of trying to incorporate bouldering one morning a week before work, or maybe trying to go really late to avoid the crowds.

I'm not big on heights, but there's something immensely satisfying about making it to the top of the bouldering walls. Plus, there's a new challenge all the time since they reset the courses pretty regularly. It's a little pricey, but with the option to use the gym facilities, it's really not bad if you're planning to be a regular. Give it a try, everyone there is really friendly and helpful.

I was worried it would be really physical or extreme (I mean it looks crazy and I'm a wimp) but there was a class to walk noobs like me through the safety and basics.  The routes are graded by difficulty and there are easier ones to start on.I took a belay class, a friend with a membership can get you a class for 1/2 off or free depending on their level of membership.  Normally a visit costs $18 plus shoe/harness rental, it is included with the belay class. After you take the class you can purchase a 5 pack of passes for $50 to be used in 2 mo (45% off, but you still pay for the shoe+harness rental).  If you decide you like it enough to buy membership, they'll put the $50 toward your fees.  A membership is about $70/mo or $50/mo if you're a student.  I'm thinking of getting a membership here instead of 24 hour fitness since they also have exercise machines, yoga classes, sauna etc.  If you're a member equiptment rental and classes are discounted.I'm not a super physical person, but this was pretty fun!  Thanks Mikey  and Donna for getting me to come out :-)

I absolutely LOVE this gym. It's amazing, everything you could want in a climbing gym and more! We've been members for about a month now, and every single time we go there it's great. The walls are really well done and all of the equipment is great. I'd love to check out a class or two as soon as I can!

Cost:- $18 day pass, $6 harness + shoes, $4 harness or shoes- Day pass works at all gyms for that day (so if you're at PGSV and go up to SF, climb on) -- Just remember your receiptTips:- If you take the belay class, for that day, you can get a discounted 5 entry pass for $50.  BUY IT! If you don't want to buy it...call me...I'll buy it.  Such a good deal.  - If you have a friend who's a member, ask them to sign you up for the belay class...even if you know how to belay...free rental, free class, free day pass...and access to the cheapy 5 pass. =D - If you are planning on taking the belay class, call a few days ahead as the classes do fill up.  - Saturday and Sunday mornings there seem to be a lot of children around, so if you have lil climber monkies this is the time for them (besides the Climb and Dine time).- 9-11 on weekdays are the best time to go.  Facilities:- All Top Ropes have Gri-Gri's so no belaying devices needed.  - Require double fisherman's with figure 8 for Top Roping.- They took away the gym chalk. =( So be sure to bring your own.- Lots of Top Ropes on all kinds of levels -- and varying lengths...so nice if you're working on endurance- Lots of Bouldering- Lots of work out Equipment- Lots of lead climbs too!- The outdoor bouldering area is kick-ass for when you've been there for a while and need to cool off, but still want to climb.- One of the biggest facilities I've seen EVER.- No cave top-ropes.- Weeknights == ALWAYS BUSY!!! Sometimes, you can wait 20 minutes to do a climb...and totally lame...or if you go and come back, your route is taken again...and you'll never get to do it.  It's an excercise in patience...but it's a good time to collect beta! =D- They constantly are changing routes, but leave them up long enough for people to try and work them out.  It's nice.- Skilla (the route setter) always kicks my butt.  Always technically challenging whether it be a crazy stemming problem, or some weird twisty turny thing...but I would always give his routes an extra 1/2 to whole grade higher than what it is marked.  People:- People there are friendly (behind the counter and in front)- there are all kinds of levels here- This is a great place for a newbie.  They offer a lot of classes, there are really great climbers here to watch and learn techniques from, and everyone is sooo nice about beta.  =D - Strangers, work on problems together...and spot each other. - All the Staff, super nice and friendly.  Stephanie (manager) is very nice.  Not all of the staff are climbers, they just like to work there...but they are all very friendly. =) - For the staff, a lot of them this seems working here is something they love, not just something they do for the money...or from what I've heard...they'd probably be working somewhere else.Classes:- They have many classes (see website for more class descriptions):    Belay Class (needed for Top Roping or to take Belay Certification Test)    BRC - Beginning Rock Climbing     101 - Intermediate    201 - More Advanced    Anchor and Repelling    Leading    Crack Climbing- Classes are awesome.  I took BRC with Cheryl and Rick and they were amazing.  They geared the class for the students.  They took the more advanced students aside and taught them things more at their level while assisting the beginner students.  Totally worth it.  For $125 you get 8 hours of instruction, unlimited access to the gym for four weeks, and 4 days of free gear rental. And initiation fees are waved after you take BRC, 101 or 201. Locker Rooms:- Bring your own padlock- Showers have separate stalls and curtains- I've been flashed in the lockers...so...um...if you're one of those people who doesn't want to be flashed...plan accordingly.  You know...lotsa European peoples.  But if you wanna be flashed...i guess...um...yeah.Gear Buy/Rental:- No Returns except for defective things- Members get 10% off - Great for buying guide books...and don't be fooled, they have everything from Castle Rock to Red Rocks to Yosemite to lesser traveled So Cal climbing areas -- Just call before hand if you're looking for something particular as stock is more hit and miss sometimesTests required for the following:- Belay Certification (so you can belay...and age requirement of 13yrs+)- Lead Certification (so you can lead climb)Overall: - My favorite Gym!  I climb here anywhere from 1-5 times a week here.  *heart*

May I belay you? NO I am not trying to pick up on you! I just want to rock climb with you ;) I guess you could say that my husband and I are the "adventurous type" and wanted a new hobby that we could do whenever we wanted to but also didn't break our piggy bank. We tried everything from hang gliding to sky diving and everything else in between but all of these hobbies are expensive and not something we can just pick up and do one afternoon without too much planning. And then enters Rock Climbing into our lives. We heard a lot of great things with Planet Granite and with this gym being near both of our jobs, it was the perfect place to get involved in our new hobby but most importantly...together! I am really impressed with this facility and even more happy that with my membership I get a lot more then just rock climbing. I get yoga classes, cycling classes, boot camps and a full gym with cardio machines, weights and a ton of other machines and a great sauna facility with a locker room with that "spa" feel. Also they offer a ton of classes at all different times so their schedule works well for me....not the other way around. The price was a lot more reasonable then I thought it would be! We got lucky and only had to pay $35 for the one time registration fee and for the both of us it will be $110 a month. Plus equipment like shoes and harnesses will cost us less then $100...so it's an affordable hobby. PG also sells equipment packages with everything you need including shoes for about $130 after tax. The staff here is friendly and knowledgeable. We had our first belay lesson and we caught on easily and our instructor was very patient with us considering the group we were put in had 3 small children. This is a family friendly place and kids are welcome. Its pretty amazing to see a 4 year old climbing up a tall wall and looking like a pro! I also saw some new parents with their baby in a stroller next to the wall they were climbing. It wasn't in the way or a deterrence to other climbers so its a great place for parents to come to without hiring a babysitter. Of course all in moderation...the next thing I hate to see is a bunch of unruly unsupervised kids running around like crazy! ;) And another great thing about this gym is that draws a lot of people....I ran into 3 friends there today! If you are a single climber, you probably will have an easy time finding a stranger (and maybe new friend!) to belay your climb. This is the only drawback and why I only give it 4 stars is because it's not really a place you can use without a permanent partner to go with or you just have to make new friends fast. ;) See you on the 5.10+......okay maybe not yet....but one day!

I'm quite impressed with planet granite in Sunnyvale. The reasonable membership fee gets you access to climbing, yoga, fitness equipment, and cycling classes. I joined in Jan, so there was no initiation fee. The climbing routes are changed often enough. There's a good number of climbs throughout the 5.6-5.11 range.  Some of the ropes are a bit thick, and rather ragged looking. The climbing gym does get crowded on weeknights. At least the crowd is generally polite and considerate of others. I don't see the logic in having so much of the gym dedicated to lead climbing. As more of a trad climber, I don't see the point of leading in a gym in general... but to each his or her own.Yoga classes are better than anyplace outside a yoga studio that I've been. Again, classes tend to be crowded at the popular times. They recently added a beginner's class that was sorely lacking before. The cardio equipment is good. Nothing special, but not the poor quality stuff either. They do have three erg's for rowing.The nautilus-type-machines and free weights are limited, but adequate.  The climbing-specific hang boards and progressive monkey bars are great. They also have a generous stretching area unlike many gyms. The locker rooms are clean and well maintained. The towels are like steel wool and smell like beach. At least you know they're clean. The men's locker room smells like sweaty feet most of the time.

There's something very primal about climbing.It's in our DNA. It engages so many of the core muscle groups, combined with the necessary flexibility and balance.After a good climb you can't help but feel exhilarated.It's so perfectly synergistic with Yoga (which they also offer on-site).Planet Granite Sunnyvale is an extremely well-run climbing gym: the entire staff are attuned to creating a welcoming environment for climbers at all levels, and always with an eye to safety.

This is a great gym, guys. Everyone knows it, too!  It does get crowded, but the crowd is a pretty friendly group, in general.  The people at the front desk are welcoming and helpful.Tue/Thu nights are the busiest.  That way climbers get their midweek fix and are fresh for the weekends.  If you want your pick, go anytime during the day before 6pm.I love the frequency with which the routes are changed, not to quickly, not to lengthy.Each toprope has a grigri attached.  One tip to handle busy climbing nights...Don't be afraid to nicely ask someone, "are you switching?" so you know how long you'll have to wait for that route.  It also lets them know you're waiting, to minimize chatting on the ground.COMMON SENSEYou probably know this, but... To have the rope locked off, you hold it below the belay device.Some routes wander.  Check to make sure you're on the correct toprope, and that you won't get in the way of someone already on the wall.Climbing under someone on lead is the biggest of no-no's. It's seriously dangerous, and inconsiderate, too. Don't do it. Even when the gym is packed. If you're belaying a leader and you see someone tied in and ready to start, you can ask them to wait.YOGAThe yoga is such a great addition to the gym.  There is an instructor and class style for everyone's taste here.CARDIO EQUIPMENTWoo-hoo!  I can be entertained by your climbing from the treadmill!  There is a good variety of cardio equipment, and it is in good condition.  No tv's anywhere in the gym.GYM EQUIPMENT & WEIGHTSRecently remodeled.  Great condition, great variety of both hand weights, machines, bosu, medicine balls, etc.  There is a small padded area for stretching, but it's pretty busy most of the time.  OTHER CLASSESSpin, abs, & crossfit classes.The bathrooms were recently remodeled and look very nice. There are showers, a sauna, lockers, a standing scale, hair dryer, etc.  All the niceties.Unless this has changed recently, no Wi-Fi.

yoga.fitness.climbing = complete body orgasm !!!A) Yoga: This place hooked me into yoga with its wide variety of styles and instructors. They have classes for beginners such as Yoga Foundations and endurance, strength, and flexibility classes such as Power Yoga. Additionally, they have morning, noon, evening and weekend classes. I highly recommend Doris, Jill, Eric, Lorraine, and Susannah. B) Fitness: It's hard to ignore the amount of toys this gym as to offer.  They have everything from weights to those gymnastics ring that makes anyone look weak. Additionally, tie these in with their Crossfit and Cycling classes you got a fitness area that is anything but conventional.C) Climbing: Uhm? Can we say "Great Fun?" Not only is it challenging (I'm afraid of heights) but you get the sense of being in a community when you climb in this gym. People are friendly and are open with helping each other out on different routes.  Furthermore, the gym is really good about making announcements for people who are looking for a belay partner and has a outdoor climbing area.And Yeah ... I'm a sucker for any place that has a sauna and this place has a pretty decent one with pretty decent shower areas where you don't have to second guess about  how filthy the floor is.

Biggest PG in the area. Staff is friendly and helpful, area is clean and maintained.It gets very packed during the week at regular gym hours (after 5pm), so be aware. Weekend mornings seem to be better.

I've been here in the past for rock climbing classes and the instructors are great. but this week, I tried the Vinyasa Flow Yoga course. it's really early in the AM, but it's a damn good workout. worth going to if you are an intermediate yogi. :) I'll definitely be coming back to this class.

I was intimidated by this place .. but as i started off climbing, it wasn't too bad! they have 5.1---5.12a++[i got no clue what it ends with].i started off with 5.3 just to get the feel, then 5.4 then 5.7, soon later i'm at a 5.10a  .. but believe me, its easy increasing your level and then reverting back ... hahahah. some of the ratings are OFF, they may be easier or harder than it is stated. [*note anything with a ledge to climb over .. is a good extra level higher] hahai got a membership after the first day! $90 initiation + $70 monthly. i even got the beginners kit = harness [black diamond], shoes [evolv], chalk bag, and chalk sock for $112+tax for both females and males. members get free 1 guest pass every other month, of 1st friday of each monday is guest day, and members can get guests into the belay class($34 value)this place may smell kinda funny the first time you come in, but you will soon get use to it.theres lots of climbs, bouldering, a equipped gym, yoga classes, lockers [sauna, showers, lockers]. it's a pretty nice place =)

The first thing that happens when one walks into Planet Granite is a feeling of "Oh my jesus what the FUCK".   This is okay.  Welcome to Planet Granite.  Welcome, as it were, to the wide world of fake rock climbing.Yes, it is fairly easy to look at the three-plus storied harnessed climbs and say, "Yes, well, I don't hate my life nearly enough for this."   True, one may see a group of third-graders crawling up a jagged boulder wall and reason, "Aha!  I am better than children in everything else, NO PROBLEM."--only to be fairly humiliated as one falls on one's ass as one attempts to move from a hanging beginning hold to the subsequent grip on one's given course.Planet Granite, though, offers all that a beginining fitnessist could desire from a gym.  Cardiovascular machines are offered and rarely fully occupied. with full locker rooms including clean towels available for use.  The climbing walls are frequently altered to provide new challenges, while retaining a consistent  balance of beginners' courses to expert, "I am either a God or Spider-Man" insanity tracks.   Never mind that there are children aged 11 or younger whose rippling abdomens  inspire no less than the encumbent evening's festive wrist-cutting, or that omnipresent shirtless simian-limbed gentlemen and ladies may suggest with their very bodies' undulent suspensions and  grunts that you are in no way deserving of a mate, much less friends.  You are here to become like them.It will take but a days' dedicated flaps of skin hanging from ones' knuckles to agree that, yes. Man was never meant to descend from the trees to the savannah, but from the trees to wall-length boulder outcroppings with plastic holds bolted into them.Planet Granite: Do it.  The cute girl struggling on the V2 is more than worth the fifteen dollars per session.

Love this place! I've recently rediscovered my love for climbing and am thrilled with Planet Granite. I was really impressed with the size of the gym and the variety of routes. My bf and I started off the new year with a belay lesson, bought the initial promotional 5-pack deal, and have since become full members. I've found the people to be really friendly and helpful and the equipment package deal (harness, shoes, chalk bag) for $129 is a deal!The fact that they have a weights, gym equipment, and yoga in addition to the rock gym  is fantastic - we both have actually dropped our other gym membership and do all our workouts at PG now.  The price for a couples membership is the same as what we were paying for a regular gym membership - bonus!I've recently tried the "beginners" yoga on Sunday AM which I really enjoyed. I've never been into yoga, but I can see why people get into this.

PG is definitely one of my more desired climbing spots. I really like their bouldering walls because it's constantly being changed up. The outdoor wall is great too, especially during the summer when you can climb and soak up the rays. I like the height of a lot of their top roping walls, as it is alot higher than most gyms. The variety of routes and difficulty levels helps for improving climbing techniques for climbers of all abilities. The gym is extensively opened aired, and never feels cramped no matter how crowded. It has a full weight room, and tons of cardio machines as well as a large pulling area for optimizing your lateral work outs. The prices are high, but all climbing gyms are, so it's to be expected, but PG does offer an early bird special, and if I'm not mistaken, it's good all day. Tons of parking. Only thing I really don't like is the fact that public transport to this facility from anywhere in the greater bay area is nil.

I had my first rock climbing lesson here tonight, and it was a lot of fun. The lessons are a pretty good deal, for the price you get the instruction and are able to use the gym as much as you want for that time. Our instructor was really cool, the class was pretty small and we all had fun climbing after learning to belay properly.There's also quite an array of cardio machines, so I can definitely see coming here to run on the treadmills while watching people scale the walls, and I'm looking forward to my upcoming lessons.

Ooo ooo ooo me monkey.  Me climb rock wall.  Throw poo from top.  Watch out, cute girl in blue tank top.  Monkey climb.  Monkey throw poo.  Monkey get in cheap.  Monkey climb.  Monkey belay.  More poo throw.Yay!

I was visiting Palo Alto this week and since this place was pretty well-reviewed, decided to check it out.  I've been climbing once or twice a week for about 8 months in a gym in Philly, so am sort of OK, but hardly an expert.  Overall, I'd recommend it and wish my home gym had some of these features.  Some longer thoughts below.Note for out-of-town people:  If you're like me and have only climbed at a place where you use carabiners to attach yourself to the rope, you have to know how to tie in with a figure eight knot at PG.  They showed us how for free, and it's pretty easy, but you might want to just practice in advance.  You also have to use a gri-gri for whatever reason, but it's pretty trivial.Pros: This place is really nice.  A lot nicer than Go Vertical in Philly, and the price is exactly the same.  The locker room is large and clean, and there's a "gym gym" to go along with climbing.  The bouldering area is really good.  It's separated from top-roping and leading areas, with lots of choices for terrain.  The staff was friendly.Cons: The ratings are a little wonky, seemingly coming from the same approach that gave us size -1 for women's clothes.  PG seems to just call everything 5.10 and then uses letters to tell you how hard it really is.  (Back home anything called 5.10 is a bit over my head, which wasn't the case here at all.  I don't think the weather made me much better over night.)I didn't have a lot of time to look around, but there didn't seem to be a lot of routes where stemming is the main thing or lots of overhangs either.It also seems like you need a car to get to it, which is a bit of a downer if you aren't renting one.  (This may be a general commentary on Sunnyvale.)

I've been an avid rock climber (generally just bouldering) for a couple of years now, largely climbing in indoor gyms though I'm beginning to climb outdoors.  This past summer I took an 11,000 mile roadtrip around the US (I drove through all of Seattle, Boston, New York, New Orleans, Los Angeles, SF and more) and I climbed at every climbing gym I could find.  Of all of the gyms that I have been to, Planet Granite is, far and above, the best.  They have a huge bouldering wall, a great diversity of routes (both in terms of technique and difficulty), and really awesome people that climb there.Planet Granite is certainly not perfect.  They can be a bit lax about maintaining their route markings and are very inconsistent about rating their problems.  I also have not been to the other two Planet Granite locations so I really can't compare this one to them them.  Overall though, I love this gym!

my 6 year old son recently completed a week-long rock climbing camp at Planet Granite.  I was impressed all around!  The instructors were wonderful with the little ones (6 year olds, mostly boys, a couple of girls) - really allowing them to explore, climb, boulder and gain confidence in a new sport.    Signed up through Los Gatos Rec.   Will be back next year!

Ah rock climbing, definitely something to put onto your Bucket List!My boyfriend and I always wanted to try climbing, but didn't know where to begin. Luckily some of our Yelp friends have been climbing at Planet Granite for a few months now and are addicted. They advised that we take the Belay Lesson because we were able to rent gear, learn how to belay, as well as climb and belay the rest of the evening. There are two lessons the evening we went, if you do decide to take the lesson, I would advise to take the earliest lesson you can so that you can belay and climb for the rest of that day. Because, once you get going, you just don't want to stop. Plus it's always fun to go with a small group of friends. The lessons are always a group of 4, so having a group at least that size would be ideal.The staff at this location are very friendly and easy going. Our Belay instructor was very cool. He was very knowledgeable and was very thorough about his explanations of belaying. NOTE for more experienced climbers: you have to take their Belay Test before you can belay in their gym.After taking the Belay Lesson my boyfriend and each purchased a 5 day pass, so that we can come back a few more times to get more of a feel of the gym. We enjoyed it our first time and are excited about returning. Since we purchased the 5 day pass after our lesson, if later we decide we would like to purchase a gym membership, they put the $50 we spent on the pass toward the membership. Which saves us lots of money and gives us the option to try the gym out before we commit to a membership.If you want to try climbing and don't know where to begin, I would suggest coming to PG and taking a Belay Lesson so that way you can experience climbing as well as be eligible to take the Belay Test if you do decide to return.
This is the best climbing gym I have even been to. Very friendly staff and great climbing routes. I have not tried anything else but climbing but even for that the price is reasonable

I've yet to experience another climbing gym so I can't really compare it to others..but I love this place.Staff and fellow climbers are nothing but kind and willing help.  If you live close by, you should definitely get some time in on the wall. It is ridiculously packed on weekdays(mon-thurs), weekend mornings usually allow for more time on the wall instead of waiting between climbs.

PG Sunnyvale is a nice indoor gym.There are way too many people however, guess climbing is becoming victim of its success. the only way to climb without being bothered by other people is to lead, if not , expect to make some queuing before getting a climb.This place also feels very much like an "industry". I have to say that I cannot blame them when I see how many people are ready to pay for it ;-) . You will not find the cozy friendly gym where everybody knows each other over here.I never tried the running and bodybuilding side of it ... I cannot understand why you would run inside when you can go just outside with such a beautiful weather as in California

My husband and I took a belay lesson here about three months ago as our weekly date night, and unintentionally got hooked. Now we're climbing fiends and are at the gym four or five times a week, not only climbing but using the cardio equipment, weights and taking cycling and yoga classes.As far as the climbing goes, we haven't had a problem getting bored with the indoor aspect. There are routes for all levels whether you're bouldering or lead climbing, and they setters change up routes all the time so there's also something new and challenging to try. The staff is also awesome, everyone is really helpful, which was great when we first started out. You're never afraid to ask a question, or as for advice, and they're really encouraging if they catch you struggling  on a climb.The facilities are AWESOME. We're work out people, but we've never really been gym people, mostly because places like 24 hour or golds are just a mess, overcrowded with an odd mix of people. But all the members here are awesome, very chill and totally friendly. Plus, you never have to wait for a machine, there's always one available, and they have a good variety. They also do crossfit, yoga and cycling and the instructors are great, and they have a wide variety of class times to choose from, especially yoga. I also love that they have different varieties and styles of yoga to choose from, so always doing the same thing.We love this place, and we're here all the time, plus, the members fees are pretty low for what you get, which is fantastic.

I love Planet Granite and I work out here every morning. However, I feel I should warn other Yelpers that PG's cleaning staff apparently doesn't start until after they open, so if you are, e.g., running on the treadmill before work (7a-8a), expect to have your lungs FILLED with extremely strong-smelling chemicals as they mop the floor around you. This happens to me every morning. I'm not chemically-sensitive, so it's just annoying (at least until I get lung cancer or something 20 years from now?), but if you are, be advised that this may not be the gym for you.

I love Planet Granite--exercise equipment, yoga classes, and rock climbing all in one place! I highly recommend becoming a member if you enjoy doing all three. Sometimes they have a special where they waive the $90 initiation fee if you join during a particular month, so look for that if you are thinking of joining.I love to exercise here. There is a good variety of equipment that is in good condition. I also love the yoga classes. There are about 5 (?) different instructors, and you really have to try each class to know which instructor suits you best. My favorite classes are Slow Flow (taught by Susannah who is wonderful), and Power (taught by Kory who is equally wonderful). All the classes are free if you are a member. If you are not a member but want to try out a class, it is $17/class and $1 to rent a mat.As for climbing, there are a lot of different routes that vary in degree of difficulty, so don't be intimidated if you are a beginner. Also, they change up the routes once in a while so you won't get bored if you go often. Each route has the initials of the person who created it, so you'll start to learn who creates the harder routes. ;) My one tiny complaint is that if you aren't a super avid climber and don't own all the gear, you have to pay $5 to rent the gear each time. I already pay over $60 to be a member each month, so I think the $5 rental fee is pretty annoying. I'm sure they have a good reason for that.... right???

This is a pretty good climbing gym. It's a big place with tons of walls, and the climbs can go pretty high. On the downside, it can get crowded, especially weekday evenings in the winter, and it's a bit expensive.They just opened a new bouldering area on the outside which I've heard is pretty cool but I haven't seen it yet. All in all a good place to go climbing with good hours, though I usually climb at a smaller place in Mountain View.

Came here with brother before his flight back to his hometown.Arrived at PG 10am-12pm on Saturday. Bro's Flight was at 3pm. Asked if we could get lunch, and come back inside around 1pm, bluntly told "No ins and out priveleges" cause we had morning passes. Seriously? A little slack?

The first gym I've had to pay for in a while. And it is worth every penny assuming you know how to use it. tl;dr version: join if you enjoy climbing/want to start climbing/need a Cross-Fit area/aren't a gym snob.Pros:3 stories of rock wall climbing with a wide spectrum of difficulties ("almost-a-ladder" all the way to "how-can-anyone-grab-that-nub?").Two bouldering areas, indoor and out, again with a wide difficulty range.Routes that change every few months to give you new problems to work on.An array of elliptical, threadmill, and bike cardio machines.Resistance machines and free weights.Cross-Fit area with rubber weights, kettlebells, and climbing rope.Locker and shower area.Friendly members and staff.Cons:Subject to any other gym's "peak time" and can get pretty crowded.People have a possibility of smelling quite bad. And you can't get away when you're 40ft off the ground and hanging onto a fake cliff.The nature of Cross-Fit lends itself to be quite loud because of Olympic style lifting and dropping of weights.One "centrally" located pair of water fountains between the entrances of the men and women locker rooms.Men's locker room has a perpetual funk smell. Can get particularly bad during peak times. Resistance area is limited.And after that laundry list, I guess I'll actually use proper grammar. The  facility is nice albeit not sparkling clean. Theres chalk nearly everywhere and you're allowed to be barefoot. That just comes with the territory. If you're used to higher end gyms like Club One or Equinox, this isn't the place for you. People actually work out here. And, don't be shamed if a 10yo is scaling the boulder walls like it was a ladder. Kids are crazy natural climbers.

-my ass is a monkey, or should i say i'm a monkey ass?-i love to climb...ask all my x boyfriends-the only experience i had prior to my 2 visits to planet granite to climb is thru the window when i locked myself in with the x boyfriends, fetching fresh coconuts for "buko" juice while in the philippines, and on a cruise to mexico-the staff could be friendlier...really-restrooms are nice, the workout area is small but seems packed -i know i can't control the smell up in hhuurr but it just confirms the reason why i don't like going to a gym-1st time i started at 5.3-5.8 -2nd time took the belay class and did up to a 5.10-bouldering doesn't interest me at all but the crack does.....i love me some crack-my visits i hope will lead me to more crack-for someone not trying to make this a regular thang i got my own toekiller shoes crotch hugging harness and all-wanna give thanks to homie pete for taking me on his free days....and the chalk bag that matches my awesome yelleerrrr  evolv pontas-love staring at the walls...they are bootyful...and calvesful-i don't have patience so with that, i have no technique,....bwahahaha but my ass gets up there, and fast. =THAT'S WHAT HE SAID.

I love this place! it is sooo fun! I with my boyfriend to rock-climb for the first time and we both loved it. We took a belaying (spelling??) class which helped a lot. The only reason that I dont gie this place 5 stars is because the steam room is the mens bathromm has been down for some time and beause this place it a bit pricey. I just because a member and hope to enjoy all the activities that PG offers.
This is the best bang for your buck. CrossFit, Rock climbing, Yoga, Pilates and a regular gym all at $75, what more can you ask for?

I surprisingly had a really good time rock climbing here. Even though I have no upper body strength... or lower body for that matter ... anyways. There were many different climbs at different levels so anyone should be able to make it to the top, no problem. Unless you have a fear of heights. I didn't try the bouldering as I wasn't too keen on falling onto a pad if I couldn't hold on any longer.I've also taken a yoga class here and let me tell you, if I went here regularly, I'd have a body of steel! The class was pretty hard for a beginner like me, so I was like a wet noodle by the end of the class. Weeeell, let's be honest here. I was dead by the middle of the class. Then after, I went climbing! The next day was very very unpleasant for me.And um, in case anyone is wondering ... the scenery is pretty good there. I mean, I felt like I was in a parallel universe - dorky looking guys with their shirts off, looking cut. It was strange... but at the same time, really awesome. Just sayin'.

This gym is rock solid. Albeit too expensive for a family man with time to go 1-2 times a week. But they have it - yoga, great routes for lead, top-rope & bouldering and also grerat cardio machines & weights. Staff is good altough not all of them. Early mornings does have a discount for drop in rates which is good. For kids they have a little play section and I have never been scolded for bringing my kids along.

I'm scared of heights. Like dribble a little pee when you walk in and see the 3-story walls kind of scared. But go with some friends who will belay/egg you on, and your spouse whom you don't want to seem like a total coward in front of, and it's amazing what feats you can accomplish. ok, 5.7s and 5.8s aren't feats of anything compared to what some of those amazing climbers can do here, but still. I've got nothing to compare this place to, and indoor rock climbing is not likely to be my next big hobby. But the facilities, gym equipment, and locker rooms seem clean, the staff is helpful and friendly, and you'll feel at home with the clientele especially if you work in silicon valley. There are obvious beginners and skilled veterans, and all share the common goal of working out and having fun. Be prepared for scraped knuckles, banged up knees, and bruised egos.

I expected too much from the country's largest climbing gym.  The size includes the yoga studio and the fitness gym, so the actual climbing walls are about the same as the other large gyms in the Bay Area.My beginner friend in the South Bay was not able to meet up due to the belay class being full.  Fortunatley she called ahead and didn't make the trip.  Be sure to sign up ahead of time.Some highlights: being able to walk and see outdoor space, more beginner routes, and the monkey bars(!).

Okay, let's be fair again. I've never actually rock climbed in the new location (I came by just to see the place), just the old. HOWEVER, I am sooo excited about going here that I'm giving them FIVE stars!! Have you seen the wall??? HOLY CRAP!!!ALI C.!!! Girl, CALL ME!! We need to go ASAP!!

They replaced their floating pads with fixed padding.It's hard and landing/falling on it hurts my ankles and shins.Asked other climbers if they liked it.  They said the same thing.They need softer padding on top or softer foam in the padding for better cushioning.I don't like it.-1 star for shit pads.Other than that, my old review still stands.

Love this place.  The Staff is friendly.  They won't cut you any slack, but really that's good.  Better they were strict than someone fell from not knowing wha thier doing. The crowd is young and friendly and they mostly stick to themselves.  Starts to crowd up around 7, and is generally COOOOOLLLLLLD!!  Until you start climbing!They have cross training classes on Monday and Thursday.  Other classes include Yoga and Cycling.

Unrivaled indoor rock climbing gym and fitness center.Insane for top roping.  Many many runs that go higher than you typically see.Great exercise facilities.  They have the coolest and most useful pull ups area.  It's like a jungle gym for adults.

Been climbing here for a few months, by far the best gym I've ever climbed at; tons of walls, the routes are great, I come solely to boulder (the back wall is my favorite) and I'm 110% happy every time. Got my first V4 the other day! Fully recommend (and try and get my friends to try it out) to anyone even remotely interested in checking out climbing, the people are great (staff and members) and super supportive and friendly.

I have been to many climbing gyms and I really liked this one, minus the crowd.  I wasn't a fan of climbing so close to another, but they had some fun routes so that made up for the climbing on top of another.I was really impressed with the outdoor boulder area, it reminded me of being out in a playground as a kid. They had a ton of great boulder routes, I love bouldering again! I liked how they had gri-gri's and the carabiners all set at all the top rope routes. This gym is all about the safety factor and it shows. I wish I had a chance to try out some routes in the lead area. There were a bunch of nice overhangy juggy routes that were calling my name.Not only is this place great for climbing, there is a huge fitness area as well. Awesome well rounded facility!

This was pretty darn fun.It's a bit expensive if you come here from time to time ($18 + rental for harness and optional shoes), but well laid out with plenty of different climbing difficulties and a decent gym in case you want to work out.One thing that I thought was icky is the number of dudes not wearing a shirt... look dude, be a mountain man in the mountains... this is indoors!The staff seemed pretty helpful and some of the clibers there even offered advice on tackling some of the different walls.What is also nice is that you dont have to get a harness to climb.. they have plenty of walls that you can free climb!I'm definitely coming back

It has definitely gotten way crowded since I first started climbing in 2007, but there is no where else like it. Everyone is extremely friendly, and I love the walls. The price is a steal considering they do not limit your access to the gym. The staff is also really nice about letting you leave and then come back.

Had a great experience here for my birthday. I had never been rock climbing before, and the staff at planet granite made everything so easy. I took the belay class and our instructor JJ was outstanding. He was patient, funny, and I could tell he genuinely cared about his job. I will definitely return and bring as many people a I can.

Now I am in the city of San Francisco and too far to commute to PG in Sunnyvale, I miss it so much. The 60 feet tall walls with over 70 ropes, two large bouldering areas, spin room, yoga room, gym and stretch area, and sauna in the locker room!! All spanking new and friendly staff.I wish I didn't have to move away from it...

I went to Planet Granite for a "team building" event. All in all, I had fun, although the 2 hour safety demonstration got tiring, and there was a bizzare teambuilding "human chain" event. We each only got to rock climb and belay once, but that was the most fun part.In all fairness, 8 people in a belay class must be difficult. That does not, however, give you an excuse to be extremely creepy, like our instructor was. You know in second grade how there's that one guy who's really mean to one girl because he likes her but is too embarssed and bashful about his sexuality to talk about it or act normally?  Well, imagine that in a creepy, 50 year old bald guy and you have our instructor. He made fun of the fact that she was left handed the entire time in a very mean way!  How stupid is that?!It seems like a nice enough climbing gym, and everyone else was really cool, so I'm not giving it a low rating. But jeez, do some quality assessments of your staff, and don't hire creepy, awkward old men!

This is an amazing climbing gym.  They installed new floor padding along all the bouldering walls, so you no longer need to fuss with moving the crash pads about, and it's no longer possible to sprain your ankle by rolling off the edge of the pads!  Incredible.  The weights gym is a little lacking in equipment though; they need a decline crunch bench, free weight preacher curl bars, and more handles for their cables.
Been here four times, good gym, offers lessons and packages to get you started to climb. All levels, I finally conquered a 5.9. They also have special events for kids or singles.

I love this gym! It's definitely worth the 20-30 minute drive it takes me to get here from San Jose. I'm far from the best at rock climbing and there's so many different problems to choose from! Amazing for beginners and fun for everyone. I come here with my boyfriend and it's given us an activity that we love to do together. I haven't tried their yoga yet, but I heard it's incredible. The staff is so friendly too, they're always super helpful. I love how everyone always encourages and helps one another, it's a very inviting atmosphere. My only complaint would have to be the prices. It's definitely not cheap, but being a student definitely helps to cut the cost a little bit

A common dilemma: on one hand, I want the community to know about this great gym and on the other hand, I want to keep this place a secret.  Planet Granite is fun, has something for everyone, and offers excellent value for the price of membership.  The climbing walls are expansive and varied, the fitness classes that I've taken are led by skilled instructors, and general facilities are conducive to fitness.For first-timers, make sure you call to schedule a belay lesson, but don't forget to check out the class schedule for yoga and spinning.  For serious climbers, there's the bouldering area and a new outdoor climbing area (currently under construction).

Only been here once but it was loads of fun. I'm no rock climbing regular. I don't go every week or every month but I always have an urge to climb if I see a wall.PG is a really relaxed and chill place to be as long as you respect others and don't get in peoples way [common courtesy].I used the indoor and outdoor short walls [didn't belay] and used the fitness equipment as well.They have different difficulty levelsAs I said, I'm no regular climber and it was my first time climbing at PG and the 0 and 1's were somewhat easy but the 2's were kickin my butt. The indoor walls were great and had nice pads to fall onto. The outside walls were great too BUT the pads outside were worn out and not so fun to fall on [So I climbed back down instead of jumping down].I love that they have a peg board there, it's one of my favorite things to do although I only get up a few holes before having to drop.The fitness equipment was pretty good, it's not 24 Hour Fitness Super Sport [my gym]. But I got a good workout after climbing and felt very satisfied by the end of my experience.I got to go in with a friend who has a membership and only had to pay for the shoes but I see $18 as not too bad of a price to pay if you only will go every once and awhile. And as someone else said, as a crossfit gym, even the membership price doesn't sound that bad especially if you don't have a gym membership already.

Planet Granite Rocks (har har har)!Some things I've found after being a member for about a year that you should consider, that other reviews may not have highlighted.1) They change the Climbing and Bouldering routes often! So often that if you face a hard problem, you know you gotta bust your butt to solve it in a week or two, or else it'll be gone, replaced by something else, and always an open question, were you really good enough? So work hard and never stop. This variety is a great thing. It helps motivate you to climb often, and the interesting sections (like the back chimney in the ice box) get changed up enough that they remain fun.2) They upgraded their gym equipment. Lots of free weights and now many machines that you can use alone (bench press with rails so no need for a spot, etc.). It's a pleasure to use the gym and although it's not that big, it's also not that full. They added some ropes, some hanging "monkey" bars or whatever they are now called as adults, and a whole set up for the training classes they run.3) They have a good slab wall which I find (I'm pretty new and not that good) to be very useful to practice the balance climbs and technique even when my arm strength has given out.4) Nice! Everyone is very nice at the gym. It's so much fun to go to.5) I haven't taken any classes here but I know a few folks, men and women, who do yoga here and say it is very good. Their classes are 90 minutes long, which I'm told by many is a great length for a yoga class (included in membership no extra cost).

I have been a member, worked at, and climbed at a dozen gyms nationwide.  This is by far the most well done gym I have ever been too.  Obviously they have great climbing with very diverse ratings.  Great climbs for beginners and experts.The ratings are not sandbagged like most of the gyms that I have been too.  Sometimes route setters have a mentality that "this route is not that hard" and rate it way too low.  For example, in the bouldering area, the V5s all climb similarly hard and they for the most part easier than all the V6s. This is in contrast to some gyms that they rate everything a VB, V0 or V1 and are obnoxiously hard.  This gym is right in the heart of Silicon Valley and it is packed after work and on the weekends.  This may seem like a downside but belonging to a couple of gyms that closed due to no revenue, A PACKED GYM IS BETTER THAN NO GYM AT ALL. Check it out!With a membership (or I believe a daily pass) you take yoga classes, use the weights, use cardio,  take spinning classes, use the steam room, showers, towel service etc etc etc.

Went here for the first time, and, boy, was I in for a surprise. I didn't expect it to be this challenging. After a few hours, me and my buddies were TIRED. Bouldering was fun and we're planning to come back sometime soon.If it's going to be your first time, rent the shoes, they help a lot! And so does chalk.

Second time there and now it will be my Tuesday's  evening workout!!!GOOD STUFF! And the sauna is an added bonus! Too bad they don't have a spa, but hey, this is not Lifetime Fitness...Anyways, I like it there because you will never see a pumped-up all-muscles-no-agility guy there! ...and a lot of chicks tooooo!

If I could find a flaw with PG I would tell you all about it, but that's a tall order.  I won't knock it for being crowded because that's really a testament to what a great climbing gym it is.  Let's talk about crowding since that's the main issue here.- Weekday mornings until about noon the gym is -empty-.  I mean, it's you, your partner and maybe 4-5 other people.  Oh... those 4-5 other people are the cleaning staff.- Saturday/Sunday morning it's a bit more crowded but still plenty of space.  Get there around 8-9 and climb for a few hours; no problemo.- Weekday evenings... well I went once I won't go back.  It's just so insanely crowded the logistics of climbing with people on adjacent/neighbouring routes takes a lot of the fun out of it for me.  It gets crazy around 7 or so.There's a great variety of top routed routes (I don't lead yet so I can't comment on that) for all levels, although the majority (90%+) are 5.8 and above which is cool because anybody climbing a few times will graduate pretty quickly to 5.8-5.9.The staff is all very laid back and friendly as are the majority of the patrons... just a great place to climb and have fun overall.

I'm gong to write this from a CrossFitter's perspective.Most people think $70 is expensive, but this is incredibly cheap considering most CrossFit gyms charge $150. Furthermore, I appreciate having an open gym. This allows me to do WODs even when I sleep in and miss class. Factor in that there are free yoga classes (oh, and there's that rock climbing thing), and Planet Granite is a steal.Minor quibbles: * Classes are getting pretty big, so sometimes we have to be creative about how we use the equipment.  We only have two GHD machines.  One of which isn't comfortable for doing back extensions because it doesn't have space for the crotch.  Also, there's only one set of rings that are high enough for muscle ups, although maybe we could hang another set on the pull up ladder.* WODs that include running (Helen, Michael) are annoying because you have to walk through half the gym in order to get outside. This adds unnecessary seconds to total time.  A lot of this would be mitigated if we had some pull-up bars outdoors.

Just came home from a pretty sweet climbing sesh =P.  It's super fun and you don't even really realize you're working out until you get to the top and your arms are shaking. The gym part is unlike other gyms, but it's awesome. It has huge monkey bars and climbing ropes, and I'm not strong enough to use most of that stuff, but the climbing keeps me occupied.
Planet Granite is the best.  I love indoor rock climbing here.  Its also one of the few options we got.

Planet Granite is awesome... 70 bucks a month or 18 dollars for a day pass hmm... Awesome place to go for the most part everyone is pretty friendly and up beat. Took there beginning rock climbing class (BRC) and learned alot from it. Ended up meeting the guy I now climb regularly with in the class too. so I certainly recommend it. A section of routes is usually changed at the begining of each week so there is always something to keep you entertained. There is also a full gym inside as well, complete with exercise machines and weights. Tends to get most busy Tuesday and Thursday nights after 6:30PM or so. Weekends are good time to go cause all the "real" climbers are out on day trips, therefore all you have to contend with is little kids parties, but they can actually be pretty entertaining themselves.
lots of fun. employees are very helpful. a bit crowded but over all good vibe and good boldering/ top rope location.

Enjoyed myself and this was possible cuz of the good 20 minute training me and my bff rec'd from the staff person. We went on a week night and there were a lot of people. I appreciated the different rock walls that had various levels of difficulty. On the other side of the building was a gym area. I'd definitely return.

I've been going to PG in Sunnyvale for a couple of years now.  Initially I was looking for a lunchtime Yoga class near my work and found that they were offered here.  The Yoga classes are excellent - really good instructors and an awesome classroom separate from the rest of the gym.  Since then I did join but tend to use the Elliptical and weights more often for my lunch time workout as my job doesn't always allow me to get to the classes on time.  They do a great job of maintaining the equipment and I find that I like the atmosphere better then places like 24 hour - less crowded and noisy and they always have the big doors up for fresh air whenever the weather allows which I really appreciate.My one criticism would be that, for my tastes, it could be a little bit cleaner.  Some areas like the restrooms and Yoga room are spotless.  Other areas like the stretching area in the gym are really dirty and the less used equipment weight machines by the back door are often very dusty.They try to play different kinds of music - some I like and some I really don't but I solved that by just using my Iphone/earphones to provide my own (and drown their's out) when it's not what I like.  I have not yet tried to climb the walls but I do enjoy watching people do it while I work out - it's a nice distraction.

I am a member here.  Planet Granite is the shit.  The difference between this gym and 24 hour fitness and Ballys is that there aren't any meat heads.Their services include bouldering, top roping, yoga, a sauna, lessons and outdoor climbing.  There is also an area for machines and weights.  A great place for beginners or experts. The staff is extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  The demographic here is pretty diverse.  You don't have a bunch of middle aged people trying to stay in shape by going to the gym.  It's mixed here.  You have kids, teens and adults all rock climbing.A really cool place to go workout and meet friends in the Silicon Valley.Come check it out!

I haven't been to a lot of climbing gyms, but this is what a climbing gym should be like!  A lot of walls, ropes, and routes. Many different features and tons of space to go. The highest wall was a great climb!The features are awesome, crack climbing, lead climbing. They even have a ledge which I could not get a handle on cause the shoes just wouldn't stick. The bouldering area was huge and they even had outdoor bouldering.Overall very pleased with this location and looking forward to coming back!

I let my membership here lapse, but this is a great place to work out.  The staff is friendly and it's fun to be at a gym that is different and not so crowded.  This one is much bigger than the one in Belmont, so they have some more room.  The rock climbing walls are great.  They won't have as much equipment as some of the bigger chain gyms, but if you don't care than this is perfect.  I have never had a bad experience here, nor have I been there when it is crazy busy, it's just not as convenient to get to from where I live.

I love this place. The trainers are very friendly (mine was Eva) and the atmosphere is very chill. Wish there were more eating places around though. After a day of climbing I'm hungry. There is a Taco Bell down the street though.

This is the BEST place ever!!! The staff is awesome and super helpful! The have the best climbing walls in the entire area! They have a work out area that emphasizes climbing skills. Yoga classes, a slack line, AMAZING bouldering walls. They have it all!!! They re set their routes all the time, you wont ever get bored with the courses. They have great hours.They have a self help area in the bouldering section so you can work on technique. This is an all around amazing place to train and work out!!! No matter what level you are there is something at Planet Granite for you!!!

The newly opened Planet Granite in Sunnyvale offers the best indoor climbing experience I've seen in the Bay Area. They have over 100 top-rope/lead climbs, a huge bouldering area, the heighest walls in Northern California, a large exercise gym, lots of classes, and soon they will open the climbing walls on the outside of the building.It gets pretty crowded on week nights, but its large so there's always enough routes and bouldering space. The exercise gym is never crowded and has some great machines that aren't at other gyms I've been too. The wall routes are generally creatively set and very enjoyable, though most of the surfaces are flat, which means the top-roping allows for less creativity with your feet.Most of the people there are Silicon Valley engineers. They are a pretty friendly group and people talk with strangers often, though it seems most conversations are either about climbing or engineering. So the general vibe isn't as interesting as Mission Cliffs. So if you are looking to meet new people to connect with over things other than climbing or engineering, you'll have to put in some extra effort.

This place is Awesome!... enough said.  Ok ok I will be more descriptive. This place is large! We spent a good couple of hours here and felt we just touched the surface of the many possible climbs we could journey.  So many routes with all different types of terrain and skill level, many short routes and some very long and high routes (the place is tall), their is a nice amount of bouldering both inside the gym and on the outside walls in a tented area. Apparently they had recently re-routed the place and do so on a pretty regular basis.  There is also a large standard gym area, with weight machines, treadmills, ellipticals etc.Outside the building there is an adult version of monkey bars and a nice picnic area.  A day pass gives you full access to the entire gym which includes showers and towel service.  Much cleaner than other rock climbing gyms I have been to, only slightly smelled like feet and there was very little visible chalk in the air and virtually no dust build up.  You must schedule a belay lesson for new belayers, but if you have already climbed other places it is a simple process to take the belay test and you can always go bouldering.  They use Grigri climb device's and this gym requires a fisherman's knot above the figure 8. We were unfamiliar with the fisherman (it not being required at other gyms we have climbed) and the guy giving us the belay test gladly showed us how it is done.

just getting back into rock climbing and gave pg a chance (after seeing the deal on groupon).  very nice layout, with plenty of walls/boulder, plus the lifting area, clean (but a little tight) change rooms/showers/sauna, yoga/exercise rooms.  i guess everyone else likes it too, cause the place is _packed_ at peak hours, even though the amount of exercise equipment/routes can almost handle it.parking could be difficult as well

I have a love/disappointment relationship with the new Planet Granite.  It is much taller than the old Santa Clara facility, has more, taller and better cracks, the route setting is better than the SC gym was getting and the bouldering area is much bigger and better.  My disappointments are it doesn't have the artificial natural features the old gym had and it feels (and is) more crowded than the old gym.More pluses include the new yoga and spinning rooms, a huge increase in exercise machines and a much larger, roomier exercise area, better weight equipment and better locker room and showering facilities.From a climbing stand point, it's great to finally have a decent indoor lead facility in the south bay.  Although the gym is crowded to the point that sometimes you can't get on a climb you want to do without waiting for a party or two, the climbing is more enjoyable overall.  I am decidedly not a boulderer, but if I do have to boulder because I can't get a partner, the bouldering definitely keeps me interested for well over an hour.I think the gym will improve once the outdoor climbing areas (both top roped and bouldering areas) open up relieving some of the crowding inside.  The gym has been very comfortable temperature wise and with the number of places to open it up, I believe it will remain so even as the temps climb during the summer.

I fell in love wtih rock climbing and joined Planet Granite about a year and a half ago.  I have to say, it just doesn't get any better than this.The staff are friendly, playful and knowledgeable.  The other customers are helpful and work like a community.  They'll give you advice if you want it, or encouragement if you don't want advice.  They'll chat with you while you're belaying.  The rates are about the same as any other climbing gym, but there's no contract to sign here - which is nice.  You can go month to month, and if you're going on vacation or if you get injured, you can put your account on hold for a month.The Sunnyvale location is huge.  There's a lot of outdoor bouldering, which is nice, and quite a lot of lead climbing space.  There's also an entire wall for cracks.I will warn you though - it gets crowded in the evenings!  I go on weeknights and sometimes it's hard to find a route that isn't busy.  :D

SO FUNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNbut  I hear it is expensive (the guy let me in on a guest pass)and be prepared to be in pain for a few days after!The only thing that really hurt in the midst of everything were my hands but a few mornings later my body felt like it was decomposing.Such a great work out, and so many climbing optionsGreat for newbies, veterans, and kids

I went here for a day a climbing a few years ago. It was crowded, but everyone was friendly and there was a good atmosphere. After reading all the other reviews it makes me regret not going here more even though it's not really close to my old house. Climbing made me feel so out of shape I couldn't believe it. The closest thing I could compare it to was the first time I went to a spin class. Challenging and intense but rewarding as well. I loved it, but I wasn't used to thinking about where to position my hands and feet while moving upwards against gravity. Personally, I'm usually more of an elliptical bound gazelle..... Anyway I would recommend it to anyone who wants my recommendation!
