For a complete beginner, Planet Granite had the most helpful staff.  They directed me to sign up for a beginner's belay class (which only had four people / class, so they fill up quick).  As mine was in the afternoon, I started climbing with friends who were already belay certified.After bouldering, we climbed with gradual difficulty.  I tried from 5-2 to 5-8 (which was mostly smearing), and found the courses to generally be well-maintained (except a friend's knob / rock got loose and fell!).  Be sure to go with people whom you trust, as there's nothing more exhilarating than letting go and knowing that you'll be enjoying a smooth ride down.From the smart, well-educated Silicon Valley people to the high-ceiling, spacious facility, I would come here to try out the gym and corresponding non-rock-climbing classes.Can't wait to get belay certified.

I don't really go climbing that much... or at all really. My friend took me here because he works a at a wall and wanted to take us. I went once at hte student center at UCSD, which was amazingly weak compared to this. Probably 1/10th the size. This place is pretty amazing... It has a lot of walls and decent gear. A lot of different challenges, and not very crowded. However the price is a little bit steep for what I would be expecting. It might be worth it to get a monthly pass, but at around 50 bucks I would have to free u my time. The only other bad part about this place is that the service is a bit slow. Our group of 8 took about 1-2 hours to get started and certified because we each had to go through individual testing that took forever. They only had one person helping us at first, and then finally a second person came to help certify us after half of us were through. Other than that, this place is great for indoor climbing in a safe environment, but is a little pricey and the service a little lacking.

LOVE THIS PLACE! Tons of fun to climb and boulder! Gym is decent and clean, locker room is clean. I can actually shower here and they have a decent sauna. Service is good. Not too many overweight and unfit people like at most gyms. Also membership includes yoga, spinning, and crossfit classes! Great place, cancelled my other gym membership and only go here now!

I went back recently to accommodate my friends because they live close by. I must admit that the smell has improved SIGNIFICANTLY and they have expanded outside even further; quite impressive. I stand by the rest of my previous review though.

My prior experience with gyms was limited to one of the big chains.  There's no comparison.  I'm truly happy to be a member here.  I was previously scared off by the price, but when I consider the value of my health, and the other things we spend as much or more money on, it's a great investment in yourself.  Especially when compared to the cost, both monetary and otherwise, of poor health.I didn't think I'd like the bouldering, but I do.  Same goes for the rope-based climbing--it's even more fun than it looks.  My wife and I go during the early mornings, and have our pick of the equipment and rocks.  As mentioned by countless others, don't come on weeknights or weekend afternoons / evenings, unless you actually want to be in a big crowd.What makes this a 5-star establishment is the staff.  We had some doubts about shoe fit, harness, etc. and they were friendly in clearing things up for us newbies.  And when I had a mishap (nothing to do with climbing, but pushing myself too much on the weights), a couple of staff looked out for me to make sure I was alright.

Yea! First time here, really enjoyed my time. Lots of people on a Saturday afternoon, but not a lot of waiting around, this place is fully staffed and lots of rock wall to climb! It did smell when I first walk in, then you get used to it, it's ok....The floor is bouncy, so it's fun even if you are just walking around...but remember to look up, just in case. Decently priced, not too expensive in my view. They provide towels in the bathroom for you to shower. I would highly recommend this place!

I love this place!  The staff are all young, energetic and friendly.I took the Beginner's Rock Climbing (BRC) a month ago and fell in love with climbing.  Climbing is such a great workout, and I always feel so energetic and exhilarated after wards.They also have a small gym  with cardio and weight machines, and a pretty decent sized mat with lots of abs equipment and Russian weights.  I mainly use the Bosu, weighted medicine balls, and different sized medicine balls for ab work.  They also have two workout rooms for yoga class and one for spinning class.  Their instructors are extremely courteous and helpful.  Their facility in Belmont is also nice too.I live by a 24 hour fitness, and am locked down to a 3 year membership, but I would rather drive the extra miles to use the gym and attend the classes here than 24!

I went here mainly to get a solid working knowledge of the fundamentals of rock climbing. I took the Beginner's Rock Climbing course which teaches you rock climbing and bouldering techniques and how to properly belay. There are four 2-hour sessions done once a week with a small class size (I think 4-8 people) and one instructor. In addition to the lessons, you get full access to the exercise gym (with all the free weights and machines you'd want), access to classes (like yoga), and access to climbing anytime during those weeks all for $120.My teacher was David. He emphasized how footwork is more important than brute upper body strength and how you have to "dance" on the wall (I believe he was a dance major). I saw other instructors teaching and, from what I saw, you really can't go wrong with any of them because they all seem like very cool people who are passionate about the sport.
I have been a rock climber for 34 years and the Sunnyvale Planet granite is by far the most diverse and interesting climbing in the bay area

Great place for climbing. The membership fee feels a little steep, but they do offer a lot in terms of gym equipment, yoga and, of course, climbing...so that costs money I guess. Anyways, they have great routes, high walls and plenty of places to climb even when they're crowded. I also like their attitude overall: for example, once I brought a guest and she didn't have her driver's license - well, they let her climb anyways. Once I went in and didn't have my card and instead of asking for ID, etc, etc, they just asked me my name and let me through - no hassles like at the 24 hr Nautalis. Once I came in and forgot my harness...again, they just lent me one, no charge. So it just leaves a good taste in your mouth like they are not out to get every last penny out of you - they just want you to have a good time. Maybe they don't really fell that way, but I felt like they did and I always appreciate that in a business.I've never been a yoga kind of person, but I did start doing that and it is fun and a good work out overall. I tend to go right after work with 2 of my buddies on Monday and it's not too crowded. I hear Fridays can be very crowded. It's also not that great coming with 2 other guys because we always have to find a belay partner for the third guy! Oh well ;)

This new facility is an improvement on the old Santa Clara one, but I still prefer the Belmont Location. Up there the walls are more naturally shaped and the layout is a bit nicer. When I was there it looked like the outdoor section was closed, so I didn't really get to see that, but I think I prefer climbing man-made walls indoors because then you don't have to worry about pesky things like sunscreen.

If you're thinking of using Planet Granite for an event, read this:I set up a corporate event at Planet Granite, and my pre-event discussions with Mike, the gym floor manager, were short, sweet and productive. Definitely a great experience from first call to final invoice. Five stars for the management.Once we got there for our 3-5pm event, I was a little slack-jawed. The place is enormous, with dozens of faces for climbing and bouldering. There were easily another 20 people there while our 20-person group was climbing. Were I to do it again, I'd skip the 'team building' section they offer, since it ate up time and was a bit cheesy to boot (human chain unraveling and something else I can't even describe akin to Handshake Mafia).However, once we got climbing, I thought the trip was worthwhile. Our 20-person group was broken up into 3 smaller ones, and we each headed to a different piece of the rock wall. My only regret is that our mini-group headed to the other end of the gym, so we didn't get to cheer on our other teammates. We got a very nuts-and-bolts walkthrough of harnesses, knots and carabiners by Zeke, our instructor, and afterwards, all 7 of us got to climb and belay at least once. It wasn't much more than a taste of rockclimbing, but in the time we had, it was appropriate.Props to the team, who allowed us to run over our allotted time since we started late (our error, not theirs).

I love Planet Granite.  I never use the climbing area or take any classes, so this review is only for the fitness and cardio areas.The cardio machines are of good quality, and it's extremely rare that every cardio machine of a given type is taken, even at 7pm on Wednesdays.  Sometimes some of the treadmills are out of order, though, which can be annoying.  They have a wide variety of cardio equipment: treadmills, several kinds of ellipticals, several kinds of bikes, and stairmasters.But what I really love is the free weight area.  Probably due to the influence of the CrossFit classes they host, they have a LOT of barbells (of several sizes), a LOT of plates, and a LOT of racks.  They still only have one power cage, but hey.  They also don't have enough benches or dumbbells, but again, hey.  The bars and plates are all of pretty good quality.  The weight machines are also pretty good: there's a good selection, and they are well maintained.  If they do happen to be creaky the staff is happy to oil them for you.The opening hours are also very good: on weekdays they open early and close late.  There are no bullshit rules of conduct, and the staff is very friendly.The drawback: it can get very crowded on weeknights (which is why I mostly go in the morning, when it's almost completely empty).  Some of the patrons in the free weights area are pretty obnoxious, and do things like literally throw a loaded barbell down on the floor from above their head.  When a CrossFit class is in session, which is most weeknights for an hour or two, it's practically impossible to navigate the weights area.

Awesome place for indoor wall climbing!  Lots and lots of courses of varying difficulty, with some reaching very, very high on the wall opposite of the entrance.  I love that they have gri-gris at each course so you don't have to lug around your own below device.  It's also so big here that it hardly ever gets completely saturated and you usually don't have to wait too long to tie in.  While this place may be awesome for climbing, it's below average as a gym.  I don't understand the concept of combining climbing with typical gym equipment and yoga.  Almost any 24 Hour Fitness will have way better gym equipment and classes, so why make the climbers subsidize the other lackluster facilities?  Climbing is already a relatively expensive hobby, so please isolate your services and reduce the price to climb ($17/day for $16 if you get a ten pack).  Beware of getting a ten pack - for some strange, strange reason, they don't log it into their systems so you have to carry around a small card in your wallet that's initially worth $160.  Why oh why would you make people do this if you have a computer system?!?!

I picked up rock climbing recently and really enjoy it! My second time was here at Planet Granite Sunnyvale and really enjoyed my experience. The facility is very big and spacious, and has different rocks for all levels. The only downside to it is that it does get pretty smelly...mostly of the chalk, but sometimes sweat as well =/ The gear that they give you a bit on the older side, compared to the other place I've been to. it is also slightly pricey, but hey...rockclimbing is a pricey sport! It's very close to my house so I would definitely come back, hopefully on a monthly basis :)

A lot of people I know consider Planet Granite to be too corporate, "the man" basically, as opposed to other more independent gyms in the Bay. Essentially, they are right -- this gym is a bit more crowded, corporate and impersonal than some -- but the consequence of this is that the place is rich and swanky enough to make City Beach and Twisters look like third world countries to PG's United States. The chain, and especially Sunnyvale and SF gyms, has the resources available to provide a great all-around experience for climbers and fitness addicts. In terms of climbing, PG Sunnyvale offers some of the most consistent ratings I have ever seen. I find the TR ratings to be pretty inflated overall and I'm not crazy about all the routesetting in this area, but the bouldering available is amazing and utilizes a great diversity of techniques. The crowd here is full of scary-amazing climbers as well as newbies, and the diversity of routes is good, with lots of routes at every level from V0 to ridiculous slope-y overhanging 10s and 11s.The yoga and other classes available are great too. I have not had a bad experience in any class but Jill's yoga class was especially good and more strenuous than the others I've tried. They also offer crossfit, abs classes, and full body conditioning.This places loses a star for me only because it is just so crowded in the evenings and peak hours and because prices are incredibly high if you do not have membership. However during weekday work hours PG is beautifully empty, and with a membership the many resources the gym has to offer make entrance well worthwhile.

Here are the three biggest reasons why I love love love PG (and you should too):1) Staff: the staff are all incredibly nice and knowledgeable.  New to climbing?  No problem, just toddle up to the front desk and ask for advice/directions how to climb a route/whatever.  2) Half naked people: yeah, there are about five hundred million very fit, very half naked people climbing, running, working out, etc. all the time.  Word to the scenery at PG San Francisco...I'll take this scenery any day =)  Also, a lot of these half naked people are engineers, marketing people, and other silicon valley professionals.  Forget about meeting for a power lunch at the Starbucks, it's all about a power climb at PG during your lunch hour now.  No joke.3) Bouldering: I'm pretty much an exclusive boulderer, so I have a major hard on (metaphorically speaking) for PG's bouldering routes.  They have a lot of beginner climbs, and the bouldering is split in two, with half being outside and half being inside.  My only warning is that the pads outside are less forgiving.  Outside will usually be almost empty, even on weekday nights when the inside is packed.  I'm going climbing tonight, and I will count how many bouldering routes there are, inside and outside, but there have to be at least fifty.  As a side note, the people who climb at PG are incredible.  I've been to several other gyms, but nowhere else have I found a community that is as friendly, helpful, and just gosh darn  fun to climb with.

I've had a good time every time I've climbed here. This has the best climbs around, and there are plenty of them. Only reason I gave this place a 4 instead of 5 is because of all the grown ass men who take their shirts off.

I love this gym, I am a member as of January. I signed up as a member when they had the special of no initiation fee, and as a student I only pay $53 a month. The membership is great, you can go to any of their gyms, I go to Sunnyvale, but I have also gone to the one in belmont a few times. And I love the fact that they have events for their members, for example they have some movie nights, competitions, events to meet new climbers, I've also been to a fundraiser where they held an auction and raised about $17,000..i think, for unlock jailhouse. I love my gym, I hear there is a touchstone opening up in san jose, even though it might be closer I will stay with planet granite!

This update is really kind of long overdue.  In the span of time since my last update, Michelle was very pro-active in contacting me and wanting to know my concerns.  She let me know the specific ways that she will address the issues that I raised, and she was extremely friendly and good-natured in the process.  I really appreciated her response, and felt listened-to.  That's really all you can ask for from customer service, and anyone who goes out of their way to respond the way she did really deserves all five stars.

So I got kind of tired of working out in the cubicle sized workout room at our apartment complex and decided it was time to try something new...not to mention more fun. I noticed "Planet Granite" just down the street and having climbed at one of these rock gym's before in ATL, I figured we might as well try it. We had to take the intro course to learn how to belay, but once we passed we were free to take advantage of all the gym has to offer. I am a big fan of Planet Granite. The facility is HUGE and has a wide variety of climbs. It's been pretty busy the few times we have gone, but since the gym is so big and has so many walls you really don't have to wait. Once you go, it becomes kind of addicting. There's also an extensive workout area that seems nice with decent machines. The only problem I have with PG is the fact that it is so expensive. It's $18 for a day pass, plus another $6 for a harness and shoes. We can't make it a regular thing, which is a bummer since it's so much fun and so good for you. But if you have some extra cash and want to do something fun, relaxing, and good for you, go to Planet Granite.

i'm definitely a fan of planet granite (PG for short), but the two primary reasons it isnt my primary choice of climbing gyms is:- it's far for me (i'm in fremont, which i wont count against them)- it's expensive ($18 each time or $72/mo - i believe)with that said, this gym is the best equipped facility in the south bay hands down. i climb at city beach, a smaller $30/mo place in fremont, but it's not nearly as big or the routes change as often.PG has decent staff - seems friendly and not stand-off-ish.PG also offers a short class on how to belay. I dont know much about it because I didnt take it. I do know you have to schedule at least a day ahead because spots actually get taken up. Usually they're at 6:30p and/or 7:30p. Once you do the belay class, you get a temporary belay card so you can practice on your guinea pig friends. the belay device are supposedly self-locking, not the bare-bones ATC's. you can also just walk in and take the belay test (for certification) w/o scheduling. you cannot, however, take it after you climbed earlier that day. you must take it right when you come in.certification is needed for lead climbing too.there is a pretty huge bouldering section with plenty of tough (V6 and up) routes and a good cluster of V0-V2/3 sections for newer climbers. there is a training section for exercises too between the bouldering and top-roping section. there is quite a variation in route heights for top-roping - some are fairly short (in the back, called the "ice box") and some are quite high (in the middle of the gym). you can boulder outside too - well padded ground with rubber chunks. there's a campus board inside and outside. actually, there are multiple campus and rungs. they have cardio machines and weights - not dinky either. there are plenty of bars to do pull ups, rings, another board, shower room, lockers... very cleanly maintained too. the front has a small gear store from shoes, crash pads, carabiners, harnesses, chalk bags, atc's, etc. i think ropes too! anyway, pg is pretty well equipped. i guess i understand why it's $18. but it's still a lot. i climb there once or twice a month with friends who are members there. sometimes there's quite a bit of traffic after work hours, but nothing that's too crazy.one thing that i see that PG does not have that city beach (my gym) has are classes for kids. maybe i am wrong, but at city beach they have programs for kids. it's pretty community-based. if you're a regular, people will know your name. PG is a bit different, catering to a larger area. but it's certainly not the only climbing gym in the south bay.

Awesome climbing gym. I was a member here for a couple of years and I haven't found a gym this good since. The abs classes are tough, the spin classes are intense and the climbing walls are the best in the Bay. It can get pretty packed in the evenings, so plan accordingly. There's not a lot of meatheads like the usual gym, so you can actually use the weights when you want to. Just be prepared for the smell of sweaty climbers in the evening.

i came here a couple weeks ago with other yelpers and it was a good time. i haven't been rock climbing since....oh gosh...2004? i think. so this was a trip for me. mikey u. and his bestie were the ones who were the certified belayers so they belayed us like no other. belay here. belay there. belay everywhere a belay. it was really great of them to too.the routes were pretty fun. some of them i found challenging and others were slightly easy. the locker was pretty nice. very clean. bring your own lock if you plan to use them. the harnesses and shoes they provide you for $6 if you rent both of them otherwise, it's $4 for one or the other. they are just your average harness and shoes. nothing too special since the ones who rent them are newbies and will mess up nice shoes real fast. i'd suggest wearing thin socks while climbing in the rented shoes since they are similar to bowling shoes where they get sprayed after every use.i'm planning on going back for a belay lesson since the bf and i are in a movement to be more physically active. not to mention we just got harnesses and shoes! PM if you'd like to join!see you out there!

the equipment here is great. Everything you want is here. Only crappy part is the staff, they must get paid pretty bad here because most of them are extremely unfriendly. Especially the middle aged lady that works in the front.

I have not gone rock climbing for awhile since I hurt my arm.  My arm has been feeling good lately so I thought why not try it again.  I really try to push myself this time and you can see the bruises on my right knee and my back has been sore. Thanks to the encouragement and help from Jackie and Mikey that I was able to make it over 5.6.  Yes it doesn't sound like a 5.6 is hard but hard enough for me.  I should take a belay class and try to see if i can get pass a 5.7.

i went here with a bunch of other yelpers (hey y'all!) for my first time rock climbing. four of us took the belay class (a nice small group!), which was really great. it was an hour long and we got a wonderful introduction to the equipment, setting it all up, and of course, safety. then we each got a climb+belay in. karen (i think her name was?) was a great instructor, making sure we got everything down pat. it was a bit rushed at an hour long, but i think we started late. in any case, after the class i felt very prepared to go climbing on my own and to belay for others.there seemed to be a nice range of difficulties, although there was a dearth of easy-to-mid ones. that said, it sort of makes sense since i think you can progress through the easy levels relatively quickly. by 7 or 8 in the evening, though, it was quite busy and it seemed like there weren't enough of *any* difficulty level. other than the climbing walls and the bouldering, there's also cardio and strength equipment.

I went to this gym for at least two years while living in Sunnyvale and it was the best investment I made, compared to Gold's and 24 hour this is a classy, no nonsense gym. I get to rock climb when I want plus their core/abs workouts are kick ass. I actually saw cuts in my abs after 1 year of their core classes. Their spinning is wonderful and Carol is their best instructor for abs and spinning. I wish they had Zumba as well for cardio variety but it sounds like they gear their workouts towards activities that help with climbing. I'm with 24 hour fitness in San Francisco now and it's so appalling I'm writing a separate review for that. :)
Really love this place - great yoga classes and different levels for rock climbing. The only reason I didn't give it all five stars is because it is expensive.

Went here for a corporate event, and our two teachers were great!  I was beyond scared and our trainer (I think his name was Luke? - we split up into two groups) was super nice and patient with me.  He even convinced me to try a real wall (versus the super easy training wall that we initially went on) and even belayed for me!  The place itself is great - pretty big, massive walls and lots to choose from.  We were luckily there in the afternoon so there was practically no one there, but when we were leaving around 4:30pm it was already definitely starting to fill up.  Overall, great place, super nice instructors!

As a former member of Touchstone San Jose becoming a member of Planet Granite was at first appalling. The overly corporate atmosphere and horrible route setting completely destroyed my desire to rock climb. But over the last 2 years PG has really made some marked improvements especially with the revamping of their route setting team and the new addition of an awesome outdoor bouldering area. The routes are changed with enough frequency to keep the climbing interesting and are a much better quality than they were a few years ago. For inexperienced climbers, there is plenty of beginner terrain in both the bouldering and top rope areas as well as classes on climbing basics, safety and belaying. For more experienced climbers looking to break a plateau or build endurance, Mike and Art coach a 6 week long, ball busting training class! The fitness classes offered at PG are also fantastic. The abs 'n core and spin classes taught by Carol are phenomenal! The variety and frequency of Yoga classes is also outstanding. Formerly the desk staff was unfriendly and lacked fundamental knowledge of rock climbing, but that too has changed for the most part.I applaud PG for the incredible improvements they have made and highly recommend it. One major downfall that cannot be changed by PG staff - the gym is ALWAYS COLD! Keep that in mind and bring a sweater

Great facility, lots of exrecise options. kid friendly and climbers are genuinely nice, helpful, and healthy people.  Lots of classes to get you into climbing also.  Ladies locker room is clean and has a sauna.

This is a pretty cool place to go climbing. I had never gone before until the girlfriend suggested we go. I didn't think I would like it because it would be so easy. Turns out I'm not that bad at it and it is a bit of a challenge. The staff is nice. A bad thing about this place is that it gets way too busy during the evening time. I would prefer climbing with less people. I took the belay test and it was helpful. I was $34 for one hour of learning how to tie yourself into the ropes and belay device.

I'm not totally sold on the 'best climbing gym' award. 17 for day pass and 3 for the sketchy harness. About the harness later.Yes, they have good bouldering. Yes, they have outdoor bouldering, which is cool and lets some nice, fresh air in.The locker room is impressively clean and there is even a dry sauna and fresh, clean towels.However, it's a very frustrating place if you've never been there before for the whole reason for going.....climbing. Their orientation sucketh.I've never used a "Gri-Gri" before for belaying and I really wanted them to show me the difference before I even started. I've been trained in my profession to get an orientation to the equipment before I even get tested on it. It's common sense. Instead, they said to read this instruction set on an I beam and wouldn't help me. Okay, I look at it, but I'm used to going to Mission Cliffs where they actually SHOW you how to do it. There was a nice member with his kid who was willing to show me, but they have a policy against it, yet the staff are not so willing to show a new gal the ropes. Literally. So how am I gonna learn what they want, which is of course the standard double figure eight knot and they also want a double fisherman's knot at the top? SHOW ME.  So finally the belay tester could see I was frustrated and finally helped me after being there for thirty minutes, trying to get one staff member to help me. Their harnesses are different too. Their harnesses to rent are cumbersome, appear well-worn and frayed. They appear sketchy at best. They are the single on the side and they have this awkward clip thing that makes a kinda g-string. Their is only a single loop to attach your whole body weight to and that seemed sketchy at best. I asked for another one, but he said they are all like that. Mission Cliffs has better rent harnesses that are doubled and there are two spots to connect the harness which is much safer. The ropes seemed over- used too. They have interesting top rope configurations and lots of tall ones and the gym is nice too. An hour later, I finally got a belay partner who was nice enough to let me be a monkey. He let me try some 5.9s which were good, but the harness, oh that damn harness. Even with the stupid piece of crap harness I did do the 5.9. The best thing about Planet Granite is the members. They are pretty chill and cool. My gripe that brought the star level down is that their orientation to new people needs work and they really need to consider raising the bar with their "Beginner" equipment. I guess I'm not good enough for them to invest in a better one. I think I'll try again Thursday if I'm in the mood, but I think for the same price, Mission Cliffs is much better and I feel safer.

Came here for a Groupon I had for a belay class.  I was surprised it was so busy on a random Tuesday night and it was probably more crowded since it looked like they were still redoing one of the bouldering areas.  I usually go to City Beach since it's down the street from where I work but if I was around here I'd definitely go here.  There is more challenging areas but i'm still a newbie so it's overwhelming.  But generally speaking everyone is super nice here from the people that work there to the actual climbers.  One big plus is that there are more adults than children in comparison to City Beach so there's more of a "organized" atmosphere but it's still a little claustraphobic for me.  Even at the other place I like it when the place is empty so it's less noise and more space to move without fear of running into someone.  But overall a place I'd go to again and/or think of joining if I get tired of City Beach.

So I haven't gone climbing for a few years now. I got really into it while in college to get over a fear of heights and just grew to really enjoy it.  I then stopped after a bad fall scared me to death and it took me almost 4 years to come back to even try it again. That being said, Planet Granite was probably the best place I could have come to return to the activity I love so much.I mean it's really fun, it really seems to scale well (from really early beginners to really advanced climbers) and it's safe. PG supplies gri-gris for pretty much every route. So I feel much safer than trusting people with an atc. Not fool proof, but a little more forgiving :) This location is my primay location which I like a lot. It has a good mix of bouldering courses and some really interesting top rope courses. They even will open out the little outside area in the back sometimes and expand some courses there too. The staff here are really nice and they will answer any question you might have. They take their time with you and really want you to enjoy your experience. I am still a beginner but I don't feel intimidated here at all.  Sometimes this place is a little relaxed on the consistency of their rating of routes but it balances out. Sometimes I master something 1 levels higher than what I am normally comfortable with, and sometimes something 1 level lower than my norm destroys me :) I find it keeps me on my toes. They seem to change up the routes every 2 - 4 weeks as well so you can practice a route pretty well before it is moved to a different configuration.

Love this Rock climbing/xfit gym.  Hugh, and the have all levels of difficulty.  The people who come here are nice too making the experience even more awesome. The staffs are attentive and helpful.  Always have a great time here.
great staff! fun times.  great workout.  They have a great selection of climbs.  Its a little pricey, but we don't go too often so its ok.  Would probably go more often if it was cheaper.

forget 24 hour fitness or the y. workout in a massive, hangar type building, with free towels instead. love this place. love it. note, the free yoga classes are really superb! i recommend william's vinyasa class. It's a real 1 1/2 hour (usually longer) sweat marathon that works out all your muscles. there are some intense yogis in the class too. they also have cross-training and spinning classes (cross training is $10 but spinning is free- and GOOD). if you live anywhere in the area and like 1) rock climbing2) working out in a gym3) yoga4) spinningyou must join.  a $65 monthly membership gets you ALL of that, unlimited! best deal ever! (even if you only like two out of those things, i mean, a $65 membership is amazing. it's cheaper than my local y for eg).

Really a top notch fitness facility.  Not only do they have a full climbing and bouldering walls, but the facility also has the standard fitness gym essentials including cardio machines and free weights.  The staff is always friendly and most of the gym members and patrons are nice folks, not always the case when you hit the local gym.  I recently took the beginning class after taking several years off from climbing and was pleasantly surprised by how quickly I picked things up again.  As always, the gym can get packed during peak hours.  However, sometimes it's majestic, entertaining, and just inspiring to watch some of the more skilled climbers ascend the walls.  If only they had more locations, I would seriously consider replacing my gym membership but until then, I'll stick to daily passes to mix up my workout routine.

No place better. Come here at least 4 days a week to boulder and do some top rope. $73/ month for a membership is kinda steep but, it's worth it in the end when you are paying $19 for each day pass. I would recommend PG Sunnyvale to anyone.

Okay so I have totally mixed feelings about this place. I have been going here for about two years now and over the years I have realized that this is a great gym for climbing with lots of bouldering problems, but the "scene" is not really for me. They have two areas for bouldering, one inside and one (remodeled) outside. I absolutely love the outdoor wall, it is so good for training! It is pretty over hanging and always has (in my opinion) the best climbs. Another perk of pg is the awesome yoga/abs classes, I have  not gone to a single abs class where I did not get my ass handed to me. Love it! They do also have an awesome fitness/work out area which also offers crossfit classes. I have never taken advantage of them so I cannot really comment on them, but everyone who takes them gets super strong. So the downsides of this place are some of the staff can be pretty cold sometimes. I am friends with the majority of the staff but there are a selected few who are very arrogant and I don't like that. It is also fairly expensive. Also I tend to have issues with the boulder problems (being 5 ft tall) since the shortest setter is about 5'6". I wish they had a girl setter but hey what can you do.

Great place to rock climb!  I've been there a few times, the one catch is that you have to either take a belay class or pass the belay test in order to belay, otherwise you climb off the mercy of others :)

Ever since my friend invited us to climb for the first time last Dec. i was hooked. Me and my girlfriend immediately purchased a membership and decided to make a commitment out of it. The Sunnyvale location is my favorite out of the three gyms. #1 Its the largest facility #2 great design of the climbs both bouldering and roping area #3 Great staff and climbing cronies that you'll get to meet! Obviously the membership gives you access to a lot of things such as free lessons on climbing classes, yoga and even circuit/workout training sessions and don't forget the full workout gym with pro equipment along with free weights. Did i mention a Sauna as well? Haven't stopped climbing since and lots of evenings are spent here climbing till the gym closes @11pm Fingers hurt from this new commitment but its pain well tolerated and gladly accepted :)

this place rocks (no pun intended, hardy har har)!  the staff is always friendly, and they even have a pair of nail clippers you can borrow at the front desk (these things have prolly been used over a bajillion times, so don't expect a clean cut, but it's good for a quick fix).the facilities include not only rock climibing surfaces (duh!), but also a full gym and locker rooms.  there is even a sauna (i haven't used it yet, cuz i'm usually too tired and hungry when i get done climbing).  they also conveniently have climbing gear and equipment for sale near the front desk, and they have some pretty good deals as well.  i don't want a membership, so i just pay for each day use. they have a 10 day pack for $160.the first time i came here i got sponsored, cuz my friend has a membership here, so my lesson was free and my entrance fee was waived.  after the lesson, they offer you a 5 pack for $50.  they also offer you a deal on equipment - harness, shoes, chalk bag, and chalk for about $120.  to buy all the equipment separately would be over $200, so i say go for it :)  now you can explain to people the REAL reason why your forearms are so big hahahhaha.

The gym and fitness equipment here are nicer than at Belmont, and it's fun to watch the climbers when you're on the cardio machines. However, the real reason I go to PG is for the climbing.  The gym has a good variety of routes -- a bit of something for everyone, from the kiddie routes to the 5.12+ climbs with long overhangs.  Some of the walls are 60' tall, so you can really work your endurance on those climbs.  There are a lot of routes here (more than at Belmont, I'm pretty sure), plus lots of them are leadable.  The slab walls don't have the natural contours that the walls in Belmont have, however. The staff are friendly and approachable, and the people who climb here are a friendly bunch.  I've made some good friends (and climbing partners) here. The main downside of PG Sunnyvale is that it gets incredibly crowded here on weeknights.  If you're trying to find a 5.10b or easier climb, there's a very good chance you'll have to wait for the people who are on it, as well as the next group queued up for it.  You can avoid the crowds by coming in the afternoon on a weekday, Friday night, or Saturday or Sunday morning.

i come to this gym twice a week. it is definitely one of the highlights of my week. the staff is playful and friendly. be aware that the place is always packed on week nights. the 5:45 yoga class fills up quickly as well. this is one of my favorite places to take a girl on a date. not only can i see her adventurous side, a lot of trust is also built up from knowing that your partner is in charge of your life or death. she gets mad points if she goes :)

Great fun, but really pricey. I think I paid $22 to climb with shoe rental. They have package deals and memberships, but it's still not cheap at all. I enjoy it a lot, but my $24 a month Supersport gym membership is probably 1/10th as cheap as this. Plus I do so many other sports I only go here 4 times a year which is perfect for me. It is a fun time though and your fingers will hurt in a good way. Make sure you try to jump and blind catch the next rock it's great fun, and if you miss, oh well... that's what the belay and belt are for!

i have not been here in a long time because i moved. i just found out they have a location by my work so i will be renewing my membership...nothing like yoga and cycling classes, full gym access, and indoor rock climbing for 65 bucks a month.  it's totally worth it and you meet some really great people by the ropes. watch out for the ones that got their nose up the air because they climb a 5.13d and you are only at a 5.10a. the only thing is that if you climb, you'll need a partner.minus one star for the stinky doods with no deodorant and no air conditioning.

The newly renovated gym is very swanky. The new locker rooms are clean and spacious. The free towel service is convenient. If I lived close by and didn't have 24hr fitness (corporate discount is too tempting), I would get a membership and use it as a workout gym as well as a climbing gym.The climbing area has good variety. The routes are endless, the longest I've seen of any gym. The walls have many features that make for interesting climbs. The bouldering routes are more difficult than other gyms. Very few bouldering foutes are suitable for beginners.An irritating thing about PG is that some of the staff are a-holes to beginners. They absolutely will not allow you to teach someone how to belay on their equipment because they want you to take their $30 belay class. I understand where they're coming from, but I wish they'd be a little more relaxed about the whole thing. Does the job orientation involve placing a stick up their a**?

I used to drive to the Sierras almost every weekend to go climbingbut with global warming I could not justify burning that much gas.This gym alows me to keep climbing without nearly as much impacton the planet.  I can hit it after work on my way home and get myvertical fix.  There are enough routes here and they change them enough thatI don't get bored.Love the new layout compared to the old location for this gym inSanta Clara.  I have brought friends from work here just to check outthe walls inside.
I got my start here a decade ago, back when the gym was at Bowers and El Camino.  Great facility, friendly staff, and very convenient (multiple locations, open 6 am to 11 pm).

its small here..lots of climbing..nice equipment..staff was ok in hospitality..didnt ask us if we needed anything..u hav to ask the questions..one thing before u start to work out...put on some deodarant pls..thanks

Great rock climbing and bouldering place. Routes changes frequently and offer something for anybody. Saturdays are quite busy. I would be there more often if the cost wasn't that high (I believe it's $18 per person, and you obviously need two people).

I belong to the SF gym, but have gone twice to the Sunnyvale gym to shake it up a bit. It's a really cool facility still and even has an outdoor bouldering area, which is super awesome. It has lots of great climbing, especially lead climbing, but it only gets four stars out of five because it feels a bit faded and dingy compared to my brand spanking new gym in the city. If I had never been to the SF gym, it'd get 5 out of 5 easy. But hey, I am totally biased and love my gym!

I caught PG Sunnyvale's grand opening this weekend.  The new location is, I'm fairly certain, taller than the now-closed Santa Clara location, and the bouldering area is significantly bigger.  The walls are almost completely made up of flat faces, not a lot of natural holds, though there is a crack-climbing area.  There are some spots where you can climb in corners, but not as much as at Santa Clara.  They also have a half-serious set of weight training equipment, which is an improvement.  They say they're building an outdoor climbing area too, which I didn't see.

Planet Granite offers friendly staff ready to help customers of different level of expertise, clean facility, spacious locker room and abundant supply of clean towels. If you never tried rock climbing before and wants to give rock climbing a try, this is a great place to be, there's a whole wall dedicated to the newbies (look for green rocks on the wall). I also recommend their classes where you learn how to work the rope and immediately apply your knowledge.

love this place.visited once with daughter but was not able to take advantage of the membership yet.love the yoga and the fun atmosphere.love the shower - clean.love the work out room - serious and not 24hrs like.people were very nice.Daughter only did bouldering for an hour but LOVED IT.We will return as soon as we get belay trained...

This is definitely a quality rock climbing gym.  There are huge walls, short walls, of all different difficulty levels.  The only thing I can't get used to is how insanely crowded it gets on weekday nights.  I get so claustrophobic.  Other than that, I highly recommend this gym!

Phenomenal! This is coming from a person who doesn't know anything else about indoor rock climbing, but I loved it. It cost my boyfriend and I each $29 to get a belay lesson and climb for the whole day. The walls were tons of fun to climb, and I think I may have found a fun new way to exercise...

Great facilities! Plenty of walls and boulders to choose from. Roomy locker room. Very friendly staff. Mostly younger crowd (mid 20s/30s). Can get a bit crowded on weeknights. If only the treadmills had TVs! :)

Great rock climbing place! This place has a lot of climbing and bouldering space with high ceilings. The climbs are definitely challenging! The equipment is good and there are a lot of climbing ropes. This place also has a good sized work out gym with treadmills, precors, weight machines etc. The locker room is well kept. They also have a yoga class here. The staff is pretty friendly and nice. My friend has a membership here and took me as her guest, I just paid $3 for harness rental if you don't have one. Great place for hanging out with friends and getting a bit of exercise :)
The best indoor climbing in the bay area.  HUGE toproping and leading and awesome cracks.  Not much else needs to be said.

This place is huge and has lots of facilities and classes. Size does matter sometimes. There is a full set of fitness equipment and weights which i rarely use.  Usually, I come here for the climbing.  There are a lot routes to climb which change regularly. There are also some long routes. There are a lot of classes for the yoga classes which makes it easy to fit in my schedule.  Although this place is great there are some downsides.  It is expensive(not sure how it compares to other climbing gyms) and the place gets crowded (hard to find a locker at peak times).  I hear the PG San Francisco will be even better.  Too bad it is so far away.

I dig this rock climbing gym.  It's got plenty of routes, good rental gear (the harnesses are simple and obvious, and the grigri autolocks, which are great for newbies like me), a crack climbing area, etc.  It's one of the places I've been frequenting since I've started rock climbing, and I've enjoyed it.  There have only been two negatives:  it's bloody crowded (it doesn't clear out after after 9pm on weeknights, which makes it rough for me to get enough climbs in before heading back to SF) and the staff their gave my friend crap for teaching us belaying himself rather than having us take a course.

As a begginner, i learned alot from this place. they have regular belay classes here.it does get pretty pricey here but they do offer price specials so sign up quickly when they do come up as this classes do get filled up.the best time for me to come here is usually just after lunch when the place is practically empty.but if you wanna network and socialize, coming in the evening is for you.they also have free weights and some treadmills.staff is very friendly and helpful.

I took the beginning climbing class with Cam at PG, and he was fantastic.  ALL of the staff members I've dealt with have been very personable.  The climbing part of the gym itself is super impressive with lots of bouldering for the strong-of-hand, and lots of very high top-roping.  The gym section has tons of treadmills and stuff, and is never too crowded on week nights.  The other clientele are generally pretty great, and I generally don't have trouble finding something at my level to climb.  Their climbing equipment store actually has pretty reasonable prices.  Their beginning climbers package actually cost less than what I would have paid for the same gear at REI.If you haven't tried climbing before, I suggest you call them and register for the belay class.  They'll teach you the basics about keeping your friends safe, and you'll be able to get your belay card so you can explore more of the gym on your next visit!
Great spot with discounts but more than enough to keep you entertained. Easy and harder courses so a great rock climbing spot if you're up for something newer to most.

I've been a member for about 10 months now and I think Planet Granite is great. For the south bay, this is it for indoor rock climbing. I really dont' know any other places nearby for this kind of thing. I think there is one in Fremont but I would bet it's not as well equipped as PG. I mostly do boulders and they have tons of bouldering stuff you can do including an outdoor bouldering space, although right now it's being reconstructed. With membership, the yoga classes are free and yoga really complements your rock climbing skills. I've done yoga by video and that just doesn't cut it. It's so boring w/o the class. I pay monthly membership which is 70 bucks. It's pretty expensive I think. But I make it worth while by going often and taking advantage of everything they have to offer: bouldering, top roping, sauna, yoga classes, weight lifting. Theyre packed on weeknights, which is when I usually go as well. It seems like a lot of the young silicon valley generation come here after work. I've also gone to PG Belmont and SF. the SF one is pretty rad. The Belmont one is smaller but fun once in awhile when you get tired of the same walls in Sunnyvale.

I'm new to rock climbing and happily addicted; partially thanks to the awesomeness of Planet Granite.  I took the beginning rock climbing class (aka BRC) with some friends and it is a great introduction to the sport.  The BRC consists of 4, two hour classes, during which you learn the basics.  The price is about $130 and that includes instruction, equipment on the lesson days, and total access to the gym and climbing areas during that month period.  Pretty damn good deal.  Our instructor, Cameron, was knowledgeable, fun and extremely helpful.  In fact most people that work here are passionate about climbing and friendly; which makes for a very positive environment.  Not only do they have a large climbing areas (ropes and bouldering) but a complete gym with cardio machines, weights, and classes (yoga and cycling).   I do not have a lot of experience with the classes yet, but the people attending and the instructors look pretty fit.  Membership prices are reasonable too (~$65 per month) which is pretty good considering your very basic YMCA in PA is $75.  The only problem I have encountered with PG is it does get crowded (the climbing area, not so much the workout area) after 5:00.  Overall, PG is accessible for beginners (like me), but full of experienced climbers, and with a friendly atmosphere and great staff.   I'm hooked!

the best indoor rock climbing place in the south bay!  they also have bouldering and rock climbing classes.  i love this facility because it's big and there are so many different rope levels to climb.  they even offer classes for kids!  planet granite also has a gym equipment (cardio and weight machines) and offers yoga and cycling classes too.  ladies night is every other friday!  we get half off a day pass after 5pm.. must be belayed certified to climb here.  they also have competitions which are just awesome to watch!  advanced climbers can do things you would never even think about doing!  you can rent climbing gear or buy it at the gear shop.  rock climbing is a great way to challenge yourself to something new!

They have some weird rules. We have been annual members for about 2 years now and we had to take a break for a couple of months for of various reasons. Our annual membership expired while we were taking a break and when we decided to go back, they said that we need to pay the initiation fees all over again! I dont understand the concept of initiation fees to start with, but to charge us the initiation fees after we had been members for a couple of years is plain stupid. Are they interested in our membership fees or the initiation fees?

i gave it 3 stars because i havent been to any other indoor rock climbing places so i have nothing to compare it to. my first time going was kind of dissapointing because we went on a day where there was no staff to help with the large wall where you need a spotter and a rope. it was my own fault though because i didnt research first what days or times that the spotter was there. they had a nice variety of walls to choose from. it ranged from flat to curved walls that were crazy looking!! i felt so out of shape because there was people there that were climbing everything! i swear i saw spiderman come hang out here but i blinked and he left!! haha jk but really it was a great place to learn as like others mentioned, the staff was very helpful

A few friends introduced my wife and I to this place a few months back and we've been coming in religiously since then. I typically avoid gyms since I think they're really boring and I'd rather not commit to annual memberships.  PG has a lot of different things to keep you interested. You could top rope one day, boulder the next, join a yoga or spin class or just crank on some free weights.  The climbing is definitely the main attraction though since three-quarters of the place is either for top-roping or bouldering.  There's an abundance of routes and always something that kicks your butt and keeps you coming back for more.  The staff are friendly and helpful and the facility itself is neat and clean - although it usually smells like feet in there.  Overall I would recommend PG to anyone who's tired of the typical gyms and wants a fun activity to do instead of cranking on weights all day.  If you wanted you could at PG too, but the climbing is definitely more fun. The  cost of membership is ok. Definitely try to get the family memberships.

I've been going to this gym for almost a year now, so I'm due to write a positive note about the place.  I took the BRC class with a group of friends and a couple of us decided to become members.  It's both a great place to workout, climb, take yoga/spinning classes, and even socialize.  The staff is friendly, especially after you get to know them.  The gym does get crowded on weekday evenings, so try to go early or on the weekends when it's less busy.  I'll definitely be renewing my annual membership next year!

Love, love, love this place!  I've been a member for the past couple of years and couldn't say nicer things about it.  I was going to 24-hour fitness and found it a chore to go.  Not only did it feel like everyone was there to impress each other, all of the equipment was always full!  After signing up for Planet Granite, I have never had a problem getting on a machine, even at their peak time.  The classes are fantastic (yoga, abs & core class and spins classes) and climbing is just plain fun!  Never get bored of going to the gym which is saying a lot!

Just had my daughter's 9th bday here and it was great.  I especially want to give thanks to Cole who was the COOLEST guy helping out my group.  He was so nice and encouraging to the kids but especially the ones who were a little scared and tentative on climbing.  We really loved him.  Our party was from 10-12 which was ideal since it was not that busy be be warned.  It was really really cold there if you were not climbing.  My other guests, likes aunts and grandparents, were freezing but still really enjoyed themselves.   I was allowed to bring small snacks and bottled water for the kids but you will have to go to a nearby pizza place if you want to feed your guests.  I went to Jake's Pizza in Sunnyvale and it was more than awesome.  All the kids had a great time and it was an easy party for this parent to organize.  It is as pricey as a cooking or ice skating party so give it a try!  We loved it but definitely try and get Cole for your guests.  He was wonderful.

Great gim for climbing, yoga, spinning and else... They change routes a lot and climbing and bouldering areas are big and fun. Climbing and yoga teachers are professional and helpful. Cons are that on weekday-evenings it can get quite crowded, that they recently increased the membership fee and eliminated guest passes!!!

Can't say enough good things about Planet Granite. If you're crazy for rock climbing then plane granite is the place to be. if you are looking to learn then also this place can help you.  The staff is supportive and teach you everything you need to know.

This is the biggest rock gym I've EVER been to, and one of the coolest too!  There are endless amounts of bouldering and trad routes for climbers of all skill levels (from beginners to those crazy guys that just go right up to a V-10 and flash it with their eyes closed).  They also have basically a full gym with exercise bikes, ellipticals, treadmills, and weights...not to mention the yoga and climbing classes/groups.  The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because sometimes it's just TOO overwhelmingly busy, and I haven't made friends with any of the staff members because I rarely see the same ones twice (I know that it's a big place, and it's good that they have so many employees to help people, but I like to make friends at the rock gym, and this one is a little to big for me to get to know a lot of people).  The memberships are a little pricey, but If you close by it's well worth it because you get access to all the climbing and fitness stuff.
Decent routes, no fitness gym.  Uses Grigri's instead of ATCs.

cool place to climb. very spacious and big. still like touchstone more becuase its closer and all. but this place has gym bouldering and rock climbing. In addition OUTDOORS ROCK CLIMBING. so cool. but yea pretty cool place y'all!

The more people I talk to, the more I hear about terrible service and downright rudeness.  One of my co-workers was kicked out for answering a girl's question related to belaying (not supposed to teach others, but she asked him a question, and she was not kicked out).  I used to do yoga classes here, which were nice, but they fired the teacher (who was very good!), then had several different teachers take over (some were good, but consistency is good too).  Seems like they don't treat their employees very well and maybe they forward that mistreatment onto their customers!
